docs.title: Foot and Ankle Note Taka
docs.text: このサイトは、足部・足関節外科に関する臨床上の考え方や研究活動のうち、公開可能な内容を整理し、継続的に更新するための個人記録です。臨床実践における意思決定は、患者さんの背景、画像所見、検査結果、併存疾患、社会的な状況など、多くの要因が複雑に絡み合うため、このサイトの記載は一般論としての整理に留まり、個別の症例への直接的な適用を意図するものではありません。

docs.title: 目的
docs.text:
• 臨床: 繰り返し参照する概念、診断の手順、術式選択の考え方、合併症とその回避策を、再現可能な形でまとめています。
  • 研究: 既に発表した業績を一覧化し、研究テーマの位置づけを明確にしています。

docs.title: 免責
docs.text: このサイトの内容は、教育的・記録的な目的で作成されており、医療行為の指示や代替となるものではありません。診療上の最終的な判断は、担当医が一次情報に基づき、適切なプロトコルとガイドラインを踏まえて行うべきです。

docs.title: 公開範囲（重要）
docs.text: このサイトは公開を前提としているため、症例を特定できる情報や、執筆中の研究内容は掲載していません。具体的な運用のルールについては、「運用・公開ポリシー」のページをご覧ください。

docs.title: Thunder breathing と Water breathing
docs.text: このサイトの記述は、臨床と研究を区別して見せつつも、作業の根本原理は同じところに収束します。その根本を、比喩として "Thunder breathing"（雷の呼吸）と "Water breathing"（水の呼吸）で表現します。

docs.title: Thunder breathing（要点の一撃）
docs.text: Thunder breathingとは、ひとつの一撃で本質的な要点を選び取り、それを徹底してやり抜き、マスターする姿勢を指します。臨床であれば「診断とプランを同一のアルゴリズムで回し、次回の分岐まで含めて設計し切る」ことが一撃であり、研究であれば「問いとアウトカムを固定し、解析と論証の骨格を一気に通す」ことが一撃です。

docs.title: Water breathing（淡々と継続して定着）
docs.text: Water breathingとは、上記の一撃で確立した型を、水が流れるように淡々と続けることで、判断と記載の質を安定させる姿勢を指します。反復は惰性ではなく、同じ手順を日々の実務に埋め込むことで、抜け、偏り、先入観といった誤差を減らし、再現性を担保するための実装です。

docs.title: 運用・公開ポリシー（必読）
docs.text: このサイトは、足部・足関節外科に関する知識と作業手順を、Markdownで継続的に整理するための公開ノートです。一方で、医療情報は本質的に再同定のリスクを含み、公開に伴う倫理的・法的な責任が不可避です。したがって、このポリシーは「何を載せるか」ではなく、まず「何を載せないか」を明示し、公開可能性の境界を固定することを目的としています。

docs.title: 1. 公開してよい情報（原則）
docs.text:
• 一般化された知識: 診断アルゴリズム、鑑別の軸、評価手順、術式選択の前提、合併症と回避策など
  • 教育的な型: 外来プレゼンの型、問診の型、手術記録の型（具体的な症例に依存しない骨格）
  • 既発表の業績: 公開済みの論文、発表、研究費などの書誌情報

docs.title: 2. 公開してはいけない情報（禁止）
docs.text:
• 症例を特定できる情報（単体または組み合わせで特定されうるもの）
  • 日時、施設、地域、稀少疾患、特徴的な既往、職業、競技歴、きわめて特異な画像所見の連続提示など
  • 未匿名化データ
  • 画像DICOM、生データ、検査結果、自由記載、音声、動画など
  • 未公開の研究内容
  • 投稿準備中の原稿、査読対応、解析途中の結果、共同研究の未公表情報

docs.title: 3. 「研究：執筆中」を確実に非公開にする運用
docs.text:
このリポジトリでは、執筆中の原稿をprivate/フォルダ以下に配置します。private/は.gitignoreにより追跡されず、GitHub Pagesの公開物にも含まれません。

ただし、これは「公開リポジトリに載らない」ための技術的な措置であり、機微情報の保護を完全に代替するものではありません。機密性の高い情報は、所属施設の規程および情報セキュリティ方針に従ってください。

docs.title: 4. 公開前チェック（最小チェックリスト）
docs.text:
• 症例を特定できる要素が残っていないか（組み合わせによる再同定を含む）
  • 画像・図表の権利（撮影者、施設、出版社）の問題がないか
  • 共同研究・学会発表の未公表情報が混入していないか
  • 「次回アクション」「術中分岐」などの記載が、個別症例の時系列や希少性を露呈していないか

docs.title: Temp
docs.text:
ご提示いただいた画像は、糖尿病性足潰瘍（Diabetic Foot Ulcer: DFU）や慢性創傷の治癒を阻害する「9つの主要な因子（Detriments）」をまとめたリストです。これらは、創傷治癒の現場で評価すべきチェックリストとして非常に実践的な内容です。 整形外科的な視点（足の変形や荷重）と、内科的な視点（血糖管理や栄養）が網羅されています。各項目について、医学的エビデンスや国際的なガイドライン（IWGDFなど）に基づき詳しく解説します。 9つの阻害因子についての詳細解説とエビデンス 1. Edema（浮腫） * 内容: 静脈不全や炎症によるコントロール不良な浮腫。患部の挙上や圧迫（弾性ストッキング等）が行われているか。 * 臨床的意義: 浮腫は組織間質の圧力を高め、微小循環（Microcirculation）を阻害し、酸素や栄養の供給を妨げます。 * エビデンス: * 静脈性潰瘍において圧迫療法は推奨グレードA（WHSガイドライン）ですが、糖尿病患者ではPAD（末梢動脈疾患）の合併に注意が必要です。ABI（足関節上腕血圧比）を確認せず圧迫すると虚血を悪化させるリスクがあります。 2. Circulation（循環・血流） * 内容: 灌流（Perfusion）の状態。NIVS（非侵襲的血管検査）は行われたか？ 虚血、貧血、COPDの既往。 * 臨床的意義: 創傷治癒には酸素供給が不可欠です。CLTI（包括的高度慢性下肢虚血）の除外が最優先です。 * エビデンス: * IWGDFガイドラインでは、足潰瘍を持つ患者全員に対してPADの評価（足関節圧、趾収縮期血圧: TBIなど）を推奨しています。 * 一般に、創傷治癒には足関節圧 >50 mmHg、SPP（皮膚灌流圧） >30-40 mmHgが必要とされています。 3. Physical Deformity（足の変形） * 内容: シャルコー関節（Charcot foot）、骨性の変形。 * 臨床的意義: 構造的な変形（槌指、外反母趾、シャルコー足）は、足底の特定部位に異常なピーク圧（Peak Plantar Pressure）を生じさせ、潰瘍の原因となります。 * エビデンス: * オフローディング（免荷）が治療の鍵です。IWGDFは、足底潰瘍に対して「膝下までの非脱着式免荷装具（TCCなど）」を第一選択として強く推奨しています。変形により靴擦れ（Shoe conflict）が起きることも再発の主要因です。 4. Glucose Control（血糖コントロール） * 内容: HbA1cの管理（メモ書きの「≠7」は、目標値7.0%未達、あるいは高値であることを示唆していると思われます）、代謝状態。 * 臨床的意義: 高血糖は白血球（好中球）の遊走能や貪食能を低下させ、感染リスクを高めます。また、血管新生を阻害します。 * エビデンス: * 長期的な予後において血糖コントロールは重要ですが、創傷治癒速度とHbA1cの直接的な相関については議論があります。しかし、米国糖尿病学会（ADA）などは、合併症予防のためにHbA1c 7.0%未満（患者背景により個別化）を推奨しています。 5. Smoking（喫煙） * 内容: タバコ、マリファナ、電子タバコ。 * 臨床的意義: ニコチンによる血管収縮と、一酸化炭素による酸素運搬能の低下により、組織低酸素を引き起こします。 * エビデンス: * 喫煙は創傷治癒遅延の独立した危険因子です。また、喫煙者の糖尿病患者は、非喫煙者に比べて切断リスクが有意に高いことが多数のコホート研究で示されています。 6. Infection/Inflammation（感染/炎症） * 内容: 感染徴候、慢性の炎症プロセス。 * 臨床的意義: 感染はバイオフィルム形成を伴い、治癒プロセスを「炎症期」で停滞させます。骨髄炎（Osteomyelitis）の合併を見逃さないことが重要です。 * エビデンス: * IDSA（米国感染症学会）およびIWGDFのガイドラインでは、「プローブ・トゥ・ボーン（Probe-to-Bone）テスト」が陽性の場合、骨髄炎の可能性が高いとしています。表層の培養ではなく、深部組織培養が推奨されます。 7. Trauma（外力・外傷） * 内容: 繰り返される圧力、摩擦（Friction）、ずれ応力（Shear forces）、荷重分散。 * 臨床的意義: いわゆる「靴擦れ」や不適切なインソール、歩行時の剪断力です。これらが除去されない限り、どんな良い軟膏を使っても傷は治りません。 * エビデンス: * 「It's not what you put on, but what you take off（何をつけるかではなく、何を取り除くか）」という格言通り、物理的なメカニカルストレスの除去がエビデンスレベルの高い介入です。 8. Nutrition（栄養） * 内容: 低アルブミン、ビタミンC、ビタミンD欠乏。 * 臨床的意義: タンパク質はコラーゲン合成の基質であり、ビタミンCはコラーゲンの架橋形成に必須です。低栄養は創傷治癒遅延に直結します。 * エビデンス: * 血清アルブミン値 <3.0 g/dL あるいは <3.5 g/dL は、創傷治癒不全や切断後の予後不良の予測因子とされています（ESPENガイドライン等）。 9. Other（その他） * 内容: メンタルヘルス、ストレス、疼痛、その他の治療。 * 臨床的意義: うつ状態や認知機能低下は、治療へのアドヒアランス（免荷を守れるか、通院できるか）を著しく低下させます。 * エビデンス: * 糖尿病患者におけるうつ病の合併率は高く、これがセルフケア行動の欠如につながり、潰瘍再発リスクを高めることが指摘されています。 まとめ このリストは、単に「傷を見る」のではなく、「傷を持っている患者の背景（全身状態・生活習慣・バイオメカニクス）を見る」という、包括的アプローチ（Holistic Approach）の重要性を示しています。 特にIWGDF（International Working Group on the Diabetic Foot）のガイドラインは、これらの要素を「予防」「オフローディング」「PAD」「感染」「創傷管理」の5つの柱で整理しており、このメモの内容と完全に合致します。

以下は、（画像で示されているような）糖尿病フットケアの要点を、臨床でそのまま説明・指導に使える粒度で整理したものです。根拠として、IWGDF（国際糖尿病足病変ガイドライン）2023/2024、ADA（米国糖尿病学会）Standards of Care 2026（2025年末公開）、NICE（英国）NG19（2025年7月レビュー）などを参照しています。

1) そもそも「なぜ足が危ないか」（患者説明の軸）

糖尿病足病変は主に ①保護感覚低下（LOPS：末梢神経障害）、②末梢動脈疾患（PAD）、③足変形（圧集中）が組み合わさって発生します。IWGDFも主要リスクとしてこれらを明示しています。 また、糖尿病関連足潰瘍は生涯で一定割合に起こり、治癒しても再発が多いため「予防が最重要」です（再発率：1年で約40%、3年で約65%など）。

2) 毎日のセルフケア（画像の“ポイント”の中核）

A. 毎日見る（観察）

足背〜足底、趾間、踵、爪周囲まで「毎日」確認

見えない場合は 割れない鏡、または家族の介助

“赤み・腫れ・熱感・水疱・ひび割れ・浸出液・皮膚色変化・悪臭”は要注意（早期受診のトリガー）

IWGDFは、リスクのある人（IWGDF risk 1–3）に対し毎日の足チェックと、（前）潰瘍性病変を疑ったら速やかに訓練された医療者へ連絡するよう推奨しています。 ADAも、教育内容として毎日の足の観察を明確に含めています。

B. 洗浄・乾燥・保湿（ただし趾間は避ける）

毎日洗う（熱すぎない湯）→ 趾間までよく乾かす

乾燥・落屑には保湿剤（ただし趾間は過湿で白癬/浸軟リスク）

ADAは初期管理として、毎日の観察とともに乾燥皮膚への保湿を含めています。

C. 爪・胼胝（自己処理を減らす）

深爪・角を攻める切り方は避け、可能ならフットケア外来/足病ケアへ

胼胝・魚の目・巻き爪・陥入爪は自己処置が潰瘍の起点になりやすい

ADAは、陥入爪や胼胝の自己処置を避けることを具体的に述べています。

IWGDFも、前潰瘍病変や過剰胼胝の適切な治療を推奨します。

D. 靴・靴下（“足を守る医療機器”として扱う）

裸足で歩かない（屋内も）

きつい靴、先の細い靴、サンダル/つっかけは避ける

新しい靴は短時間から慣らし、履く前に中を触って異物確認

足変形や足底胼胝がある場合は、適切な靴型や減圧インソール/装具を検討

ADAは教育項目として、裸足回避や靴の選択を明示し、治療用フットウェア/カスタム装具が足底圧を下げることにも触れています。 IWGDFも、足リスクに応じた適切なフットウェアや統合的予防ケアを重視します。

E. 熱傷・外傷の回避（感覚低下があるほど重要）

湯たんぽ、電気毛布、カイロ、床暖房、こたつでの低温熱傷に注意

直に当てない、温度を手で確認できない場合は使用しない

自分で角質を削る器具・カミソリ使用は避ける（微小外傷→感染）

（これらはガイドラインの“セルフケア教育”の定番構成で、LOPS/PAD/変形の理解と日々の観察・爪/皮膚ケアを含めた教育が推奨されています。）

3) 「受診を急ぐ」危険サイン（指導で必須）

潰瘍（皮膚が開いた）

腫れ・赤み・熱感・疼痛の増悪（痛みが乏しくても熱感は要注意）

浸出液・悪臭・黒色壊死

足が急に温かく腫れて赤い（潰瘍がなくてもCharcotを疑う）

ADAは、開放性潰瘍や原因不明の腫脹/発赤/熱感があれば緊急紹介を明記しています（Charcot疑いも含む）。 感染が疑われる場合の評価・治療はIWGDF/IDSA感染ガイドラインが国際標準です。

4) 医療者側：定期スクリーニング（最低限ここまで）

A. 年1回以上の包括的フット評価

ADAは、少なくとも年1回の包括的フット評価を推奨し、内容として

皮膚の観察

変形評価

神経（10gモノフィラメント、またはIpswich touch＋追加検査）

血管（足背/後脛骨動脈など脈拍） を明示しています。

B. 高リスクは「毎回診察で足を見る」

ADAは、感覚低下や潰瘍/切断既往があれば毎回の受診で足の観察を推奨します。

C. NICE：診断時＋年1回＋入院時などで評価

NICEは、糖尿病患者の足リスク評価を診断時および少なくとも年1回、加えて入院時などでも行うことを推奨しています。

5) IWGDFの「リスク別フォロー頻度」（運用に便利）

IWGDFは、統合的フットケア（専門的フットケア＋適切なフットウェア＋構造化教育）を、リスクに応じて繰り返し提供することを推奨し、目安として

高リスク：1〜3か月ごと

中等度：3〜6か月ごと を示しています。

リスクのイメージ 典型例 フォロー目安

低〜中等度 LOPSやPAD、変形などがある 3〜6か月 高リスク 潰瘍/切断既往、重い変形、腎不全合併など 1〜3か月

（厳密な区分は施設運用に合わせ、IWGDF risk分類を併用すると安定します。）

6) エビデンスの質感（患者教育で誤解されやすい点）

フットケア教育は重要ですが、「教育だけで潰瘍が有意に減る」と断言できるほど強いデータは一貫していません（IWGDFはRCTのメタ解析でRR低下傾向を示しつつ、信頼区間が幅広い点も示しています）。

そのため実臨床では、教育＋定期評価＋胼胝処置＋適切な靴/装具（減圧）＋早期受診導線を「セット」で回すのがガイドラインの考え方です。

docs.title: 臨床
docs.text: このページ群では、足部・足関節領域の臨床トピックを、臨床推論の手順が追跡できる形で整理します。具体的には、(1)鑑別診断の軸、(2)評価手順（身体所見・画像・検査）、(3)治療選択（保存／手術）と適応、(4)合併症と再手術シナリオ、を最小単位として記載しています。

docs.title: 運用方針
docs.text:
• 公開範囲: 教育的・一般化可能な内容に限定し、症例を特定できる情報は扱いません。
  • 更新: トピック単位で追記し、後日修正を前提とする「生きたノート」として運用します。

docs.title: これから追加する項目
docs.text:
• 外反母趾：術式選択の前提（変形要素の分解）
  • 後脛骨筋腱機能不全：ステージングと治療戦略
  • 足関節不安定症：保存療法の限界と術式選択
  • 距骨軟骨損傷：病態分類と治療アルゴリズム

docs.title: 身体診察の順序（下肢・足部）
docs.text: 系統的な診察は、患者の体位変換を最小限にし、見落としを防ぐために一定の順序で行います。以下は足部・足関節を中心とした下肢診察の標準的な流れです。

docs.title: 1. 正面立位（Standing, anterior view）
docs.text:
• 膝のアライメント（genu varum / valgum）
  • 下肢全体のアライメント

docs.title: 2. 背面立位（Standing, posterior view）
docs.text:
• 脊柱のアライメント（側弯、後弯）
  • 膝窩の対称性
  • 後足部アライメント（hindfoot varus / valgus）
  • アキレス腱の走行

docs.title: 3. 歩行観察（Gait）
docs.text:
• 歩行パターン
  • 足部外旋（foot progression angle）
  • 跛行の有無

docs.title: 4. 椅子座位（Sitting）
docs.text:
• 膝Jサイン（patellar tracking）
  • 足関節可動域（dorsiflexion / plantarflexion）
  • 外側靭帯（ATFL, CFL）
  • 内側靭帯（deltoid ligament）
  • 後脛骨筋腱（tibialis posterior tendon）
  • 腓骨筋腱（peroneal tendons）
  • 足部の可動域と疼痛誘発テスト

docs.title: 5. 仰臥位（Supine）
docs.text: ） - 脚長（leg length: true / apparent） - 股関節可動域（hip ROM） - 膝可動域（knee ROM） - 膝安定性テスト（Lachman, drawer, varus/valgus stress） - 股関節伸展（hip extension / Thomas test）

docs.title: 6. 腹臥位（Prone）
docs.text:
• 股関節前捻（hip anteversion / femoral rotation）
  • 下腿脚長（tibial length）
  • 足部外旋（thigh-foot angle）

docs.title: 会話フレーズ集（患者との対話用）
docs.text: このページは、診察室で患者と直接コミュニケーションを取る際に使用する実践的な英語フレーズ集です。挨拶から診断説明、治療計画の共有、手術の説明まで、外来診療の各段階で使用できるフレーズを整理しています。

docs.title: 初診時
docs.text:
• Good morning / Good afternoon. My name is Dr. Taka Ogawa. I'm from Japan, and I'll be taking care of you today. (professional, warm)
  • Nice to meet you. I'm Dr. Taka Ogawa. Please, have a seat. (friendly, casual)
  • Hello, [PATIENT]. Thank you for coming in. I'm Dr. Taka Ogawa, and I'm a foot and ankle surgeon. I'm originally from Japan. (professional, informative)
  • Good morning, [PATIENT]. It's a pleasure to meet you. I'm Dr. Taka Ogawa, and I'll be conducting your examination today. (formal, polite)

docs.title: 再診時
docs.text:
• Good to see you again, [PATIENT]. How have you been? (friendly)
  • Welcome back, [PATIENT]. How are things going since we last met? (warm, professional)
  • It's good to see you again. Let's see how you're doing. (casual, friendly)
  • Hello again, [PATIENT]. I trust you've been well since our last visit. (formal, polite)

docs.title: 名前の発音について（必要に応じて）
docs.text:
• My name is Taka Ogawa—you can call me Dr. Ogawa if that's easier. (casual, friendly)
  • Please feel free to call me Dr. Ogawa if that's more comfortable for you. (polite)

docs.title: オープンクエスチョン
docs.text:
• What brings you in today? (casual, direct)
  • What's the main problem you're experiencing? (friendly, professional)
  • Tell me about what's been bothering you. (warm, conversational)
  • What would you like me to help you with today? (friendly)
  • How may I assist you today? (formal, polite)
  • Could you please describe what concerns have brought you to see me? (formal, polite)

docs.title: 機能障害としての主訴の確認
docs.text:
• What is the main thing that's bothering you? Is it the pain itself, or is there something you're not able to do because of it? (friendly, thorough)
  • What activities have become difficult for you? (direct, professional)
  • What's the biggest limitation in your daily life right now? (casual, empathetic)
  • I'd like to understand how this is affecting your daily activities. Could you describe what has become challenging for you? (formal, empathetic)

docs.title: 症状の性質
docs.text:
• Can you describe the pain for me? Is it sharp, dull, aching, or burning? (friendly, direct)
  • Where exactly do you feel the pain? Can you point to it? (casual)
  • Does the pain stay in one place, or does it spread or radiate? (professional)
  • How would you rate the pain on a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 is no pain and 10 is the worst pain you can imagine? (standard clinical)
  • Could you please describe the nature of the pain you're experiencing? (formal, polite)
  • I'd appreciate if you could indicate the precise location of your discomfort. (formal, polite)

docs.title: 時間経過
docs.text:
• When did this start? (casual, direct)
  • Was there a specific injury or event that triggered it? (friendly)
  • Has it been getting better, worse, or staying about the same? (conversational)
  • Does it come and go, or is it constant? (direct)
  • Could you tell me when you first noticed these symptoms? (polite)
  • Has there been any change in the severity since onset? (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 機能への影響
docs.text:
• How far can you walk before it becomes a problem? (direct, practical)
  • Are stairs difficult for you? (casual)
  • Can you stand for long periods? (direct)
  • Does it affect your sleep? (friendly, concerned)
  • Have you had to change your activities at work or home? (conversational)
  • Could you describe how this condition is impacting your daily activities? (formal, polite)
  • I'd like to understand the extent to which this affects your mobility. (formal, professional)

docs.title: 増悪・軽快因子
docs.text:
• What makes it worse? Walking, standing, rest, or certain movements? (direct, helpful)
  • What makes it better? Rest, medication, or specific positions? (friendly)
  • Is it worse in the morning, during the day, or at night? (clinical)
  • Are there any activities or positions that exacerbate the discomfort? (formal, clinical)
  • Have you identified any factors that provide relief? (polite, professional)

docs.title: 腫脹・炎症徴候
docs.text:
• Have you noticed any swelling? (casual, direct)
  • Does the swelling get worse during the day? (conversational)
  • Is the area warm or red? (direct, clinical)
  • Does it feel stiff, especially in the morning? (friendly)
  • Have you observed any inflammation or changes in appearance? (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 神経症状
docs.text:
• Do you have any numbness or tingling? (direct)
  • Any weakness or feeling of instability? (casual, quick)
  • Does it feel like pins and needles? (conversational, descriptive)
  • Have you experienced any sensory changes, such as numbness or paresthesia? (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 既往治療
docs.text:
• Have you tried any treatments for this? (casual)
  • What have you done so far? Physiotherapy, medication, injections, or braces? (friendly, comprehensive)
  • How long did you try [TREATMENT]? Did it help at all? (conversational)
  • Are you currently taking any medications for this? (professional)
  • Could you describe any previous treatments you've undertaken? (formal, polite)
  • What has been your experience with prior interventions? (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 4. 身体所見の説明（患者への説明）
診察の開始
docs.text:
• Now, let me take a look at your [FOOT/ANKLE/LEG]. I'm going to examine the area, check the movement, and see where the pain is. (friendly, informative)
  • Please let me know if anything hurts or if you feel uncomfortable. (caring, casual)
  • I'm going to touch different areas—tell me if any spot is particularly tender. (direct, helpful)
  • I'd like to conduct a physical examination now. Please inform me if you experience any discomfort. (formal, polite)
  • With your permission, I'll now examine the affected area. (very polite, formal)

docs.title: 診察中の説明
docs.text:
• I can see some swelling here. (neutral, observational)
  • There's tenderness when I press here. (clinical, matter-of-fact)
  • The range of motion is a bit limited. (professional)
  • The alignment looks [normal / slightly off]. (casual, clinical)
  • I notice [DEFORMITY / SWELLING / SKIN CHANGES]. (neutral)
  • I'm observing some [FINDING] in this area. (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 診察の終了
docs.text:
• Thank you. That's helpful. Let me explain what I found. (friendly, appreciative)
  • Thank you for your cooperation. I'll now discuss my findings with you. (formal, polite)

docs.title: 診断の提示
docs.text:
• Based on what you've told me and what I found on examination, I believe you have [DIAGNOSIS]. (friendly, professional)
  • The symptoms and examination findings are consistent with [DIAGNOSIS]. (clinical, straightforward)
  • Essentially, this means [SIMPLE EXPLANATION IN PLAIN LANGUAGE]. (casual, educational)
  • After reviewing your history and examination, my assessment is that you have [DIAGNOSIS]. (formal, professional)
  • The clinical presentation suggests [DIAGNOSIS]. (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 診断の説明（平易な言葉で）
docs.text:
Plantar fasciitis: - This is inflammation of the thick band of tissue on the bottom of your foot. It's a common cause of heel pain. (casual, clear) - You have inflammation in the plantar fascia, which is the supportive structure on the sole of your foot. (formal, descriptive)

Achilles tendinopathy: - This is a problem with the tendon at the back of your heel. It can become painful and swollen, often due to overuse. (friendly, explanatory) - The Achilles tendon has developed a degenerative condition, typically related to repetitive strain. (formal, clinical)

Ankle instability: - The ligaments that hold your ankle stable have been stretched or damaged, which can cause the ankle to feel unstable or give way. (conversational, descriptive) - There is laxity in the lateral ankle ligaments, resulting in mechanical instability. (formal, clinical)

Hallux valgus (bunion): - This is a deformity where the big toe angles toward the other toes, creating a bony bump on the side of the foot. (casual, clear) - This condition involves angular deviation of the first metatarsophalangeal joint. (very formal, clinical)

Osteoarthritis: - This is wear and tear of the joint cartilage, which can cause pain, stiffness, and reduced movement. (friendly, understandable) - This represents degenerative changes to the articular cartilage, a progressive condition. (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 鑑別診断の説明（必要に応じて）
docs.text:
• There are a few possibilities we need to consider. The most likely is [DIAGNOSIS], but we should also rule out [ALTERNATIVE]. (friendly, thorough)
  • To be sure, I'd like to order some tests to confirm the diagnosis. (casual, practical)
  • We must consider several differential diagnoses. I recommend further investigation to establish a definitive diagnosis. (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 検査の提案
docs.text:
• I'd like to order [X-RAY / MRI / CT / ULTRASOUND] to get a better picture of what's going on. (friendly, conversational)
  • This will help us confirm the diagnosis and plan the best treatment. (practical, clear)
  • The results should be available in about [TIMEFRAME]. (informative)
  • I recommend obtaining [IMAGING] to better characterize the condition. (formal, professional)
  • It would be prudent to perform [INVESTIGATION] for a comprehensive assessment. (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 画像所見の説明
docs.text:
• The X-ray shows [FINDING IN PLAIN LANGUAGE]. (casual, clear)
  • The MRI confirms [DIAGNOSIS] and shows [RELEVANT DETAILS]. (professional, informative)
  • The good news is [POSITIVE FINDING]. However, we can see [CONCERNING FINDING]. (friendly, balanced)
  • The imaging demonstrates [FINDING]. (formal, clinical)
  • The radiographic findings reveal [FINDING], which is consistent with our clinical assessment. (formal, professional)

docs.title: 保存療法の提案
docs.text:
• I recommend we start with non-surgical treatment. This includes [TREATMENT OPTIONS]. (professional, clear)
  • Let's try [PHYSIOTHERAPY / ORTHOTICS / MEDICATION / INJECTION] for [DURATION] and see how you respond. (friendly, collaborative)
  • Most people improve with these conservative measures. (reassuring, casual)
  • I propose we initiate conservative management with [TREATMENT]. (formal, professional)
  • The recommended approach is to commence non-operative treatment. (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 治療の目的と期待値
docs.text:
• The goal is to [REDUCE PAIN / IMPROVE FUNCTION / PREVENT PROGRESSION]. (direct, clear)
  • This should help with [SPECIFIC SYMPTOM]. (casual, practical)
  • It may take [TIMEFRAME] to see improvement, so please be patient. (friendly, realistic)
  • Our objective is to [TREATMENT GOAL] while minimizing intervention. (formal, professional)
  • The anticipated outcome is [EXPECTED RESULT] over the course of treatment. (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 治療の期限と評価
docs.text:
• We'll try this for [DURATION], and then we'll reassess. (casual, practical)
  • If you're not better by [TIMEFRAME], we'll need to consider other options. (conversational, planning)
  • We shall implement this treatment plan and reevaluate at [TIMEFRAME]. (formal, professional)

docs.title: 手術の提案
docs.text:
• Given that conservative treatment hasn't provided enough relief, I believe surgery would be the best option for you. (professional, direct)
  • Surgery can help by [SPECIFIC BENEFIT: e.g., stabilizing the ankle, correcting the deformity, removing damaged tissue]. (friendly, informative)
  • Considering the limited response to conservative measures, I recommend we discuss surgical intervention. (formal, professional)
  • In light of the persistent symptoms, a surgical approach would be most appropriate. (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 手術のリスクとベネフィット
docs.text:
Benefits: - The main benefits are [IMPROVED STABILITY / PAIN RELIEF / FUNCTIONAL IMPROVEMENT / DEFORMITY CORRECTION]. - This should allow you to [RETURN TO ACTIVITIES / REDUCE PAIN / IMPROVE QUALITY OF LIFE].

Risks: - As with any surgery, there are risks. The main ones include: - Infection (though this is uncommon) - Nerve injury, which could cause numbness or tingling - Stiffness or reduced range of motion - Blood clots (DVT/PE) - The problem could come back (recurrence) - Anaesthetic risks

Natural history (手術をしない場合): - If we don't treat this, [PROBLEM] may get worse over time, potentially leading to [LONG-TERM CONSEQUENCES: e.g., more pain, further joint damage, increased difficulty with activities].

docs.title: 術後回復の説明
docs.text:
• After surgery, you'll need to [NON-WEIGHT-BEARING / WEIGHT-BEARING IN BOOT] for about [DURATION].
  • You'll be in a [CAST / BOOT / SPLINT] for [DURATION].
  • Physiotherapy will start at [TIMEFRAME] and focus on [GOALS].
  • Full recovery typically takes [TIMEFRAME], though this varies from person to person.
  • You'll need to take [DURATION] off work, depending on your job.

docs.title: 意思決定の確認
docs.text:
• I've explained the procedure, the risks, and the expected recovery. Do you have any questions? (professional, thorough)
  • I'd like you to take some time to think about this. There's no rush—we can discuss it again at your next visit. (friendly, supportive)
  • If you decide to proceed, we can schedule the surgery. Just let us know when you're ready. (casual, collaborative)
  • Please take the time you need to consider this information. We can arrange a follow-up discussion at your convenience. (formal, polite)
  • I encourage you to reflect on this decision. Should you wish to proceed, please inform us, and we shall make the necessary arrangements. (very formal, polite)

docs.title: 9. フォローアップの説明
次回予定
docs.text:
• I'd like to see you back in [TIMEFRAME] to review how you're doing. (friendly, clear)
  • We'll review the test results and decide on the next steps together. (collaborative, professional)
  • Please make an appointment for [DATE / TIMEFRAME]. (direct, practical)
  • I would like to schedule a follow-up appointment in [TIMEFRAME]. (formal, professional)
  • Please arrange a review consultation for [TIMEFRAME] at your convenience. (formal, polite)

docs.title: 分岐の説明（If-Then）
docs.text:
• If the symptoms improve with the current treatment, we'll continue and gradually reduce the support. (casual, encouraging)
  • If the symptoms persist or get worse, we'll need to consider [NEXT STEP: e.g., injection, surgery, further imaging]. (professional, contingency)
  • If the test shows [FINDING A], then we'll proceed with [TREATMENT B]. (clear, logical)
  • On the other hand, if [FINDING C], we can continue with conservative management. (conversational)
  • Should the conservative approach prove unsuccessful, we shall reassess and consider alternative interventions. (formal, professional)

docs.title: 緊急時の対応
docs.text:
• If things get suddenly worse, or if you notice [RED FLAGS: e.g., increasing numbness, spreading redness, severe pain], please don't wait for your appointment—call us right away or go to the emergency department. (urgent, caring)
  • If you have any concerns before your next visit, please contact the clinic. (friendly, accessible)
  • Should you experience any concerning symptoms, please seek immediate medical attention. (formal, serious)

docs.title: 術後経過の確認
docs.text:
• How are you feeling after the surgery? (friendly, caring)
  • How is the pain? Is it manageable? (direct, concerned)
  • Are you able to follow the weight-bearing restrictions? (professional, checking)
  • Any concerns or problems? (casual, open)
  • How has your postoperative course been? (formal, professional)
  • Are you experiencing any difficulties with the prescribed protocol? (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 術後所見の説明
docs.text:
• The wound is healing well. (reassuring, clear)
  • The swelling is normal at this stage—it should gradually improve. (friendly, informative)
  • The X-rays look good. The [IMPLANT / FUSION / REPAIR] is in the right position. (casual, positive)
  • The surgical site is healing appropriately. (formal, clinical)
  • The radiographic findings demonstrate satisfactory positioning. (formal, technical)

docs.title: 術後計画の説明
docs.text:
• You can now start [WEIGHT-BEARING / REMOVE BOOT / INCREASE ACTIVITY]. (direct, encouraging)
  • Continue with the exercises we discussed. (casual, reminding)
  • We'll see you again in [TIMEFRAME] to check your progress. (friendly, scheduled)
  • You are now cleared to progress to [NEXT PHASE]. (formal, authorizing)
  • Please continue with your rehabilitation program as outlined. (formal, instructive)

docs.title: 11. よくある質問への対応
治療期間について
docs.text: • Q: How long will this take to get better? A: Most people start to see improvement within [TIMEFRAME], but full recovery can take [TIMEFRAME]. It varies from person to person.

docs.title: 運動・活動について
docs.text: • Q: Can I still exercise / play sports? A: For now, I'd recommend avoiding [HIGH-IMPACT ACTIVITIES]. You can continue with [LOW-IMPACT ACTIVITIES: e.g., swimming, cycling] if they don't cause pain.

docs.title: 仕事への影響
docs.text: • Q: Can I still work? A: It depends on your job. If you have a desk job, you should be fine. If your work involves [STANDING / WALKING / HEAVY LIFTING], you may need to modify your activities or take some time off.

docs.title: 手術の必要性
docs.text: • Q: Do I really need surgery? A: Surgery is one option, but it's not always necessary. Let's try conservative treatment first. If that doesn't work after [TIMEFRAME], then we can discuss surgery again.

docs.title: 痛みの管理
docs.text: • Q: What can I take for the pain? A: You can take [PARACETAMOL / NSAIDs] as needed. If the pain is severe, let me know and we can discuss stronger options.

docs.title: 質問の確認
docs.text:
• Do you have any questions? Please feel free to ask about anything, no matter how small. (friendly, open)
  • Is there anything else you'd like to know? (casual, inviting)
  • Does that make sense? Let me know if you'd like me to explain anything again. (conversational, supportive)
  • Please don't hesitate to ask if you have any questions or concerns. (formal, polite)
  • Are there any aspects you would like me to clarify further? (formal, professional)

docs.title: 閉めの言葉
docs.text:
• Alright, I'll see you in [TIMEFRAME]. Take care, and I hope you feel better soon. (friendly, warm)
  • Thank you for coming in today. We'll be in touch about [NEXT STEP]. (professional, clear)
  • Feel free to call if you have any concerns before your next visit. (casual, accessible)
  • Have a good day, and take care of yourself. (warm, caring)
  • Thank you for your time today. I look forward to seeing you at your next appointment. (formal, polite)
  • I wish you a smooth recovery. Please contact us should any issues arise. (formal, professional)

docs.title: 13. 文化的配慮（必要に応じて）
言語の確認
docs.text:
• Do you prefer to speak in English, or would you like an interpreter? (considerate, practical)
  • If anything I said wasn't clear, please let me know—I want to make sure you understand everything. (friendly, caring)
  • Would you be more comfortable with an interpreter present? (polite, accommodating)
  • Please inform me if you require interpretation services for our discussion. (formal, professional)

docs.title: 理解度の確認
docs.text:
• Let me make sure I've explained this clearly. Can you tell me what you understand about [DIAGNOSIS / TREATMENT PLAN]? (friendly, checking)
  • I want to make sure we're on the same page. What questions do you have? (casual, collaborative)
  • May I ask you to summarize your understanding to ensure clarity? (formal, educational)
  • I would like to confirm your comprehension of the treatment plan. (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 患者が不安な場合
docs.text:
• I understand this can be worrying. Let's take it one step at a time. (empathetic, reassuring)
  • It's normal to feel anxious about [SURGERY / DIAGNOSIS]. We'll work through this together. (supportive, collaborative)
  • I appreciate this is a concerning situation. Please know that I'm here to support you through this process. (formal, empathetic)
  • Your concerns are completely understandable. Allow me to address them comprehensively. (formal, validating)

docs.title: 患者が治療に消極的な場合
docs.text:
• I understand that [SURGERY / TREATMENT] can seem daunting. Let's discuss your concerns. (friendly, open)
  • What are your main worries? Let's address them one by one. (casual, systematic)
  • I respect your hesitation. May we discuss what aspects concern you most? (formal, respectful)
  • I would like to understand your reservations so we can address them appropriately. (formal, professional)

docs.title: 予後が不確実な場合
docs.text:
• It's difficult to predict exactly how this will progress, but based on similar cases, [TYPICAL OUTCOME]. (honest, informative)
  • We'll monitor you closely and adjust the treatment as needed. (reassuring, flexible)
  • While the exact trajectory is uncertain, we will provide close monitoring and modify our approach as indicated. (formal, clinical)

docs.title: コミュニケーションの原則
docs.text:
• Listen actively: Give the patient time to speak, and acknowledge their concerns.
  • Use plain language: Avoid medical jargon. If you must use technical terms, explain them.
  • Check for understanding: Ask "Does that make sense?" or "Do you have any questions?"
  • Be empathetic: Acknowledge the patient's pain and concerns.
  • Set realistic expectations: Be honest about what treatment can and cannot achieve.

docs.title: 時間管理
docs.text:
• If time is limited, prioritize: (1) chief complaint, (2) key examination findings, (3) diagnosis and plan, (4) follow-up.
  • For complex cases, consider scheduling a longer appointment or a follow-up to discuss options in detail.

docs.title: 文化的背景の考慮
docs.text:
• As a surgeon from Japan, you may encounter cultural differences. Be respectful and open to different perspectives on health and treatment.
  • Some patients may prefer more direct communication, while others may prefer a more gradual approach. Adjust your style as needed.

docs.title: 16. よく使う表現のバリエーション
痛みの確認
docs.text:
• Where does it hurt? (casual, direct)
  • Can you show me where the pain is? (friendly, practical)
  • Point to where it's most painful. (direct, simple)
  • Could you please indicate the location of your discomfort? (formal, polite)

docs.title: 理解度の確認
docs.text:
• Does that make sense? (casual, checking)
  • Are you with me so far? (friendly, conversational)
  • Do you follow what I'm saying? (casual, checking)
  • Is my explanation clear? (professional)
  • Do you have a clear understanding of what I've explained? (formal, thorough)

docs.title: 同意の確認
docs.text:
• Does that sound reasonable? (casual, collaborative)
  • Are you comfortable with this plan? (friendly, checking)
  • Does this work for you? (casual, flexible)
  • Is this approach acceptable to you? (formal, respectful)
  • Do you consent to proceed with this treatment plan? (formal, clinical)

docs.title: 追加情報の依頼
docs.text:
• Tell me more about that. (casual, inviting)
  • Can you give me more details? (friendly, curious)
  • What else should I know? (direct, open)
  • Could you elaborate on that point? (formal, professional)
  • I would appreciate additional details regarding this matter. (formal, polite)

docs.title: 注意事項
docs.text:
• このフレーズ集は一般的なガイドラインです。個々の患者の状況、文化的背景、言語能力に応じて調整してください。
  • 患者の反応を観察し、理解度や感情的な状態に合わせてコミュニケーションスタイルを変えることが重要です。
  • 専門用語を使う場合は、必ず平易な言葉で説明を追加してください。
  • 時間が限られている場合は、最も重要な情報（診断、治療計画、フォローアップ）に焦点を当ててください。

docs.title: トーンの使い分けについて
docs.text:
各フレーズには以下のようなトーン表記が付けられています：

  • casual: カジュアルで親しみやすい。関係が構築された患者や若い患者に適切
  • friendly: 温かく親しみやすいが、プロフェッショナルな距離感を保つ。多くの状況で使いやすい
  • professional: 専門的で信頼感がある。標準的な医療コミュニケーション
  • formal: 丁寧で格式ばった表現。初診、高齢者、または正式な場面に適切
  • polite: 礼儀正しく配慮のある表現。デリケートな話題や不安な患者に適切
  • clinical: 医学的・技術的な表現。専門的な説明や記録に適切
  • empathetic: 共感的で支持的。不安や悩みを抱える患者に適切

推奨事項: - 初診では professional または formal なトーンから始め、患者の反応を見て調整する - 関係が構築されたら、friendly や casual なトーンで親近感を高める - 深刻な診断や手術の説明では、formal と empathetic を組み合わせる - 若い患者には casual から friendly が効果的 - 高齢者や初対面の患者には formal または polite が安全

docs.title: 問診・インターラクションの型（患者との対話）
docs.text: このページは、患者とのインターラクションを「漏れなく・偏りなく・過剰に侵襲的でなく」進めるための問診の型を定義します。重要なのは、情報収集そのものよりも、(1)患者が語る困りごとを正確に定義し、(2)臨床仮説の検証に必要十分な追加質問へ段階的に移り、(3)意思決定の前提（価値観・生活背景・許容リスク）を同定することです。

docs.title: 1. 最初の一文（主訴の同定）
目的
docs.text: 主訴を「痛い」ではなく、機能障害として定義します。主訴が曖昧なまま鑑別に入ると、診断は偶然当たってもプランがぶれます。

docs.title: 型
docs.text:
• いちばん困っていることは何ですか（痛み以外も含む）
  • それが起きるのは、どの動作／どの場面ですか（歩行距離、階段、片脚立位、靴、仕事）
  • そのために、何ができなくなりましたか（具体的に）

docs.title: 2. 受傷／発症の基点と時間軸
docs.text:
• いつからですか（起点）
  • きっかけはありますか（外傷／過負荷／靴変更／運動量変化）
  • どのように変化しましたか（急性→改善／慢性進行／波がある）

docs.title: 3. 仮説駆動の追加質問（過不足を減らす）
目的
docs.text: 鑑別を列挙するのではなく、「どの仮説を否定／支持したいか」に沿って質問します。

docs.title: 典型軸
docs.text:
• 荷重との関係：荷重痛／安静時痛／夜間痛
  • 局在：一点か、広がるか（放散）
  • 腫脹：夕方増悪、圧痕、熱感
  • 神経症状：しびれ、灼熱感、誘発肢位
  • 炎症性徴候：朝のこわばり、対称性、他関節

docs.title: 4. 患者の意思決定前提（価値観と制約）
docs.text:
治療の選択は、解剖学的な正しさだけでなく、患者の価値観と制約の上で成立します。ここを曖昧にすると、説明が「正しいが受け入れられない」形になりやすくなります。

  • 生活上の優先順位（仕事・育児・介護・スポーツ）
  • 受け入れ可能なダウンタイム（免荷期間、通院頻度）
  • 望まない結果（瘢痕、可動域制限、疼痛遷延）
  • 手術への態度（恐怖、過去の経験、情報源）

docs.title: 目的
docs.text: 患者説明は「情報提供」ではなく、治療目標と観察ポイントを共有し、次回分岐（AならB）を患者に理解可能な形で提示することです。

docs.title: 型
docs.text:
• 現時点の見立て：
  • いま一番大事な点：
  • 今日やること：
  • 次回こうだったら（A）→ こうします（B）
  • 逆にこうなら（C）→ こうします（D）

docs.title: 6. 公開運用上の注意
docs.text: この型は一般論であり、個別症例の記載は行いません。症例ベースのメモが必要な場合は、公開外（private/フォルダなど）に分離し、匿名化・規程遵守を前提とします。

docs.title: 7. 実践スクリプト（挨拶から診察終了まで）
docs.text: 以下は、外来での実際の問診の流れを、医師の立場からの会話例として示したものです。患者の反応に応じて柔軟に調整してください。

docs.title: Phase 1: Opening and chief complaint
docs.text:
Physician: Good morning/afternoon, [PATIENT]. Thank you for coming in today. My name is Dr. [NAME], and I'll be taking care of you. Please, have a seat.

Physician: What brings you in today?

(Listen to patient's response)

Physician: I see, you're having pain in your [LOCATION]. Let me ask you a bit more about this. What is the main thing that's bothering you? Is it the pain itself, or is there something you're not able to do because of it?

docs.title: Phase 2: Functional impact
docs.text:
Physician: When does the pain bother you the most? For example, when you're walking, going up or down stairs, first thing in the morning—which activities are most difficult?

Physician: How far can you walk before it becomes a problem? Has that changed compared to before?

Physician: Are there things in your daily life or at work that you've had to stop doing or do differently because of this?

docs.title: Phase 3: Onset and timeline
docs.text:
Physician: When did this start?

Physician: Was there anything that might have triggered it? For example, did you twist your ankle, start a new exercise, change your shoes, or increase your activity level?

Physician: Since it started, has it been getting better, worse, or does it come and go?

docs.title: Phase 4: Hypothesis-driven questions
docs.text:
Physician: Does the pain happen mainly when you're standing or walking, or does it hurt even when you're resting?

Physician: Does it ever wake you up at night?

Physician: Have you noticed any swelling or warmth? Does it change during the day?

Physician: Do you have any numbness or tingling sensations?

docs.title: Phase 5: Prior treatments
docs.text:
Physician: Have you tried any treatments for this?

(Listen to patient's response)

Physician: How long did you try [TREATMENT]? Did it help at all?

docs.title: Phase 6: Patient values and constraints
docs.text:
Physician: What's most important to you right now in your daily life? Is there something you really need to be able to do—for work, family, sports, or hobbies?

Physician: If treatment is needed, how much time off or modified activity would be manageable for you? Are there times that would be particularly difficult, like around work commitments or family responsibilities?

Physician: How do you feel about the possibility of surgery, if it were to come to that? Have you had surgery before?

docs.title: Phase 7: Physical examination transition
docs.text:
Physician: Okay, let me take a look now. I'm going to examine your [LOCATION], check the movement and see where the pain is. Please let me know if anything hurts, okay?

(Perform physical examination)

docs.title: Phase 8: Assessment and plan
docs.text:
Physician: Thank you. Let me explain what I think is going on.

Physician: Based on what you've told me and what I've found on examination, I believe you have [DIAGNOSIS]. Essentially, [BRIEF EXPLANATION].

Physician: Today, I'd like to order [INVESTIGATION] to confirm the diagnosis. We should have the results in about [TIMEFRAME].

Physician: In the meantime, I recommend [CONSERVATIVE TREATMENT: e.g., anti-inflammatory medication, a brace, physiotherapy]. This should help with [PURPOSE].

docs.title: Phase 9: Follow-up and contingency planning
docs.text:
Physician: I'd like to see you back in [TIMEFRAME] to review the results and decide on the next steps together.

Physician: If the test shows [FINDING A], then we'll need to consider [TREATMENT B: e.g., an injection or possibly surgery].

Physician: On the other hand, if [FINDING C], then we can continue with the current treatment and monitor how you're doing.

Physician: Between now and then, if things get suddenly worse, or if you notice [RED FLAG: e.g., increasing numbness, spreading swelling], please don't wait for your appointment—call us right away.

docs.title: Phase 10: Questions and closing
docs.text:
Physician: Do you have any questions? Please feel free to ask about anything, no matter how small.

(Address patient's questions)

Physician: Alright, I'll see you in [TIMEFRAME]. Take care, and I hope you feel better soon.

docs.title: Notes on using this script
docs.text:
• This script is a general framework. Adjust the order, skip sections, or add detail based on the patient's responses and the available time.
  • Creating a comfortable atmosphere is most important. Avoid a rapid-fire interrogation; listen actively and acknowledge the patient's concerns.
  • Use plain language and avoid jargon. Check for understanding.
  • If time is limited, prioritize Phases 1-3 and 7-10, and select from Phases 4-6 as needed.

docs.title: 外来の型（レター中心）
docs.text:
このページは、外来レターを再現可能な型として固定し、上級医へのプレゼンテーション、紹介元への報告、患者説明の整合性を同時に担保することを目的としています。レターは常に、以下の順序で記載します。

  1. Diagnosis
  2. Plan（次回外来のアクションを含む If–Then）
  3. Main paragraph（"It was a pleasure to see …" から開始）
  4. Impression and recommendation

docs.title: 0. 原則
docs.text:
• レターの冒頭は Diagnosis と Planであり、結論を先に提示します（情報の羅列を目的にしません）。
  • Planは必ず「次回何をするか」を含み、可能な限り次回で決着がつく設計に寄せます。
  • レター本文（Main paragraph）は 「読者が前提知識なしに追える」 よう、要点のみを因果順に配置します。

docs.title: 1. レターの型（共通）
docs.text: 以下は、外来レターを最短で作成するための共通骨格です。New referralとFollow-upのいずれでも、まずはこの枠で書き、必要に応じてState別の型（後述）へ寄せます。

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text:
構造: 診断名を簡潔に列挙します。

よく使う単語・フレーズ: - chronic | acute | subacute | recurrent - plantar fasciitis | Achilles tendinopathy | ankle instability | hallux valgus | tibialis posterior tendon dysfunction - stage I / II / III - bilateral | unilateral | left | right - refractory to conservative management - secondary to [CAUSE] - injury occurred [DATE] | sustained [DATE]

例: - [DIAGNOSIS 1] - [DIAGNOSIS 2]（必要に応じて）

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
構造: 検査、保存療法、次回予定、分岐（If-Then）を明示します。

よく使う単語・フレーズ:

Investigation: - X-ray | MRI | CT | ultrasound | weightbearing CT - to assess | to evaluate | to confirm | to rule out - bone stock | cartilage integrity | ligament injury | alignment

Conservative management: - physiotherapy | orthotics | heel cups | night splints | CAM boot - NSAIDs | analgesia | injection (corticosteroid / PRP) - activity modification | offloading | stretching program - for [DURATION: 3 months / 6 weeks / until next review]

Follow-up: - in [TIMEFRAME: 3 months / 6 weeks / after investigations complete] - to review symptoms | to assess progress | to discuss next steps

If-Then branching: - If symptoms persist → consider [injection / surgery / further imaging] - If improvement → continue conservative | wean from support | return PRN - If deterioration → urgent review | modify treatment

例: - 検査：[INVESTIGATION]（目的：仮説の支持／否定） - 保存： [CONSERVATIVE]（期限：[DURATION]） - 次回： [TIMEFRAME] に再診し結果レビュー - If A（例：症状残存／所見陽性／画像で○○）→ Then B（追加検査／注射／手術検討） - If C（例：改善傾向）→ Then D（負荷調整／リハ継続／PRN）

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text:
構造: 挨拶→主訴（機能障害として）→発症と経過→既治療→身体所見→検査

よく使う単語・フレーズ:

Opening: - It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] - Thank you for referring [PATIENT] - [PATIENT] returns today for review

Chief complaint (functional): - reports difficulty with | is unable to | experiences pain when - walking distance limited to [DISTANCE] - stairs are difficult | cannot stand for prolonged periods

Onset: - began [TIMEFRAME] ago | following [INJURY / ACTIVITY] - insidious onset | traumatic onset | gradual progression

Course: - progressive | stable | intermittent | improving | worsening - exacerbated by | relieved by

Prior management: - has tried | has undergone | has completed - physiotherapy | orthotics | injections | NSAIDs | immobilization - with good / partial / minimal / no relief

Examination: - On examination | Inspection reveals | Palpation demonstrates - tenderness over | swelling is present | range of motion is limited - neurovascularly intact | alignment is neutral / varus / valgus - [TEST NAME] is positive / negative

Investigations: - Radiographs demonstrate | MRI shows | CT reveals - joint space narrowing | osteophytes | subchondral sclerosis - tendon tear | cartilage defect | bone marrow edema

例:

It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for review of [REGION/COMPLAINT]. [PATIENT] reports [CHIEF COMPLAINT AS FUNCTION], which began [ONSET/INJURY BASIS] and has followed [TIME COURSE]. Prior management has included [TREATMENTS TRIED], with [RESPONSE]. On examination, [KEY EXAM FINDINGS]. Investigations [IMAGING/TESTS REVIEWED OR REQUESTED].

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text:
構造: 診断のまとめ→鑑別診断→推奨事項→次回予定

よく使う単語・フレーズ:

Summary: - In summary | Overall | In conclusion - the presentation is consistent with | most likely represents - diagnostic features include

Differential: - The key differential diagnoses include - Other considerations are - We have ruled out | We need to exclude

Recommendation: - I recommend | The plan is to | We will proceed with - conservative management | surgical intervention | further investigation - with close monitoring | as tolerated | until symptoms resolve

Follow-up goal: - to reassess | to review progress | to finalize the plan - to discuss surgical options | to ensure adequate healing

例:

In summary, [PATIENT]'s presentation is consistent with [IMPRESSION]. The key differential diagnoses include [DIFFERENTIALS]. I recommend [RECOMMENDATION], and I will review [PATIENT] in [FOLLOW-UP TIMEFRAME] to [GOAL OF REVIEW].

docs.title: 2. State別の型（最小差分）
docs.text: 先生の運用フロー（New referral → Conservative / Consider surgery → Follow-up）を、上記4枠の中で破綻なく回すため、Stateごとの“差分”のみを示す。

docs.title: 2-1. New referral（Diagnostic testing and follow up）
docs.text:
• Diagnosis: Working diagnosis（暫定）＋ Differential（上位）
  • Plan: 検査依頼（目的明記）＋「検査完了後に再診」＋待機期間中の保存療法（期限つき；= Temporarily）
  • Impression and recommendation: "暫定"であることを明示し、結果で分岐することを文章で固定する

具体例（Sample 1 より）:

Diagnosis - Chronic bilateral plantar fasciitis (L>R), refractory to standard conservative management - Differential diagnosis for medial heel pain includes Baxter's nerve entrapment

Plan - Follow up in my clinic after investigations are complete (approx. [~4 months]). - Advised to continue physiotherapy, shockwave therapy, heel cups, and night splints for [~4 months] while awaiting investigations. - Investigations: [INVESTIGATIONS] (purpose: confirm plantar fascia pathology; assess for alternative causes of medial heel pain)

Impression and recommendation（結語） I recommend completion of the requested investigations and continuation of the above conservative measures while awaiting results. I will review [PATIENT] after investigations are complete to finalise management based on findings and clinical response.

docs.title: 2-2. New referral（Conservative）
docs.text:
• Diagnosis: 確定診断＋重症度／ステージ
  • Plan: 保存療法を期限つきで提示し、成功／不成功の評価軸を If–Then に落とす

具体例（Sample 14 より）:

Diagnosis - Insertional Achilles tendinopathy with calcaneal spur / insertional swelling

Plan - Continue non-operative management (footwear modification, activity modification, physiotherapy as appropriate) - Review in [~6 months] - If symptoms significantly deteriorate → revisit operative options; coordinate perioperative medication management with treating teams

Impression and recommendation（結語） Given the current symptom severity and elevated perioperative considerations, I recommend continued non-operative management and review in [~6 months], with earlier review if symptoms worsen.

docs.title: 2-3. New referral（Consider surgery）
docs.text:
• Diagnosis: 確定診断
  • Plan: IC（risk/benefit + recovery）を箇条書きで明示し、患者が"考える期間"と次アクション（連絡して日程調整）を固定する

具体例（Sample 3 より）:

Diagnosis - Right ankle lateral ligament and anteromedial ligament complex laxity

Plan - Plan: Right ankle arthroscopy and lateral and medial ligament stabilisation - IC (risk and benefit): - Benefits: improved stability, symptom reduction, functional improvement - Risks: nerve injury, infection, stiffness, recurrent instability, DVT/PE, anaesthetic risks - Natural history: untreated instability increases risk of recurrent episodes and may increase risk of cartilage damage and long-term arthritis - Postoperative recovery: - [~6 weeks] weight-bearing in a CAM boot, then commence physiotherapy - Expected recovery [~3–6 months] (variable)

Impression and recommendation（結語） I believe [PATIENT] would benefit from ankle arthroscopy and lateral and medial ligament stabilisation. I have discussed the procedure and the specific risks, including nerve injury and recurrent instability, as well as the expected recovery pathway. We will proceed with organising surgery and postoperative rehabilitation as outlined.

docs.title: 2-4. Follow-up（Post conservative）
docs.text:
• Diagnosis: 既診断＋経過（改善／不変／増悪のいずれか）
  • Plan:
  • Success → PRN（フォロー終了条件を明示）
  • Failure → Consider surgery（必要なら検査追加→IC）

具体例（Sample 2 より）:

Diagnosis - Chronic right ankle instability and pain, secondary to inversion injuries in [MONTH YEAR] and [MONTH YEAR] - Secondary hindfoot varus and lateral ankle pain due to altered gait

Plan（Failure → Consider surgery の分岐を含む） - Conservative management with orthotics (including carbon shank) has been trialled - Continue home exercise program, focusing on proprioception and strengthening - If symptoms persist / significantly impact quality of life: - Consider 1st MTP joint fusion (non-weight bearing for [~6 weeks], total recovery up to [~1 year]) - If symptoms of pinching become frequent, consider ankle arthroscopy to debride scar tissue - Review: - [PATIENT] will contact the office to schedule surgery if they decide to proceed - If symptoms worsen or fail to improve by [MONTH YEAR], return for review

Impression and recommendation（結語） While many patients improve with structured physiotherapy, [PATIENT] remains at higher risk of requiring surgery if instability and symptoms persist. I recommend a dedicated period of structured physiotherapy focused on proprioception and strength, with gradual functional re-introduction. I will review [PATIENT] again in [~3–4 months] to assess progress and determine whether further intervention is warranted.

docs.title: 2-5. Follow-up（Post op）
docs.text:
• Diagnosis: 術式＋術後週数
  • Plan: 荷重・固定・リハ・画像フォロー・次回受診を、術後プロトコルとして固定する

具体例 A：Acute phase（Sample 4 より / TAR 3 weeks）:

Diagnosis - [~3 weeks] post right total ankle replacement, performed [DATE]

Plan - Wound care: remove anterior wound sutures today; continue local wound care - Rehabilitation: commence/continue active range of motion exercises - Weight-bearing: remain non-weight-bearing until [~6 weeks] - Imaging: review at [~6 weeks] with X-ray; consider progression to WBAT in boot depending on radiographic and clinical status

Impression and recommendation（結語） [PATIENT] is progressing appropriately in the acute post-operative phase. I recommend continuing non-weight-bearing and range of motion exercises as outlined. I will review [PATIENT] at the [~6-week] mark with X-rays to determine readiness for progression to weight-bearing in a boot.

具体例 B：Sub-acute phase（Sample 9 より / TKR 6 weeks）:

Diagnosis - [~6 weeks] post left total knee replacement, performed [DATE]

Plan - Continue range of motion and strengthening program - Return to driving: permitted from [~6 weeks] post-op if safe and functional - Follow-up: review in [~2–3 months]

Impression and recommendation（結語） [PATIENT] has satisfactory clinical and radiographic progress at [~6 weeks] post TKR. I recommend ongoing range of motion work and will review [PATIENT] again in a few months.

docs.title: 3. 次回アクション設計（AならB、CならD）
docs.text:
次回分岐は「都度考える」から「事前に定義する」へ移すことで、診療の一貫性と学習効率が上がる。典型的な分岐は以下である。

  • 症状: 改善／不変／増悪
  • 身体所見: 誘発テスト陽性の持続／消失
  • 画像: 追加撮像の要否（仮説検証のための追加）
  • 治療反応: 固定・薬物・注射・リハへの反応

docs.title: 4. 実装メモ（運用上の注意）
docs.text:
• 公開ノートでは、患者名は常に [PATIENT] とし、日時・施設・地域・職業などもプレースホルダで表現する。実症例の全文は公開外（private/ 等）へ分離する。
  • “上級医に相談するための情報”と“患者説明に必要な情報”は重なるが同一ではない。前者は仮説と分岐設計、後者は期待値調整（治療期間と見通し）に重心がある。

docs.title: 5. サンプルレター（完全匿名化）
docs.text: 以下は、先生が提示されたレター断片を、患者名を[PATIENT]へ置換し、日時・職業・施設などの症例同定性をプレースホルダ化した上で、固定順序（Diagnosis → Plan → Main paragraph → Impression and recommendation）に再構成したサンプルである。

docs.title: Sample 1（New referral：Diagnostic testing and follow up）
Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Chronic bilateral plantar fasciitis (L>R), refractory to standard conservative management
  • Differential diagnosis for medial heel pain includes Baxter’s nerve entrapment
  • Palpable dorsal left foot mass consistent with a ganglion cyst ０

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Follow up in my clinic after investigations are complete (approx. [~4 months]).
  • Advised to continue physiotherapy, shockwave therapy, heel cups, and night splints for [~4 months] while awaiting investigations.
  • Investigations: [INVESTIGATIONS] (purpose: confirm plantar fascia pathology; assess for alternative causes of medial heel pain; characterise dorsal mass if required)

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for assessment of bilateral foot pain. [PATIENT] presents with a [2–3 year] history of bilateral foot pain, worse on the left. The pain is most severe with the first steps in the morning and after periods of rest. Symptoms have been refractory to conservative treatments, including physiotherapy exercises, hot and cold compresses, [two] steroid injections (providing only brief relief), shockwave therapy, and night splints. On examination, there is a palpable, soft, cystic-feeling mass on the dorsal aspect of the left foot, consistent with a ganglion cyst.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT]’s presentation is consistent with chronic bilateral plantar fasciitis, more severe on the left, refractory to standard conservative management. The differential diagnosis for the medial heel pain includes Baxter’s nerve entrapment. I recommend completion of the requested investigations and continuation of the above conservative measures while awaiting results. I will review [PATIENT] after investigations are complete (approximately [~4 months]) to finalise management based on findings and clinical response.

docs.title: Sample 2（Follow-up：Post conservative / Failure → Consider surgery を含む）
Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Chronic right ankle instability and pain, secondary to inversion injuries in [MONTH YEAR] and [MONTH YEAR]
  • Secondary hindfoot varus and lateral ankle pain due to altered gait
  • Left ankle lateral ligament injury, approximately [~9 months] post injury (injury sustained on [DATE])
  • Right 1st MTP joint arthritis with hallux rigidus and associated bony prominence

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Conservative management with orthotics (including carbon shank) has been trialled
  • Continue symptomatic relief with paracetamol as needed
  • Continue home exercise program, focusing on proprioception and strengthening with ankle bands
  • Slow weaning from the boot in a controlled manner under physiotherapy guidance
  • Gradually return to higher-impact activities (running/jumping), starting on even, controlled surfaces
  • Cease smoking / nicotine use to improve tissue healing potential
  • Surgery (if symptoms significantly impact quality of life):
  • Consider 1st MTP joint fusion (non-weight bearing for [~6 weeks], total recovery up to [~1 year])
  • If symptoms of pinching become frequent or limit activity, consider ankle arthroscopy to debride scar tissue
  • Review:
  • [PATIENT] will contact the office to schedule surgery if they decide to proceed
  • If symptoms worsen or fail to improve by [MONTH YEAR], return for review
  • Review in [X months] to assess progress

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] for review regarding ankle and forefoot symptoms. [PATIENT] reports a history of inversion injuries affecting the ankles (including a significant inversion injury at work on [DATE] and a further inversion injury on [DATE]), with ongoing functional limitation. Prior management has included immobilisation in a boot and physiotherapy with mixed results. Currently, [PATIENT] describes episodic lateral ankle pain when overactive (e.g., running or jumping), with perceived instability and occasional rolling episodes. [PATIENT] also reports forefoot symptoms consistent with hallux rigidus, including hypersensitivity and activity limitation. There are [no / some] associated neuropathic symptoms, such as tingling or numbness over the dorsolateral foot, particularly at night, which may disturb sleep. On examination, gait is [antalgic / normal]. There is tenderness over the anterolateral ankle (including along the course of the superficial peroneal nerve) and lateral ligament complex. Stress testing demonstrates laxity with anterior drawer and talar tilt compared with the contralateral side. Range of motion is limited by pain. Investigations reviewed include [X-rays / MRI] demonstrating [ligament injury / preserved cartilage space / no obvious fracture / incidental Haglund’s deformity].

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] remains symptomatic with chronic ankle instability with a mixed picture of soft tissue pain/nerve irritation and deconditioning-related perceived instability. While many patients improve with structured physiotherapy, [PATIENT] remains at higher risk of requiring surgery if instability and symptoms persist. I recommend a dedicated period of structured physiotherapy focused on proprioception and strength, with gradual functional re-introduction, and cessation of nicotine to optimise tissue healing. I will review [PATIENT] again in [~3–4 months] with weight-bearing X-rays (and/or other investigations as indicated) to assess progress and determine whether further intervention (including arthroscopy and/or ligament reconstruction) is warranted.

docs.title: Sample 3（New referral：Consider surgery / IC を前面化）
Diagnosis
docs.text: • Right ankle lateral ligament and anteromedial ligament complex laxity

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Plan: Right ankle arthroscopy and lateral and medial ligament stabilisation
  • IC (risk and benefit):
  • Benefits: improved stability, symptom reduction, functional improvement
  • Risks: nerve injury (including superficial peroneal nerve proximity; temporary neuropraxia possible; permanent sensory change possible), infection, stiffness, recurrent instability, DVT/PE, anaesthetic risks
  • Natural history: untreated instability increases risk of recurrent episodes and may increase risk of cartilage damage and long-term arthritis
  • Postoperative recovery:
  • [~6 weeks] weight-bearing in a CAM boot, then commence physiotherapy
  • Expected recovery [~3–6 months] (variable)

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] for review of persistent ankle symptoms. [PATIENT] reports ankle pain and instability, including morning pain and functional limitation, and wishes to proceed with operative management after consideration of timing and goals. On examination, foot and ankle alignment is [normal] with full range of motion of the ankle and subtalar joint. There is severe lateral ligament laxity and anteromedial laxity, with the ability to partially sublux the talus anteriorly on the tibial mortise. Investigations: ankle MRI reviewed, demonstrating a severely attenuated and lax ATFL and CFL. The deltoid ligament is intact but lax. Cartilage is intact.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] has clinically and radiologically significant ligamentous laxity consistent with mechanical instability. I believe [PATIENT] would benefit from ankle arthroscopy and lateral and medial ligament stabilisation. I have discussed the procedure and the specific risks, including nerve injury and recurrent instability, as well as the expected recovery pathway. We will proceed with organising surgery and postoperative rehabilitation as outlined.

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text:
• [~8 weeks] post left total ankle replacement and gastrocnemius/Achilles lengthening, performed [DATE]
  • Neuropathic pain symptoms, likely related to the tibial nerve (working diagnosis)

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Weight-bearing: commence WBAT in boot; remove boot for sleep and exercises
  • Boot weaning: stop boot altogether in [~4 weeks] if progressing
  • Imaging: weight-bearing X-ray of the left ankle today; repeat X-rays in [~6 weeks]
  • Follow-up: review in [~6 weeks] to reassess symptoms, neurogenic pain, and radiographic progression

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for review of a left ankle replacement, [~8 weeks] post-operatively. [PATIENT] reports the ankle feels “pretty good” overall, with minimal mechanical ankle pain, but describes neuropathic pain characterised by shooting pain into the great toe and dysaesthetic sensations (including coldness and nocturnal symptoms). On examination, the left foot shows mild colour difference compared to the contralateral side, with a small residual scab at the anterior wound. Range of motion is good ([~10° dorsiflexion / ~40° plantarflexion]), hindfoot alignment is neutral, swelling is controlled, and there is no focal tenderness around the ankle. Investigations: weight-bearing X-rays demonstrate satisfactory alignment and evidence of bone ingrowth onto components.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] shows satisfactory mechanical recovery at [~8 weeks] post total ankle replacement. The primary issue is neuropathic pain symptoms, likely tibial nerve related. I recommend progressing to WBAT in a boot with planned weaning, ongoing exercises, and radiographic follow-up. I will review [PATIENT] in [~6 weeks] with repeat X-rays to reassess both symptoms and implant integration.

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text:
• [~8 years] post right total ankle replacement, performed [DATE], stable
  • Residual hindfoot varus
  • Right lateral forefoot discomfort likely footwear-related / varus moment exacerbation

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text: • [~3 weeks] post right total ankle replacement, performed [DATE]

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Wound care: remove anterior wound sutures today; continue local wound care
  • Rehabilitation: commence/continue active range of motion exercises
  • Weight-bearing: remain non-weight-bearing until [~6 weeks]
  • Imaging: review at [~6 weeks] with X-ray; consider progression to WBAT in boot depending on radiographic and clinical status

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for a post-operative review, [~3 weeks] following a right total ankle replacement. The anterior wound sutures were removed today and the wound is satisfactory. [PATIENT] is performing active range of motion exercises. There are no red flags reported.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] is progressing appropriately in the acute post-operative phase. I recommend continuing non-weight-bearing and range of motion exercises as outlined. I will review [PATIENT] at the [~6-week] mark with X-rays to determine readiness for progression to weight-bearing in a boot. - Continue conservative management (footwear modification, orthoses as required) - Imaging: repeat X-ray in [~12 months] - Review: earlier review if pain worsens, swelling develops, or functional decline occurs

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for review of the right ankle, [~8 years] following a total ankle replacement. [PATIENT] reports right lateral forefoot discomfort aggravated by walking, which appears temporally related to new shoes that push the foot into varus; the insoles have been modified. On examination, [PATIENT] has good ankle range of motion ([~20° dorsiflexion / ~35° plantarflexion]), no ankle tenderness or swelling, and mild hindfoot varus. Imaging: X-rays show a fixed-bearing ankle prosthesis in situ without subsidence. A mild halo around the tibial component is unchanged compared with prior imaging and is asymptomatic.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT]’s ankle replacement remains stable long term. The forefoot discomfort is most consistent with footwear-related exacerbation of a pre-existing hindfoot varus. I recommend continued conservative management and annual radiographic surveillance.

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Left knee medial compartment osteoarthritis (bone-on-bone)
  • Background: prior right total ankle replacement and left flatfoot reconstruction (historical)

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Plan: left total knee replacement
  • Preoperative work-up: [pre-op imaging / templating / medical clearance]
  • IC (risk and benefit):
  • Benefits: pain relief and improved mobility
  • Risks: infection, vascular injury, numbness, stiffness, pain, incomplete pain relief
  • Expectations: recovery milestones (e.g., [~6 weeks], [~3 months], [~6 months], [~12 months])
  • Next steps: provide consent form; organise [imaging]; schedule surgery after [DATE]; arrange rehabilitation plan [LOCATION/HOSPITAL]

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] for review. [PATIENT] has a background history of a right total ankle replacement and left flatfoot reconstruction and now presents with worsening left knee pain affecting gait and function. On examination, gait is antalgic. Knee range of motion is [~0–100°] with mild varus alignment. Investigations: X-rays demonstrate bone-on-bone medial compartment osteoarthritis of the left knee.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] has symptomatic end-stage medial compartment osteoarthritis of the left knee. I recommend a left total knee replacement and have discussed the procedure, risks, and expected recovery. We will proceed with preoperative planning and scheduling as outlined.

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text: • [~2 weeks] post left total knee replacement, performed [DATE]

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Continue rehabilitation program; analgesia optimisation as needed
  • Imaging: knee X-ray at next review [~4 weeks]
  • Follow-up: review in [~4 weeks]
  • Safety net: urgent review if fever, increasing redness/drainage, calf pain/swelling, escalating pain, or functional decline

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] for review following a recent left total knee replacement, [~2 weeks] post-operatively. [PATIENT] reports ongoing pain and is currently in rehabilitation, with concern that pain feels worse than the contralateral side did at a similar stage. On examination, the wound is healing well with good alignment. Range of motion is improving with almost full extension and [~100°] flexion. There are no clinical signs of infection or other red flags. Postoperative X-rays obtained soon after surgery were satisfactory.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] is progressing appropriately at [~2 weeks] post TKR without evidence of infection. I recommend continuing rehabilitation and will review [PATIENT] in [~4 weeks] with a knee X-ray to assess ongoing progress.

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text:
• [~6 weeks] post left total knee replacement, performed [DATE]
  • History of postoperative cellulitis, resolved (historical)

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Continue range of motion and strengthening program
  • Return to driving: permitted from [~6 weeks] post-op if safe and functional
  • Follow-up: review in [~2–3 months]

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for review. [PATIENT] underwent a left total knee replacement [~6 weeks] ago. [PATIENT] has been walking well and is able to walk long distances, noting mild stiffness after prolonged sitting that improves with movement. On examination, gait is normal. The knee extends fully with good quadriceps tone. There is no effusion and the surgical incision is well healed. Investigations: postoperative X-rays demonstrate satisfactory bone–prosthesis interface with good integration.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] has satisfactory clinical and radiographic progress at [~6 weeks] post TKR. I recommend ongoing range of motion work and will review [PATIENT] again in a few months.

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Right hip osteoarthritis (symptomatic, function-limiting)
  • Past surgical history: left total hip replacement [YEAR] (stable)
  • Possible obstructive sleep apnoea / CPAP pending (medical background)

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Plan: right total hip replacement
  • Further imaging: preoperative templating to assess component sizing and leg length/offset
  • IC (risk and benefit):
  • Benefits: pain relief, improved function
  • Risks: nerve injury, leg length discrepancy, dislocation, fracture, subsidence/revision, thromboembolism (DVT/PE), infection, medical complications
  • Medical workup: [cardiology / general medical clearance]; request relevant correspondence as indicated
  • Postoperative pathway: early mobilisation; typically full weight-bearing; physiotherapy plan [home program / fund]

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to meet [PATIENT] today. [PATIENT] previously underwent a left total hip replacement in [YEAR], which has remained successful and asymptomatic. [PATIENT] now presents with right hip pain predominantly in the groin, aggravated by turning and activity, with functional limitation sufficient to consider surgery. On examination, [PATIENT] demonstrates a limp with walking. Hip examination is consistent with established osteoarthritis, with irritability and restricted movement. Investigations: X-rays confirm right hip osteoarthritis; further imaging is required for templating.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] has symptomatic right hip osteoarthritis with significant impact on mobility and quality of life. I recommend proceeding with right total hip replacement after completion of preoperative templating and medical clearance, and I have discussed surgical risks, benefits, and recovery expectations.

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text: • [~2 weeks] post right total hip replacement, performed [DATE]

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Wound check: wound healed; continue standard wound care
  • DVT assessment: [doppler] negative (if performed)
  • Imaging: review at [~6 weeks] with X-ray
  • Follow-up: [~6 weeks] post-op review

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] for a post-operative wound check, [~2 weeks] following a right total hip replacement. [PATIENT] is doing well and is being discharged home from rehabilitation today. The wound has healed well. A Doppler study was negative for DVT.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] is recovering well in the acute post-operative period following right THR. I recommend continuing the standard postoperative pathway and will review [PATIENT] at [~6 weeks] with an X-ray.

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Bilateral knee osteochondral lesions / osteoarthritis (side-specific as per imaging)
  • Varus malalignment (left) and valgus alignment (right)
  • Avascular necrosis of femoral condyles (bilateral)
  • Significant medical comorbidity (e.g., immunosuppression, transplant, anticoagulation) [as applicable]

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Imaging:
  • Weight-bearing CT scan [region] (bilateral)
  • Standing EOS scan
  • Supine fine-cut CT for 3D modelling
  • Updated MRI scans (bilateral knees)
  • 3D modelling review with [TEAM/SURGEON]
  • Discuss staged surgical options as indicated (e.g., high tibial osteotomy left; distal femoral osteotomy right)
  • Follow-up: review imaging results and finalise management plan in complex clinic
  • Risk management: surgical caution given medical background; balance disease progression and infection/thrombotic risk

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today in the complex clinic for assessment of progressive knee pain and functional limitation. [PATIENT] has a significant medical background including [immunosuppression / transplant / anticoagulation]. Symptoms are activity-related, with the left knee typically the clinical priority. On examination, gait is antalgic. The left knee shows reduced range of motion ([~5–115°]) with patellofemoral crepitus and medial pseudolaxity consistent with medial compartment disease. The right knee demonstrates valgus alignment with functional limitation. Investigations reviewed include prior MRI/CT findings consistent with osteochondral disease and compartment-specific osteoarthritis, and updated imaging is requested for comprehensive alignment and 3D planning.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] has multi-factorial bilateral knee pathology with malalignment and progressive arthritic change. I recommend a structured imaging workup and 3D modelling review to determine the most appropriate staged intervention, balancing potential benefit with elevated perioperative risk.

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Leg length discrepancy
  • Right hip excision arthroplasty (Girdlestone appearance) secondary to prior infected THR and femoral osteomyelitis (historical)
  • Left leg radicular pain, likely secondary to lumbar spondylosis (working diagnosis)

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Referral: [NEUROSURGEON/PAIN SPECIALIST] for assessment of back pain and radiculopathy
  • Imaging: plain X-ray and CT scan of the lumbar spine
  • Report: to GP and copied to [PATIENT], supporting funding for:
  • Home modifications
  • Mobility assistance devices
  • Occupational therapy input
  • Safety net: review if neurological deficit progresses, pain escalates, or functional capacity declines

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today to assist with an application for functional support and home modifications. [PATIENT] ambulated with [two crutches] and reports significant mobility limitation and pain. [PATIENT] has a complex surgical history including a right total hip replacement complicated by infection requiring multiple surgeries, followed by right hip excision arthroplasty and subsequent femoral osteomyelitis, now resolved. [PATIENT] has not required further hip surgery since [YEAR]. On examination, [PATIENT] demonstrates a positive Trendelenburg gait, significant right leg shortening, and instability. Hip examination is consistent with an excision arthroplasty state. The left hip and knee demonstrate preserved range of motion without focal pain. Straight leg raise is [positive/negative] for radicular symptoms. Investigations: plain X-rays demonstrate a Girdlestone appearance of the right hip and lumbar spondylosis.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] has major ongoing functional impairment and pain related to the sequelae of multiple right hip operations and chronic leg length discrepancy, compounded by probable lumbar radiculopathy. Further reconstructive hip surgery is not practically available given complexity and high risk. I recommend specialist assessment of spinal symptoms and lumbar imaging as outlined. I will provide a report to the GP (copied to [PATIENT]) documenting the functional limitations and supporting funding for home modifications, mobility assistance, and occupational therapy.

docs.title: Sample 14（New referral：Insertional Achilles tendinopathy / decision against surgery for now）
Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Insertional Achilles tendinopathy with calcaneal spur / insertional swelling
  • Rheumatologic background on immunomodulatory therapy [as applicable]

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Continue non-operative management (footwear modification, activity modification, physiotherapy as appropriate)
  • Review in [~6 months]
  • If symptoms significantly deteriorate, revisit operative options; coordinate perioperative medication management [DMARD/antiplatelet] with treating teams

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for assessment of right heel pain. [PATIENT] has a background history of multiple orthopaedic procedures and inflammatory arthritis managed with [medications], currently well controlled. Over the last [~12 months], the right Achilles insertion has become increasingly symptomatic, though not yet severely restrictive, and [PATIENT] has partially improved with footwear modification. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness at the Achilles insertion. Investigations: X-rays demonstrate a calcaneal spur with associated soft tissue swelling.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT]’s presentation is consistent with insertional Achilles tendinopathy. Given the current symptom severity and elevated perioperative considerations, I recommend continued non-operative management and review in [~6 months], with earlier review if symptoms worsen.

docs.title: Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Left Achilles tendon rupture, sustained [DATE] (delayed diagnosis)
  • Left talar bone bruising (likely impingement related to injury mechanism)
  • Relevant comorbidity increasing infection risk [as applicable]

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Plan: left Achilles tendon percutaneous repair on [DATE]
  • Physiotherapy referral: pre-op training for non-weight-bearing strategies and post-op rehabilitation
  • Postoperative pathway: [~6 weeks] non-weight-bearing in a CAM boot
  • IC (risk and benefit): infection, DVT/PE, nerve injury, wound complications, re-rupture, need for further surgery
  • Work planning: arrange [~6 weeks] off work post-operatively

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for assessment of left ankle pain following an injury [~3 months] ago involving hyperdorsiflexion. [PATIENT] reports posterior ankle pain radiating into the calf, worse with walking and improved with rest, with incomplete improvement despite use of a CAM boot. On examination, there is a positive Thompson test and a palpable defect in the Achilles tendon. Investigations: MRI demonstrates a complete rupture of the Achilles tendon and increased signal in the talar neck consistent with bone bruising.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] has a complete Achilles tendon rupture with delayed diagnosis and associated talar bone bruising. I recommend percutaneous repair as outlined, with appropriate thromboprophylaxis and rehabilitation planning. We will proceed with surgery scheduling and physiotherapy coordination.

docs.title: Sample 16（New referral：Hallux valgus + crossover/hammer toe / plan surgery）
Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Right hallux valgus
  • Right second hammer toe with MTP dislocation / crossover deformity
  • Midfoot arthritis [if present]

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Plan: percutaneous correction of hallux valgus + correction of second toe position
  • Alternatives: non-operative care; in selected cases, second toe amputation discussed [context-dependent]
  • IC (risk and benefit): infection, DVT/PE, nerve injury/neuroma, non-union, fracture, incomplete correction, need for hardware removal, anaesthetic risks
  • Recovery: post-op shoe or boot; adherence to post-op instructions for optimal healing
  • Next steps: provide consent forms; schedule surgery at [HOSPITAL/CLINIC] depending on availability and patient preference

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for an initial consult regarding bunion symptoms and difficulty with footwear. [PATIENT] reports progressive pain and functional limitation, including nocturnal neuropathic-type discomfort and difficulty finding comfortable shoes. On examination, there is severe hallux valgus with a palpable medial bony prominence at the 1st MTP joint. The second toe is dislocated with fixed deformity and tight surrounding soft tissues. Distal neurovascular status is grossly intact. Investigations: X-rays demonstrate hallux valgus deformity with second MTP dislocation and midfoot arthritic changes.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] has a complex forefoot deformity consistent with hallux valgus and second toe dislocation, correlating with symptoms and shoe-wear difficulty. I recommend operative correction as outlined and have discussed realistic goals, risks, and recovery. [PATIENT] will consider scheduling options and advise the clinic of their decision.

docs.title: Sample 17（Post op：Acute / forefoot deformity correction 2 weeks）
Diagnosis
docs.text: • [~2 weeks] post bilateral hallux valgus and crossover/second toe correction, performed [DATE]

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Wound care: sutures removed today; continue swelling control
  • Weight-bearing: WBAT with post-op shoe/boot as directed; progress to normal footwear in [~4 weeks] if appropriate
  • Imaging: repeat X-ray at [~4 weeks]
  • Follow-up: review in [~4 weeks]

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for review [~2 weeks] after bilateral hallux valgus and crossover second toe correction. [PATIENT] reports minimal pain and no neurological complications. Wounds have healed nicely and sutures were removed. Swelling is well controlled and overall foot and toe positioning is satisfactory.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] is progressing well in the early postoperative phase. I recommend continuing swelling control and protected weight-bearing as outlined, with repeat X-rays and review in [~4 weeks] to guide progression to normal footwear.

docs.title: Sample 18（New referral：Forefoot-driven varus + gouty tophus / imaging-based planning）
Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Gouty tophus around the 1st MTP joint region (working diagnosis based on exam/imaging)
