  • Forefoot-driven varus deformity with plantarflexion of first/second rays contributing to varus moment on weight-bearing
  • Bilateral fourth curly toes secondary to FDL tightness

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Imaging: updated weight-bearing X-rays, weight-bearing CT, and MRI as indicated
  • Medical: continue gout management [medication] with coordination [GP/Rheumatology]
  • Consider procedures depending on imaging and symptoms:
  • FDL release to fourth toe
  • Extension osteotomy of first/second rays to address forefoot pronation/plantarflexion component
  • Follow-up: review once imaging is complete to finalise operative vs non-operative strategy and provide a quote if required

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for review of forefoot symptoms and deformity. [PATIENT] reports a history of intermittent gout and progressive functional difficulty. On examination, there is a large soft tissue swelling under the first metatarsal region consistent with gouty tophus, along with a forefoot-driven varus deformity and bilateral fourth curly toes. There is relative plantarflexion of the first and second rays contributing to a varus moment on weight-bearing. Investigations: prior plain X-rays showed erosive changes consistent with gout; updated imaging is requested to delineate current anatomy and guide management.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT] has a combined medical (gouty tophus) and mechanical (forefoot-driven varus) problem contributing to symptoms. I recommend updated imaging and a structured review to determine the most appropriate staged intervention, including possible tendon release and osteotomy if indicated.

docs.title: Sample 19（Follow-up：Post op / sinus tarsi impingement concern）
Diagnosis
docs.text:
• [~6 weeks] post-operative right lateral process of talus osteotomy
  • Persistent peroneal spasm (pain-related)
  • Concern for recurrent sinus tarsi impingement (working diagnosis)
  • Background: possible tarsal coalition [if applicable]

docs.title: Plan
docs.text:
• Imaging: request weight-bearing CT scan of right foot and ankle to assess for recurrent sinus tarsi impingement and delineate anatomy
  • Symptom management: supportive footwear; avoid high-impact activities
  • Infection control (if scar inflammation): prescribe oral antibiotics [if indicated]
  • Follow-up: review in [~2 weeks] to discuss CT results and formulate further management
  • Contingency: consider arthroscopic debridement if recurrent impingement confirmed and symptoms persist; reserve subtalar fusion as salvage procedure

docs.title: Main paragraph
docs.text: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] for review [~6 weeks] following a right lateral process of talus osteotomy. [PATIENT] reports the ankle is sore after work. On examination, gait is normal. There is mild ongoing inflammation along the lateral ankle scar. Ankle range of motion is symmetrical. There is spasm of the peroneal tendons. Investigations: a weight-bearing CT scan has been requested to assess for recurrent sinus tarsi impingement.

docs.title: Impression and recommendation
docs.text: In summary, [PATIENT]’s persistent peroneal spasm is most likely pain-mediated, with concern for recurrent sinus tarsi impingement. I recommend weight-bearing CT assessment and close follow-up. Further intervention will be guided by CT findings and clinical course, with arthroscopic debridement considered if indicated and subtalar fusion reserved as salvage.

docs.title: Outpatient Phrasebook (English-only)
docs.text: This page collects useful English phrases for outpatient orthopaedic notes and referral letters. The goal is to build a personal phrasebook that you can draw on repeatedly, helping you write clear, professional letters more efficiently. Placeholders like [PATIENT], [SIDE], [DIAGNOSIS], [DURATION], [IMAGING], and [FOLLOW-UP] can be replaced with specific details. Remember to avoid including any identifying information when sharing examples.

docs.title: Time and course
docs.text:
• acute / subacute / chronic
  • intermittent / persistent
  • progressive / stable
  • atraumatic onset / following an injury
  • recurrent / episodic

docs.title: Symptom vocabulary
docs.text:
• pain, tenderness, swelling, stiffness
  • instability, giving way
  • numbness, tingling, weakness
  • catching, locking
  • limp, reduced walking tolerance

docs.title: Examination vocabulary
docs.text:
• inspection / palpation / range of motion
  • alignment / deformity
  • neurovascularly intact
  • tenderness over [STRUCTURE]
  • pain at end range
  • provocative test

docs.title: Imaging vocabulary
docs.text:
• plain radiographs (X-rays)
  • MRI / CT / ultrasound
  • joint space narrowing
  • osteophytes
  • subchondral sclerosis / cysts
  • malalignment

docs.title: Assessment language
docs.text:
• consistent with
  • most likely
  • differential diagnosis
  • rule out
  • red flags

docs.title: 1) Opening and purpose (clinic note / letter)
docs.text:
• It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for assessment of [PROBLEM].
  • Thank you for referring [PATIENT] for evaluation of [PROBLEM].
  • [PATIENT] returns today for follow-up of [DIAGNOSIS/PROBLEM].
  • I reviewed [PATIENT] today regarding [PROBLEM], with a focus on [GOAL].

docs.title: Core descriptors
docs.text:
• The pain began [ONSET] and has been present for [DURATION].
  • Symptoms are [IMPROVING / WORSENING / UNCHANGED] over time.
  • The pain is located over the [LOCATION] and is [SHARP / DULL / ACHING / BURNING].
  • Symptoms are aggravated by [ACTIVITY] and relieved by [REST / MEDICATION / OFFLOADING].
  • [PATIENT] reports [INSTABILITY / CATCHING / LOCKING / GIVING WAY].
  • There is [NO / INTERMITTENT / PERSISTENT] swelling.

docs.title: Functional framing (high yield)
docs.text:
• The main limitation is [FUNCTIONAL LIMITATION].
  • [PATIENT] is unable to [ACTIVITY] because of pain.
  • Walking tolerance is approximately [DISTANCE / TIME].
  • Stairs are [DIFFICULT / NOT POSSIBLE] due to [PAIN / INSTABILITY].

docs.title: Prior management
docs.text:
• Prior management has included [PHYSIOTHERAPY / ORTHOTICS / NSAIDs / INJECTION / IMMOBILIZATION].
  • This provided [GOOD / PARTIAL / MINIMAL] relief.
  • [PATIENT] has tried [TREATMENT] for [DURATION] without sustained benefit.

docs.title: 3) Past history and risk modifiers (brief)
docs.text:
• Relevant comorbidities include [DIABETES / SMOKING / RA / OSTEOPOROSIS].
  • There is no history of inflammatory arthropathy.
  • [PATIENT] is [NOT] taking anticoagulants.
  • Allergies: [ALLERGIES].

docs.title: 4) Examination (phrases that read well)
docs.text:
• On examination, the skin is intact with no erythema or warmth.
  • There is tenderness over the [STRUCTURE].
  • Swelling is [MILD / MODERATE / SIGNIFICANT].
  • Range of motion is [FULL / LIMITED], with pain at [END RANGE / THROUGHOUT].
  • Neurovascular status is intact distally.
  • The hindfoot alignment is [NEUTRAL / VARUS / VALGUS].
  • [TEST] is [POSITIVE / NEGATIVE].

docs.title: 5) Imaging and investigations
docs.text:
• Plain radiographs demonstrate [FINDINGS].
  • There is evidence of [OSTEOPHYTES / JOINT SPACE NARROWING / SUBCHONDRAL SCLEROSIS] consistent with [OA].
  • MRI shows [FINDINGS].
  • CT is requested to assess [BONE STOCK / ARTHRITIS EXTENT / ALIGNMENT].

docs.title: 6) Impression (diagnosis statement)
docs.text:
• Overall, this presentation is most consistent with [DIAGNOSIS].
  • The leading differential diagnoses include [DDX 1] and [DDX 2].
  • At present, there is no clinical evidence of [RED FLAG].

docs.title: 7) Plan (actionable, includes If–Then)
docs.text:
• I recommend [CONSERVATIVE PLAN] for [DURATION].
  • We will arrange [INVESTIGATION] to clarify [QUESTION].
  • Follow-up in [FOLLOW-UP] to review symptoms and results.
  • If symptoms persist despite [CONSERVATIVE], then we will consider [NEXT STEP].
  • If there is meaningful improvement, then we will continue [PLAN] and review as needed.

docs.title: 8) Shared decision-making / consent-style phrases
docs.text:
• We discussed the options of [OPTION A] versus [OPTION B], including expected recovery and potential complications.
  • The potential benefits are [BENEFITS]; the main risks include [RISKS].
  • [PATIENT] understands the above and wishes to proceed with [PLAN].
  • [PATIENT] would like time to consider surgery; we will reassess in [TIMEFRAME].

docs.title: 9) Postoperative instructions (generic phrasing)
docs.text:
• Postoperatively, the patient will be [NWB / PWB / WBAT] for [DURATION].
  • Immobilization in [SPLINT / CAST / BOOT] for [DURATION].
  • DVT prophylaxis: [AGENT] for [DURATION], unless contraindicated.
  • Wound check at [TIMEFRAME]; suture removal at [TIMEFRAME].
  • Physiotherapy to commence at [TIMEFRAME] focusing on [GOALS].

docs.title: 10) Letter closing (professional tone)
docs.text:
• Thank you again for the referral.
  • Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.
  • I will review [PATIENT] in [FOLLOW-UP] to reassess and finalize the plan.

docs.title: 手術記録の型（術直後に仕上げる）
docs.text: 手術記録は、後から思い出して書くものではなく、術中の意思決定と再現可能性を記録するためのものです。このページでは、術直後に完成できる型を提供します。必要に応じて音声入力やスクライブを活用することで、記録の質と効率を両立できます。

docs.title: 0. 原則
docs.text:
• 記録の核は適応と術式選択の理由です。手順を羅列するだけでは不十分です。
  • 術中に分岐した点（予定変更、追加処置、固定方法の変更など）を最優先で記録します。
  • 翌日の自分や他者が読んで再現できる粒度を目指しましょう。
  • 症例同定性のある情報は公開ページに含めず、必要な場合はprivate/フォルダへ保存します。

docs.title: Total Ankle Replacement (TAR)
docs.text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: Ankle joint arthritis in a setting of previous talar osteochondral defect.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: Same as preoperative.

NAME OF PROCEDURES: - Total ankle replacement - Insertion of medial malleolar screw - Ankle medial and lateral gutter release with ostectomies - Talonavicular joint arthrotomy and release

DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:

The patient was positioned supine on the operating table. A thigh tourniquet was applied and inflated to 300 mmHg. Intravenous antibiotics were administered. The limb was prepped, marked and draped. A primary and secondary time out was performed prior to skin incision.

A midline anterior incision was made over the ankle. An anterior approach was utilized to the ankle joint via the interval of the tibialis anterior and the EHL tendon. The anterior tibial neovascular bundle was identified and protected laterally throughout the operation. The superficial peroneal nerve was identified immediately in the deep subcutaneous cavity and was protected laterally throughout the operation also. An anterior arthrotomy of the ankle joint was made with continued extension down to the level of the talonavicular joint whereby further arthrotomy was made with release medially and laterally of the talonavicular joint.

The patient specific instrumentation jig was applied to the tibia under the use of direct vision and x-ray. Multiple K wires were inserted for positioning under the confirmation of x-ray. The apparatus for the distal tibial cut was applied. The proximal corners were predrilled. The distal tibial cut was made with the use of the cutting jig and with intraoperative x-ray. The distal tibial bone segment was removed. Balancing was examined with the use of a lamina spreader which confirmed there was no significant medial or lateral ligament redundancy or laxity. A medial and lateral gutter release was performed along with ostectomies of the gutters.

The patient specific talus guide was applied under direct vision and the use of intraoperative x-ray. Multiple K wires were inserted for fixation. A talar chamfer cut was made via the use of a cutting jig. A trial of components was performed with equal balancing.

The bony surfaces were prepared. Local bone graft was deposited into the anterior talar chamfer cut. Insertion of the definitive prosthesis was then made. The prosthesis sizes were a Stryker Infinity tibia size 2 with a Stryker Infinity size 2 talar body. A Stryker Infinity 6 mm poly was inserted. The final reduction was stable and well balanced clinically. Final intraoperative x-rays were utilized as well.

The wound was irrigated and closed in a layered manner with 2-0 Vicryl to the arthrotomy and the extensor retinaculum. 3-0 Vicryl sutures were used for the subcutaneous layer and 3-0 nylon sutures were used for the skin closure. A Jelonet and gauze dressing was applied. A below knee Tri slab plaster was applied. The tourniquet was deflated.

POSTOPERATIVE INSTRUCTIONS: The patient is nonweightbearing in a below knee Tri slab plaster for 3 weeks. The patient requires intravenous antibiotics for 24 hours postoperative. The patient requires aspirin 81 mg b.i.d. orally for 3 weeks for VT prophylaxis. The patient is being prescribed hydromorphone analgesia p.r.n. upon discharge along with vitamin C and vitamin D supplementation.

Follow-up in 3 weeks' time for removal of plaster, inspection of the surgical wound and removal of surgical sutures. Then aim to commence a graduated weightbearing program in a fracture boot following the 3 week review.

docs.title: Double Fusion (Subtalar and Talonavicular)
docs.text:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Stage 3 posterior tibial tendon deficiency with CT SPECT positive increased uptake in the navicular and posterior aspect of the subtalar joint. The patient was given the option of extraarticular correction and double fusion. In going over the risks and benefits preoperatively, we felt that the safest option for preventing recurrence and patient outcome would be a double fusion.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same as preoperative.

NAME OF PROCEDURE: 1. Subtalar fusion with 7-0 Fixos screws 2. Talonavicular fusion with two 4-0 Fixos screws and a 20-20 EasyClip staple 3. Peroneal brevis to longus transfer 3 cm proximal to the tip of the fibula 4. Gastroc recession from medial side approach 5. Bone graft with allograft as well as augment to subtalar talonavicular joints

DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:

The patient was brought to the operating room after undergoing a popliteal block with catheter in the block room. The patient was given 2 grams of Ancef and the leg was then prepped and draped in normal sterile fashion with a bump under the hip and thigh tourniquet and flannels under the leg that were well padded. The leg was then exsanguinated with an Esmarch and sharp dissection was made over the medial aspect of the gastroc at the musculotendinous junction as there was an equinus contracture 5 degrees short of neutral when the foot was corrected first to the subtalar joint and talonavicular joint. The gastroc was visualized and a dewar was used to clean out the tendon and protect it and the recession was complete making sure we did not have any damage to the sural nerve on the lateral side. This allowed about 10 to 15 degrees of dorsiflexion with the foot corrected and then that skin was closed with a nylon suture at that time and a sterile Mepore dressing was placed over top of it.

Sharp dissection was then made over the tip of the fibula at the subtalar joint, going down to the joint and protecting the CFL. A lateral process was removed with an osteotome and then the joint was prepared with an osteotome to remove the cartilage and a curette to the back along with a skinny rongeur. We were happy with the overall preparation of the joint but did not do any drilling or foraging at this point. We could see the FHL tendon through the joint, ensuring that we had adequate debridement. The posterior half of the subtalar joint was quite arthritic and sclerotic more so than what would have been expected from the CT SPECT scan, but again confirming the benefit of the subtalar fusion for the patient's symptoms at this time.

An incision was made just posterior to the fibula approximately 3 cm up, visualizing the peroneal brevis deep to the peroneal longus. The peroneal brevis was then released at the level of the subtalar joint and pulled up through and then kept in that incision until the tension at the end for the Pulvertaft weave.

Attention was then made over the talonavicular joint where sharp dissection was made. Superficial peroneal nerve was visualized and protected. EHL tendon sheath was then transected sharply. The deep neurovascular bundle was visualized and taken off the TN capsule. The TN capsule was then incised sharply and the TN joint was visualized. Laminar spreader was placed inside and an osteotome and bur were used under low speed to remove the bone off of both the talus and the navicular bone for good preparation. We were happy with the overall preparation. We assessed the ability to correct the foot. Once we were happy with the correction of the subtalar joint as well as talonavicular joint, 2 K-wires were placed to fuse the subtalar joint for 7-0 screws. Once we were happy with their position and that the foot was corrected, the subtalar joint was reduced and the talus was restacked. They were measured and then drilled across. They were verified on lateral AP and Harris heel views to ensure that they were in bone and we were happy with their positioning. We also verified prior to placing these that the K-wires were across the subtalar joint and we were able to reduce and pronate the TN joint to where we wanted it and we were happy with this position. Two K-wire bone grafts with augment were placed into the subtalar joint prior to this as well as the TN joint and packed tightly.

Attention was then made after the 7-0 screws were placed in the subtalar joint to the TN joint where percutaneously 2 medial K-wires were placed that would fit the 4-0 screws. We were happy with their position. Fifty mm 4-0 Fixos screws were inserted, showing good compression and position of the overstacking of the navicular on the talus and good A-P coverage as well. An EasyClip 20 mm staple was then placed laterally to help with rotational control and compression. The ankle was then taken through a full range of motion and verified the foot position. We were happy on x-ray as well as clinical of the strike point of the calcaneus being just slightly lateral to the tibial tubercle as well as the visible arch now on the medial side of the foot and the strike point of the first and fifth rays.

The wounds were irrigated. The capsule was closed with TN joint and the EHL tendon sheath was closed with the TN joint and subcutaneous closure done with 3-0 Vicryl and skin was closed with nylon sutures. The lateral incision and percutaneous holes were closed with nylon sutures and then the Pulvertaft weave was completed under tension with the foot in a neutral position, we tensioned the peroneal brevis as long as possible and pulvertafted it through the longest and sutured and tied it off with a 3-0 PDS. Subcutaneous closure there was done with 3-0 Vicryl and skin was closed with nylon sutures.

A final x-ray was taken. We were happy with the overall positioning and range of motion and a sterile dressing and a tri-slab were placed. The patient will be nonweightbearing for approximately 6 to 12 weeks until x-ray shows signs of healing. Follow-up in 2 to 3 weeks for wound check. DVT prophylaxis, vitamin D and vitamin C prescribed.

docs.title: OUT PATIENT
docs.text: This section provides structured templates for outpatient consultations, organized by patient type and clinical scenario. Each scenario includes guidance for patient communication, documentation, and presentation.

docs.title: 1. New Referral
docs.text:
First-time consultations for new patients referred to the foot and ankle service.

  • A. Diagnostic Testing + Non-Surgical Treatment: Patients requiring investigation with planned conservative management
  • B. Surgical Treatment: Patients being offered operative intervention

docs.title: 2. Follow-up
docs.text:
Return visits for established patients.

  • A. Test Results + Non-Surgical Treatment: Reviewing investigations and initiating/continuing conservative care
  • B. Post-Op Acute (Complication Monitoring): Early postoperative review (0-6 weeks) focusing on wound healing and complication surveillance
  • C. Post-Op Subacute (Functional Recovery): Later postoperative review (6 weeks+) focusing on rehabilitation and functional outcomes

docs.title: Format
docs.text:
Each clinical scenario is presented in three formats:

  1. Patient Communication: Conversational phrases and explanation templates for direct patient interaction
  2. Documentation: Structured templates for medical records and referral letters
  3. Short Presentation: Concise format for presenting to colleagues or at handover

docs.title: Components
docs.text:
Each format follows the same clinical structure:

  • a. History Taking: Key questions and information gathering
  • b. Examination: Physical findings and assessment
  • c. Impression: Diagnostic synthesis and clinical reasoning
  • d. Recommendation: Treatment plan and follow-up strategy

This is a new dictation for PATIENT NAME. ID is . Dictated by Takahisa Ogawa orthopedic fellow signed for Dr Mark Glazebrook. Dictation date is X. Please cc this letter to patients family physician X.

docs.title: Follow-up
docs.text: Return visits for established patients. The clinical approach varies based on treatment stage and goals of the visit.

docs.title: A. Test Results + Non-Surgical Treatment
docs.text:
For patients returning to: - Review investigation results - Discuss diagnostic confirmation - Continue or modify conservative treatment - Reassess symptoms and progress

Key Goals: - Explain test findings in plain language - Confirm or refine diagnosis - Review treatment response - Plan next steps with If-Then contingencies

docs.title: B. Post-Op Acute (Complication Monitoring)
docs.text:
Early postoperative period (typically 0-6 weeks) focusing on: - Wound healing assessment - Complication surveillance (infection, DVT, nerve injury) - Pain management - Initial mobilization guidance

Key Goals: - Identify complications early - Ensure safe wound healing - Confirm adherence to weight-bearing restrictions - Plan progression to next phase

docs.title: C. Post-Op Subacute (Functional Recovery)
docs.text:
Later postoperative period (typically 6 weeks+) focusing on: - Functional recovery and rehabilitation - Return to activities - Long-term outcome assessment - Discharge planning

Key Goals: - Monitor functional progress - Guide rehabilitation advancement - Manage patient expectations - Plan return to work/sport - Determine discharge or ongoing follow-up needs

docs.title: Letter Structure
docs.text:
This template follows the standard outpatient letter format: Diagnosis → Plan → Main paragraph → Impression and recommendation.

For acute postoperative follow-up (typically 2-4 weeks), focus on wound healing, early complications, and protocol adherence.

docs.title: 1. Diagnosis
docs.text:
Format: Time post-op + Procedure + Current status

Template: - [TIME: ~2 weeks / ~3 weeks / ~4 weeks] post [SPECIFIC PROCEDURE], performed [DATE] - [Postoperative course descriptor if relevant]

Common descriptors: - progressing satisfactorily | progressing as expected | uncomplicated postoperative course - history of [COMPLICATION] (if applicable - now resolved / managed)

Example:

Diagnosis
- ~3 weeks post right total ankle replacement, performed 15/12/25
- Progressing satisfactorily with no complications

docs.title: 2. Plan
docs.text:
Format: Wound management → Weight-bearing/immobilization status → Rehabilitation → Imaging → Follow-up → Red flags

Template:

Wound Care: - Status: [clean and dry / healed / sutures removed today / staples removed] - Continue: [local wound care / keep dry / no specific care needed] - Suture/staple removal: [completed today / planned at TIMEFRAME] - Dressing: [none needed / continue for DURATION]

Weight-Bearing and Immobilization: - Current status: [NWB / PWB / WBAT / FWB] - Continue: [NWB / PWB / WBAT] until [TIMEFRAME: ~6 weeks / ~8 weeks] - Equipment: [boot / cast / crutches] until [TIMEFRAME] - Progression: Plan to [advance to WBAT / transition to shoe / wean from boot] at [TIMEFRAME]

Rehabilitation: - Current phase: [early ROM / protected mobilization] - Instructions: [commence / continue] active range of motion exercises - Restrictions: Avoid [specific activities] - Physiotherapy: [commence at TIMEFRAME / continue current program / not yet indicated]

Medications: - Analgesia: [continue as needed / wean / specific instructions] - DVT prophylaxis: [agent, duration] (if applicable) - Other: [antibiotics if indicated / specific medications]

Imaging: - Today's X-ray: [reviewed - findings summarized] - Next X-ray: at [~6 weeks / next visit] to assess [healing / hardware position / alignment]

Follow-up: - Review in [TIMEFRAME: ~2-4 weeks / ~6 weeks] - Purpose: [wound check / suture removal / X-ray review / progress assessment / plan next phase]

Red Flags - Return Immediately If: - Fever >38°C or chills - Increasing redness, warmth, or drainage from wound - New or worsening numbness or tingling - Severe pain not controlled by medication - Calf pain or swelling (DVT concern) - Any concerns about wound healing

Common phrases: - Wound care: sutures removed today | continue local wound care | keep clean and dry - Weight-bearing: remain NWB until [~6 weeks] | continue PWB in boot - Imaging: review at [~6 weeks] with X-ray | consider progression to WBAT depending on radiographic and clinical status - Follow-up: review in [TIMEFRAME] for [purpose] - Red flags: If fever, increasing redness, drainage, or concerns → contact office immediately

Example:

Plan
- Wound care: Anterior wound sutures removed today; wound is healed; continue local wound care with simple dressing changes until fully sealed

- Weight-bearing: Remain non-weight-bearing until ~6 weeks post-op
- Equipment: Continue in CAM boot for protection
- Mobility: Continue with crutches, may use knee scooter if preferred

- Rehabilitation: Commence/continue active range of motion exercises (ankle pumps, circles within comfort) - 3-4 times daily
- Restrictions: Avoid forced dorsiflexion or plantarflexion for now

- Medications: 
  - Analgesia: Continue paracetamol as needed; wean off opioids if prescribed
  - DVT prophylaxis: Aspirin 100mg daily for 6 weeks post-op
  - No antibiotics needed

- Imaging: X-ray today reviewed - satisfactory prosthesis position, alignment maintained
- Next X-ray: At ~6-week visit to assess bone ingrowth and alignment

- Follow-up: Review at ~6 weeks (approximately [DATE]) with X-ray
- Purpose: Assess radiographic and clinical healing, consider progression to WBAT in boot

- Red flags: Contact office immediately if fever, increasing wound redness/drainage, severe uncontrolled pain, calf swelling, or any concerns

docs.title: 3. Main Paragraph
docs.text:
Format: Opening → Postoperative timeframe → Symptom review (pain/wound/mobility) → Adherence check → Complications screening → Examination (wound/neurovascular/early functional) → Imaging review

Template:

Opening: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for a postoperative review, [TIME] following [PROCEDURE].

Pain Assessment: [PATIENT] reports pain is [well controlled / manageable / moderate / severe]. Current pain level: [VAS score / descriptive]. Taking [analgesic regimen] with [good / adequate / insufficient] relief. Pain is [improving trend / stable / worsening]. [Specific pain patterns if relevant - night pain / pain with movement / constant vs intermittent].

Wound Status: [PATIENT] reports the wound [looks good / is dry / has some drainage / concerns]. No fever or chills. Dressing has been [kept dry / changed as instructed / some issues]. No concerning symptoms.

Mobility and Function: [PATIENT] has been [adhering to NWB restrictions / managing with crutches / using boot as prescribed / having difficulties]. [Able to perform daily activities with assistance / independent at home / requiring significant support]. No episodes of inadvertent weight-bearing.

Medications and Compliance: Taking [analgesia / DVT prophylaxis / other medications] as prescribed. [No side effects / specific side effects if relevant]. [No / Some] difficulties with compliance.

Complications Screening: No fever, chills, or systemic symptoms. No signs of wound infection. No symptoms suggesting DVT/PE (no calf pain or swelling, no shortness of breath or chest pain). No new neurological symptoms. No concerns reported.

Examination:

Wound Assessment: - Appearance: [clean, dry, intact / well-healed / minor erythema / drainage / dehiscence] - Surgical incision(s): [location] - [well-approximated / healing well / concerns] - Sutures/staples: [removed today / intact / partial removal / will remove at next visit] - Swelling: [minimal / moderate / significant - expected for timeframe] - Temperature: [normal / slightly warm / hot - clinical concern] - Surrounding skin: [normal / erythema / breakdown]

Neurovascular Assessment: - Sensation: [intact / altered - distribution if abnormal] - Motor function: [intact / weakness - specify] - Vascular: [good capillary refill / pulses palpable / concerns] - Distal circulation: [toes warm and pink / concerns]

Range of Motion (if appropriate to assess at this stage): - [Measured ROM or note if assessment deferred due to postoperative protocol] - [Note if limited by pain vs surgical restriction vs stiffness]

Functional Assessment (basic at this stage): - Can perform ankle pumps / toe movements - [Other relevant early functional measures]

Post-Operative Imaging (if obtained):

X-ray ([DATE], [views]):

Hardware Assessment: - Type and location: [screws, plate, prosthesis - specify configuration] - Position: [satisfactory / excellent / concerns] - Screws: [number], trajectory [good / suboptimal], purchase in bone [adequate / concerns] - Plate: [position / contouring - satisfactory] - Prosthesis: [position / alignment - specify]

Alignment: - [Measurements - angles, distances as relevant] - Compare to immediate post-op: [stable / slight change / significant change] - Overall alignment: [anatomic / satisfactory / concerns]

Bone Healing (too early at this stage for significant healing): - Fracture/osteotomy site: [maintained / gap unchanged / concerns about displacement] - Arthrodesis site: [bone contact adequate / concerns] - Note: Too early for callus formation or significant healing

Complications: - Hardware: [secure / loosening suspected / broken hardware] - Alignment: [maintained / loss of reduction] - Other: [any concerns - hematoma, bone quality issues]

Imaging Interpretation: Post-operative X-rays demonstrate [hardware in satisfactory position / alignment maintained / appropriate for this early timeframe]. [Any specific concerns or reassuring features]. No immediate complications visualized.

Common phrases: - It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] for postoperative review - [TIME] following [PROCEDURE] - reports pain is well controlled with [medication] - The [anterior / medial / lateral] wound is [healing well / healed] - No fever, chills, or systemic symptoms - No signs of wound infection or DVT - Sutures/staples removed today | intact and will be removed at next visit - On examination, the wound is [clean, dry, intact] - Swelling is [minimal / moderate] which is [normal / expected] for this timeframe - Neurovascular status: sensation intact, motor function intact, good capillary refill - X-rays demonstrate [hardware in satisfactory position] - Alignment is [maintained / anatomic] - No immediate complications visualized

Example:

Main Paragraph

It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for a post-operative review, approximately 3 weeks following a right total ankle replacement performed on 15/12/25.

[PATIENT] reports pain is well controlled. Current pain level is 2-3/10 at rest, 4-5/10 with movement or elevation changes. Taking paracetamol 1g four times daily and occasional endone (3-4 tablets over the past week, decreasing frequency). Pain has been steadily improving over the past week. Mainly achiness and stiffness rather than sharp pain. Some increase in discomfort at end of day but managed with elevation and ice. No night pain interfering with sleep for the past 5 days. No neuropathic symptoms (shooting pain, burning, numbness).

[PATIENT] reports the anterior wound looks good and has been staying dry. No drainage, no odor, no increasing redness. Dressing changes performed as instructed every 2-3 days. No fever or chills. No systemic symptoms. No calf pain or swelling to suggest DVT.

[PATIENT] has been strictly adhering to non-weight-bearing restrictions and managing well with crutches at home. Using knee scooter for longer distances. Independent in transfers and most daily activities. Spouse assisting with some household tasks. Able to perform ankle pump exercises regularly. No episodes of inadvertent weight-bearing.

Taking aspirin 100mg daily for DVT prophylaxis with no side effects or concerns. No issues with medication compliance.

No complications reported: no fever (has been monitoring temperature - all readings <37°C), no wound concerns, no chest pain or shortness of breath, no new neurological symptoms, no difficulties with circulation.

On examination:

Wound assessment:
- Anterior incision is well-healed, approximately 10cm in length, centrally located over anterior ankle
- Sutures removed today without difficulty
- Wound edges well-approximated with no gaps or concerns
- Minimal residual scab at inferior aspect (expected)
- No erythema, no drainage, no signs of infection
- Surrounding skin normal, no breakdown
- Swelling: Moderate diffuse swelling of the ankle and hindfoot (expected for 3 weeks post major ankle surgery)
- Temperature: Ankle slightly warmer than contralateral (expected postoperative inflammation, not concerning)
- No focal tenderness to suggest abscess or deep infection

Neurovascular assessment:
- Sensation: Intact in superficial peroneal, deep peroneal, sural, and tibial nerve distributions
- No areas of numbness or altered sensation
- Motor function: Able to perform active ankle pumps and toe movements
- Great toe extension and flexion intact
- No new motor deficits
- Vascular: Dorsalis pedis pulse palpable, posterior tibial pulse palpable
- Capillary refill <2 seconds in all toes
- Foot warm, toes pink, no concerns about circulation

Range of motion (early assessment):
- Active ankle ROM in boot: Approximately 5° dorsiflexion to 20° plantarflexion (limited by postoperative stiffness and swelling, appropriate for timeframe)
- Not pushing ROM at this early stage
- Subtalar motion deferred for now per protocol

Functional assessment:
- Performs ankle pumps well (20 repetitions demonstrated)
- Able to wiggle all toes
- No difficulty with early exercises

Post-operative imaging:

X-ray right ankle (today, weight-bearing views not performed - non-weight-bearing status):
- AP, lateral, and mortise views reviewed

Hardware assessment:
- Fixed-bearing total ankle prosthesis in situ
- Tibial component: Position satisfactory, slight anterior placement (planned intraoperatively), appropriate sizing, no evidence of subsidence
- Talar component: Position satisfactory, well-seated on talar dome, appropriate sizing
- Two anterior tibia screws securing tibial component: Position excellent, good trajectory, adequate purchase
- Overall prosthesis alignment looks good

Alignment:
- Tibiotalar alignment: Neutral (satisfactory)
- Hindfoot alignment: Neutral to slight valgus (appropriate)
- Component positioning: Tibial component approximately 5mm anterior translation relative to tibia (within acceptable range, allows adequate clearance)
- No varus or valgus malalignment
- Compare to immediate post-op films (performed 16/12/25): Position unchanged, no migration or subsidence

Bone healing:
- Bone cuts: Clean, well-apposed to components
- No periosteal reaction yet (too early)
- No evidence of early loosening or subsidence
- Bone quality appears adequate
- Note: Too early for significant bone ingrowth, but position stable is reassuring

Complications:
- No hardware failure
- No loss of alignment
- No fracture
- No significant heterotopic ossification
- Small amount of expected postoperative soft tissue swelling
- No lucencies around components (would be concerning this early)

Imaging interpretation:
Post-operative X-rays demonstrate the total ankle prosthesis in satisfactory position with maintained alignment since immediate post-operative films. Both tibial and talar components are well-positioned without evidence of subsidence, migration, or loosening at this early timeframe. Alignment is neutral, which is appropriate. No immediate complications visualized. Overall appearance is consistent with expected postoperative changes at 3 weeks.

docs.title: 4. Impression and Recommendation
docs.text:
Format: Summary of progress → Healing status → Complication assessment → Continue current plan → Next milestone → Follow-up

Template:

Summary of Progress: In summary, [PATIENT] is progressing [satisfactorily / appropriately / well / as expected] at [TIME] post [PROCEDURE]. [Overall assessment of recovery trajectory].

Healing Status: The wound is [healing well / healed / satisfactory] with [no / minor] concerns. [Pain is controlled / improving / requires adjustment]. [Patient is managing well / having some difficulties] with postoperative restrictions and care.

Complication Assessment: There are [no signs / no current evidence] of [infection / DVT / nerve injury / other specific complications]. [Neurovascular status remains intact / all parameters normal]. [Radiographic assessment shows no immediate complications].

Continue Current Management: I recommend continuing the current postoperative protocol as outlined: - [Weight-bearing status and duration] - [Immobilization and equipment] - [Exercises and activity restrictions] - [Medications]

Next Milestone: At the next visit ([TIMEFRAME]), we will: - [Obtain X-rays to assess healing/hardware/alignment] - [Assess readiness for weight-bearing progression] - [Review clinical healing and function] - [Plan transition to next phase: WBAT / boot weaning / physiotherapy]

Safety Net: [PATIENT] has been advised to contact the office immediately if: - [Specific red flags relevant to procedure and current phase] - Any concerns about healing or recovery

Common phrases: - is progressing satisfactorily | appropriately | as expected - in the acute post-operative phase - The wound is healing well | nicely | satisfactorily - Pain is well controlled | manageable | improving - There are no signs of infection | DVT | complications - Neurovascular status remains intact - I recommend continuing non-weight-bearing | current postoperative pathway - I will review [PATIENT] at the [~6-week] mark - with X-rays to determine readiness for | to assess - earlier if concerns arise | any issues develop

Example:

Impression and Recommendation

In summary, [PATIENT] is progressing satisfactorily in the acute post-operative phase following right total ankle replacement, now 3 weeks post-surgery. Overall recovery trajectory is appropriate for this timeframe.

The anterior wound is healed with sutures removed today without difficulty. No signs of infection, wound breakdown, or dehiscence. Pain is well controlled with simple analgesia and steadily improving. [PATIENT] is managing well at home with non-weight-bearing restrictions, adhering to protocol, and performing exercises as instructed. Psychological adjustment to postoperative period is good.

There are no current signs of complications. Specifically: no evidence of wound infection (no fever, no systemic symptoms, wound appearance excellent, no drainage or erythema); no evidence of DVT (no calf pain or swelling, taking aspirin prophylaxis); neurovascular status remains intact with normal sensation, motor function, and vascular perfusion; no hardware failure or alignment loss on radiographic assessment. The moderate swelling present is expected for this timeframe and not concerning.

I recommend continuing the current postoperative protocol as outlined:
- Remain non-weight-bearing for an additional 3 weeks (total 6 weeks from surgery)
- Continue using CAM boot for protection and crutches for mobility
- Continue active range of motion exercises 3-4 times daily (ankle pumps, circles) within comfort
- Avoid forced dorsiflexion or inversion/eversion for now
- Continue aspirin 100mg daily for DVT prophylaxis (will continue for total 6 weeks)
- Wean analgesics as able; paracetamol should be sufficient at this point
- Elevation when resting to manage swelling
- Ice application as needed for comfort

At the next visit in approximately 3 weeks (~6 weeks post-op, around [DATE]), we will:
- Obtain weight-bearing X-rays to assess prosthesis position, alignment stability, and early bone ingrowth
- Assess clinical healing: swelling status, ROM improvement, pain level
- Determine readiness for progression to weight-bearing as tolerated (WBAT) in boot
- If appropriate based on radiographic and clinical assessment, commence WBAT phase and transition to formal physiotherapy for supervised rehabilitation

The expected timeline for recovery milestones:
- 6 weeks: Progress to WBAT in boot (if X-rays satisfactory)
- 8-10 weeks: Wean from boot to supportive shoes
- 3 months: Increasing activity and function
- 6 months: Substantial functional improvement
- 12 months: Final outcome assessment

[PATIENT] has been advised of red flags and instructed to contact the office immediately if:
- Fever >38°C or chills
- Wound changes: increasing redness, warmth, drainage, wound breakdown, odor
- Severe pain not controlled by medications or sudden increase in pain (could indicate hardware failure or other complication)
- New neurological symptoms: numbness, tingling, weakness, foot drop
- Calf pain or swelling (DVT concern)
- Shortness of breath or chest pain (PE concern)
- Any other concerns about healing or recovery

Thank you for allowing me to participate in [PATIENT]'s care.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. [YOUR NAME]
Orthopaedic Surgeon

docs.title: Complete Letter Example
docs.text:
[CLINIC LETTERHEAD]
[DATE]

Dr. [REFERRING DOCTOR]
[ADDRESS]

Re: [PATIENT NAME], DOB: [DATE]

Dear Dr. [REFERRING DOCTOR],

Diagnosis
- ~3 weeks post right total ankle replacement, performed 15/12/25
- Progressing satisfactorily with no complications

Plan
- Wound care: Sutures removed today; wound healed
- Weight-bearing: Remain NWB until ~6 weeks
- Equipment: Continue CAM boot and crutches
- Rehabilitation: Continue active ROM exercises
- Medications: Wean analgesia; continue aspirin 100mg daily (DVT prophylaxis)
- Imaging: X-ray today - satisfactory prosthesis position; next X-ray at ~6 weeks
- Follow-up: Review at ~6 weeks with X-ray to assess progression to WBAT

Main Paragraph

It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] for postoperative review, 3 weeks following right total ankle replacement. Pain well controlled (2-3/10 rest, 4-5/10 movement) with paracetamol, steadily improving. No fever, no wound concerns. Adhering to NWB restrictions. Taking aspirin for DVT prophylaxis. No complications reported.

On examination: Anterior wound healed, sutures removed today. No signs of infection. Moderate swelling (expected for timeframe). Neurovascular status intact: sensation and motor function normal, pulses palpable. Able to perform ankle pumps.

X-rays: Total ankle prosthesis in satisfactory position, alignment maintained since immediate post-op, no subsidence or hardware concerns.

Impression and Recommendation

In summary, [PATIENT] is progressing satisfactorily at 3 weeks post total ankle replacement. Wound healed, pain controlled, no complications. I recommend continuing NWB for 3 more weeks. Review at ~6 weeks with X-ray to assess readiness for WBAT in boot and commence formal physiotherapy.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. [YOUR NAME]
Orthopaedic Surgeon

docs.title: Letter Structure
docs.text:
This template follows the standard outpatient letter format: Diagnosis → Plan → Main paragraph → Impression and recommendation.

For subacute postoperative follow-up (typically 6 weeks to 6 months), focus on healing progression, functional recovery, return to activities, and discharge planning.

docs.title: 1. Diagnosis
docs.text:
Format: Time post-op + Procedure + Current recovery status

Template: - [TIME: ~6 weeks / ~3 months / ~6 months] post [SPECIFIC PROCEDURE], performed [DATE] - [Recovery status descriptor]

Common descriptors: - progressing well | satisfactory recovery | excellent functional outcome - good radiographic healing | solid fusion | bone healing progressing - achieving functional goals | returned to most activities

Example:

Diagnosis
- ~6 months post right ankle arthroscopy and lateral ligament reconstruction, performed 15/07/25
- Excellent functional outcome with achievement of all goals

docs.title: 2. Plan
docs.text:
Format: Activity progression → Rehabilitation status → Discharge vs continued follow-up → Long-term considerations

Template:

Activity Progression: - Current activity level: [describe what patient can do now] - Cleared for: [specific activities - full activity / return to sport / return to work] - Progression guidance: [gradual increase / specific restrictions / sport-specific advice] - Timeframe: [when to expect full function]

Rehabilitation Status: - Physiotherapy: [completed / ongoing / discharged from physio] - Home exercise program: [continue / can stop / maintenance program] - Specific goals achieved: [ROM / strength / proprioception milestones] - Further therapy needed: [yes - for DURATION and GOALS / no further formal therapy needed]

Return to Activities:

Work: - Status: [returned to full duties / modified duties / not yet returned] - Clearance: [cleared for full duties / continue modifications for DURATION / gradual return advised] - Restrictions: [none / avoid SPECIFIC ACTIVITY for DURATION]

Driving: - Status: [already driving / cleared to resume] - Guidance: [specific advice if relevant - e.g., right ankle surgery and emergency braking]

Sport: - Status: [returned / progressing toward return / not yet] - Clearance: [cleared for all sports / specific sports / contact sports at TIMEFRAME] - Progression: [gradual return over DURATION / sport-specific program / return when comfortable]

Follow-up Plan:

If Progressing Well: - Discharge: To GP care with open-door policy - Annual review: If indicated (e.g., for hardware, arthroplasty, fusion assessment) - PRN return: If concerns, symptoms worsen, or new problems develop

If Concerns or Ongoing Issues: - Continued follow-up: Review in [TIMEFRAME] - Goals for next visit: [assess specific concern / finalize recovery / hardware removal planning] - Additional treatment: [if needed - further physio / injection / consideration for revision]

Long-term Considerations: - Expected timeline to final outcome: [up to 12 months / 18 months] - Ongoing care: [monitoring for arthritis / hardware surveillance / other] - Activity modifications: [lifelong / temporary] - Footwear: [specific recommendations / orthotics]

Common phrases: - Cleared for | may return to | can progress to - Continue | Stop | Maintain - Discharge to GP care | Open-door policy | Return PRN - If concerns arise | symptoms worsen | new problems develop - Annual review | Routine follow-up in [DURATION] - Expected full recovery by | Continue to improve over - Long-term: monitor for | surveillance of

Example:

Plan
- Activity progression:
  - Cleared for all activities including return to recreational basketball and hiking
  - No restrictions on activity level
  - Continue to build endurance and intensity gradually over the next 2-3 months

- Rehabilitation status:
  - Discharged from formal physiotherapy (completed 12-week program)
  - Continue home proprioception exercises for maintenance (balance board 3x/week)
  - ROM and strength goals achieved (equal to contralateral)

- Return to activities:
  - Work: Already returned full-time (desk job) - no issues
  - Driving: No restrictions
  - Sport: Begin gradual return to basketball - start with skills practice and light drills, progress to full play over 4-6 weeks as tolerated; cleared for hiking immediately

- Follow-up:
  - Discharge to GP care with open-door policy
  - Return PRN if concerns arise: recurrent instability, persistent pain, new symptoms
  - Routine follow-up not required unless problems develop

- Long-term considerations:
  - Small risk of recurrent instability (5-10%) - if occurs, return for assessment
  - Some residual stiffness compared to pre-injury normal is expected and should not limit function
  - No specific activity restrictions lifelong
  - Monitor for development of arthritis long-term (annual X-rays not needed unless symptomatic)

docs.title: 3. Main Paragraph
docs.text:
Format: Opening → Postoperative timeframe → Functional status review → Symptom status → Rehabilitation progress → Patient satisfaction → Examination (comparative to baseline and goals) → Imaging review with healing assessment

Template:

Opening: [PATIENT] returns today for review, [TIME] following [PROCEDURE].

Functional Status: [PATIENT] reports [excellent / good / satisfactory / ongoing difficulty with] functional recovery. Currently able to: [specific functional milestones - walking unlimited / stairs without rail / returned to work / doing sport]. Compared to preoperative status: [much improved / significant improvement / some improvement / minimal change].

Specific activities: - Walking: Distance [unlimited / limited to DISTANCE] [on flat ground / on uneven terrain / with aids] - Stairs: [managing independently / requires rail / difficulty] - Work: [returned full duties / modified duties / not yet returned] - Sport: [specific activities and level achieved]

Symptom Status: Pain: [resolved / minimal / mild / moderate / severe]. Current level: [VAS or descriptive]. Location: [if persistent - where]. Character: [if persistent - description]. Timing: [at rest / with activity / after activity]. Compared to preoperative: [much better / improved / unchanged].

Swelling: [resolved / minimal after activity / moderate / significant]. Timing: [constant / end of day / after specific activities]. Impact: [none / limiting footwear / limiting activity].

Stiffness: [none / minimal / significant]. Timing: [morning / after rest / constant]. Impact: [none / limiting function / requires warmup].

Instability or other symptoms: [describe if present / none reported].

Rehabilitation Progress: Physiotherapy: [Completed NUMBER sessions / ongoing]. Focus: [ROM / strengthening / proprioception / sport-specific]. Achievements: [specific milestones reached]. Home program: [compliant / partially compliant / issues with].

Progress in rehabilitation: [excellent / good / slower than expected / complications or setbacks].

Patient Satisfaction: [PATIENT] reports being [very satisfied / satisfied / somewhat satisfied / dissatisfied] with the outcome. [Achieving / Has achieved / Working toward / Not yet achieved] preoperative goals of [specific goals]. Overall quality of life: [significantly improved / improved / unchanged / worse].

Examination (Comparative):

Gait: [normal / minimal antalgic component / antalgic / uses walking aid]. Compared to preoperative: [much improved / improved / similar].

Inspection: - Scar(s): [well-healed / hypertrophic / keloid / other] - Swelling: [absent / minimal / moderate / significant] - Alignment: [maintained / appropriate / concerns] - Muscle atrophy: [resolved / minimal / still present]

Palpation: - Tenderness: [resolved / minimal over LOCATION / significant over LOCATION] - Hardware: [not prominent / palpable / prominent / painful - if applicable] - Surgical area: [no tenderness / residual sensitivity]

Range of Motion: - [JOINT]: Active [measurements] / Passive [measurements] - Compared to contralateral: [equal / 90% / 75% / 50% / <50%] - Compared to preoperative: [much improved / improved / similar / worse] - End feel: [normal / stiff / painful / soft tissue restriction] - Specific movements: [note any particularly limited or problematic movements]

Strength: - [Muscle groups tested]: [5/5 / 4+/5 / 4/5 / 3/5 - compared to contralateral] - Compared to preoperative: [improved / similar / weaker] - Functional strength: [good / adequate / needs further work]

Stability (if relevant): - [Ligament tests / stress tests]: [negative / stable / mild laxity / concerns] - Compared to preoperative: [much improved / improved / unchanged] - Patient perception: [feels stable / some instability / significant instability]

Functional Tests: - Single leg stance: [able for SECONDS / unable] - Heel/toe walking: [able / unable / difficulty] - Squat/lunge: [able / unable / pain with] - Hop test: [able / unable / reluctant] (if appropriate for stage and procedure) - [Other relevant functional tests specific to procedure or goals]

Follow-up Imaging Review:

X-ray ([DATE], [views]):

Hardware Assessment (if applicable): - Position: [stable / unchanged from previous / migrated / concerning changes] - All components: [intact / broken / loosened / backing out] - Compare to [DATE - previous X-ray]: [no change / progression noted]

Alignment: - [Measurements - angles, distances]: [maintained / within normal limits / concerns] - Compare to immediate post-op: [stable / some loss of correction / significant change] - Compare to [DATE]: [stable / progressive change] - Overall alignment: [satisfactory / excellent / concerns]

Bone Healing: - Fracture/osteotomy site: [healed / progressive healing / delayed union / nonunion] - Callus formation: [mature / bridging / hypertrophic / absent] - Bridging: [complete - 4/4 cortices / partial - 2-3/4 cortices / minimal - 0-1/4 cortices] - Time since surgery: [WEEKS/MONTHS] - [appropriate for timeline / delayed / concerning] - Quality of healing: [excellent / satisfactory / poor]

For Arthrodesis (Fusion) Cases: - Joint space: [obliterated / narrowing / persistent gap] - Bone bridging: [complete across joint / partial / minimal / absent] - Fusion status: [solid / progressing well / questionable / nonunion] - Estimated consolidation: [~X% fused based on appearance] - Grade: [by grading system if used - Suckel fusion grades or similar]

Complications: - Hardware failure: [none / specific issue] - Loss of reduction/alignment: [no / yes - describe] - Heterotopic ossification: [absent / present but not limiting / concerning] - Bone resorption or osteolysis: [none / present at LOCATION] - Arthritic changes in adjacent joints: [none / developing / significant] - Other: [any additional findings]

Radiographic Healing Timeline Assessment: At [X weeks/months] post-operatively, radiographic findings demonstrate [excellent / satisfactory / appropriate / delayed / concerning] healing for this timeframe. [Specific assessment of progress]. [Expected to progress to complete healing / union within expected timeframe / concerning for delayed union or nonunion - may require extended monitoring or intervention].

For Arthroplasty Cases: - Prosthesis position: [stable / no migration / subsidence noted] - Component alignment: [satisfactory / concerns] - Bone-prosthesis interface: [good integration / lucencies / loosening] - Wear: [not evident / minimal / concerning] - Compare to prior: [stable / changes noted]

Common phrases: - returns for review | [TIME] following [PROCEDURE] - reports excellent functional recovery | is doing well - Currently able to [specific activities] - Walking unlimited distances | returned to work full-time | playing sport - Pain is [resolved / minimal] - Swelling [resolved / minimal after prolonged activity] - Completed [NUMBER] sessions of physiotherapy - Very satisfied with outcome | achieving goals - On examination, gait is normal - Scar well-healed | no tenderness | no swelling - Range of motion [equal to contralateral / 90% of contralateral] - Strength 5/5 throughout | improved from preoperative - Single leg stance able for [TIME] | heel/toe walking able - X-rays demonstrate | show | confirm - [Fracture/osteotomy/fusion] is [healed / progressing well / solid] - Hardware in situ, position stable - Bone bridging complete | callus formation excellent - At [TIME] post-op, findings show [appropriate / excellent] healing

Example:

Main Paragraph

[PATIENT] returns for review, 6 months following right ankle arthroscopy and lateral ligament reconstruction (Broström-Gould procedure with suture tape augmentation), performed on 15/07/25.

[PATIENT] reports excellent functional recovery and achievement of all preoperative goals. Currently able to walk unlimited distances without pain or instability, including on uneven terrain and hiking trails. Able to manage stairs without difficulty or need for handrail. Returned to full-time work (teaching, requires prolonged standing and walking) 3 months ago without issues. Recently resumed playing recreational basketball - has played 3 full games over the past month with no giving-way episodes, good confidence in the ankle, and minimal post-activity soreness that resolves overnight. Compared to preoperative status: dramatic improvement - was having 2-3 giving-way episodes per week and was unable to play any sport; now fully active without instability.

Pain: Essentially resolved. Occasionally (once every 1-2 weeks) experiences mild aching (1-2/10) in the ankle after very long or intense activity days, which resolves with rest overnight. No pain at rest, no pain with normal daily activities. Vastly improved from preoperative constant achiness (4-5/10) and severe pain (8/10) with giving-way episodes.

Swelling: Resolved. No residual swelling even after full day of activity or after basketball games. Initially had mild end-of-day swelling for the first 3-4 months but this has completely resolved.

Stiffness: Minimal. Slight stiffness for the first 5 minutes after waking in the morning, resolves quickly with walking. No stiffness with activities. Doesn't feel this limits function.

Instability: Completely resolved. No subjective sense of instability. No giving-way episodes since surgery. Confident on all surfaces including uneven ground. Able to jump and land without fear or sensation of ankle instability. Subjectively feels the ankle is "much more solid" than before surgery.

Rehabilitation progress: Completed 12-week formal physiotherapy program (April-June 2025) with excellent progress. Focused on ROM restoration (weeks 6-8), progressive strengthening (weeks 8-12), proprioception training (weeks 8-12), and sport-specific training (weeks 10-12). Home program compliance has been good - continued balance board exercises 3-4 times per week for maintenance. Formal therapy discharged 3 months ago.

Patient satisfaction: [PATIENT] is very satisfied with the surgical outcome. States "I'm so happy I had this done - I can do everything I want to do now without worry about my ankle giving way." Has achieved preoperative goals of: (1) return to basketball - achieved, (2) hiking without instability - achieved, (3) confident in ankle stability for daily activities - achieved. Quality of life significantly improved, no longer limited by ankle symptoms.

On examination:

Gait: Normal. No antalgic component. Normal heel strike, midstance, and toe-off phases. No circumduction. Preoperatively had cautious gait with shortened stance phase on right.

Inspection:
- Surgical scars (anterolateral and lateral ankle): Well-healed, thin, non-tender. Approximately 3cm and 5cm in length. No hypertrophy or keloid. Normal pigmentation.
- Swelling: Absent. Ankle contours symmetric to contralateral side.
- Alignment: Neutral hindfoot alignment maintained. No varus or valgus deformity.
- Muscle: No visible atrophy of peroneals or calf compared to left (had mild atrophy early postoperative period, now resolved).

Palpation:
- No tenderness over surgical sites
- No tenderness over lateral ligament complex
- No tenderness over peroneal tendons
- Anterolateral ankle: No tenderness or thickening
- Hardware not palpable (suture tape is internal)

Range of motion:
- Right ankle: Active dorsiflexion 12° / plantarflexion 48°
- Left ankle (unaffected): Active dorsiflexion 15° / plantarflexion 50°
- Right ankle: 96% of left ankle ROM (excellent)
- Preoperative right ankle: Dorsiflexion 15° / plantarflexion 50° (full ROM preoperatively; current slight restriction is common after ligament reconstruction due to intentional tightening)
- End feel: Firm capsular end feel, not painful
- Subtalar motion: Full inversion and eversion bilaterally, symmetric
- Pain: No pain throughout range of motion

Strength:
- Ankle dorsiflexion: 5/5 bilaterally (tibialis anterior)
- Ankle plantarflexion: 5/5 bilaterally (gastrocnemius-soleus)
- Ankle inversion: 5/5 bilaterally (tibialis posterior and invertors)
- Ankle eversion: 5/5 bilaterally (peroneals) - had been 4/5 at 3-month mark, now fully recovered
- Great toe extension and flexion: 5/5 bilaterally
- Compared to preoperative: Eversion strength improved (was 4/5 preoperatively due to disuse and deconditioning)

Stability:
- Anterior drawer test: Negative. ~3mm anterior translation (normal), compared to left ~3mm. Firm endpoint. Preoperatively: 10mm with soft/absent endpoint.
- Talar tilt test: Negative. ~5° tilt, compared to left ~5°. Preoperatively: 15° with marked apprehension.
- Subjectively: Ankle feels very stable to patient. No apprehension with stress testing.
- Overall: Excellent stability restored

Functional tests:
- Single leg stance: Able to maintain >30 seconds eyes open on right, >30 seconds eyes closed. Equal to left. Excellent proprioception recovered.
- Heel walking: Able without difficulty
- Toe walking: Able without difficulty
- Single leg heel raise: Able x 20 repetitions on right (equal to left x 20)
- Squat: Able to full depth without pain or instability
- Hop test: Able to perform single-leg hops on right with good control, no pain, no subjective instability. Not formally measured but appears equal to contralateral.

Follow-up imaging:

X-ray right ankle (today's visit, weight-bearing AP, lateral, and mortise views):

Hardware assessment:
- Suture tape augmentation (internal brace) present, running from fibula to talus
- Position: Stable, unchanged from 3-month postoperative X-rays
- Fibular anchor site: Well-incorporated, no lucency or bone resorption
- Talar anchor site: Well-incorporated, no lucency
- No hardware failure, no migration

Alignment:
- Tibiotalar alignment: Neutral (satisfactory)
- Hindfoot alignment: Neutral on mortise and lateral views
- No varus or valgus tilt
- Talar dome position within mortise: Centered
- Compare to immediate post-op: Unchanged, alignment maintained

Bone:
- No avascular necrosis of talus
- No fractures
- Bone density normal
- Anchor sites healed without complication

Joint:
- Tibiotalar joint space preserved (3-4mm, symmetric to contralateral)
- No evidence of post-traumatic arthritis
- No osteophytes
- Cartilage space maintained (excellent - preserved cartilage preoperatively is holding up well)

Soft tissues:
- No significant effusion
- No calcifications or heterotopic ossification
- Soft tissue contours normal

Complications:
- No hardware failure or migration
- No loss of alignment
- No development of arthritis (favorable at 6 months)
- No bone resorption at anchor sites
- No other complications visualized

Radiographic assessment:
At 6 months post-operative, X-rays demonstrate maintained alignment with stable hardware position and excellent preservation of joint space. The suture tape internal brace is in satisfactory position and well-incorporated. Most importantly, there is no evidence of post-traumatic arthritis development, which is favorable (one of the goals of ligament reconstruction is to restore stability to prevent cartilage damage and arthritis development). The bone anchor sites are fully healed without lucency or resorption. Overall radiographic appearance is excellent for this timeframe and supports the clinical finding of successful stabilization.

docs.title: 4. Impression and Recommendation
docs.text:
Format: Summary of recovery quality → Compare to goals → Imaging interpretation → Activity clearance and guidance → Discharge vs follow-up → Long-term monitoring

Template:

Recovery Summary: In summary, [PATIENT] has achieved [excellent / good / satisfactory / suboptimal] functional outcome following [PROCEDURE], now [TIME] post-operatively. [Overall assessment of recovery trajectory and quality].

Goal Achievement: [PATIENT] [has achieved / is achieving / is progressing toward / has not yet achieved] the preoperative goals of [specific goals]. [Comparison to baseline / preoperative status]. [Patient satisfaction level].

Radiographic Assessment: Radiographic assessment demonstrates [solid fusion / excellent healing / stable hardware / preserved joint / other relevant findings]. [Specific positive findings]. [Any concerns or findings requiring monitoring].

Functional Status: Functionally, [PATIENT] [has returned to all desired activities / is working toward return / has residual limitations of SPECIFIC]. [Specific activity clearances or restrictions].

Activity Clearance and Guidance:

I have cleared [PATIENT] for: - [Specific activities with any qualifications or progression guidance] - [Work status - full duties / sport clearance / driving / etc.] - [Any ongoing restrictions if applicable, with duration]

[Specific advice for progression - gradual increase / sport-specific guidance / listen to body / reasonable activity modifications].

Rehabilitation and Home Program: - [Continue / discharge from] formal physiotherapy - [Continue / no longer needed] home exercise program with [specific guidance] - [Maintenance exercises] recommended: [specific exercises and frequency]

Discharge or Continued Follow-up:

If Excellent Progress / Discharge: Given the excellent functional outcome and achievement of all goals, I am discharging [PATIENT] to GP care with an open-door policy. [PATIENT] should return if: - [Specific reasons to return - symptoms worsen / instability recurs / new problems / concerns] - [Routine follow-up in TIMEFRAME if indicated - e.g., annual for arthroplasty, hardware removal consideration]

If Ongoing Monitoring Needed: I will continue to follow [PATIENT] with review in [TIMEFRAME] to: - [Specific goals for next visit] - [Assessment needed / decision pending]

Long-term Considerations and Counseling: - Expected final outcome: [Continue to improve over DURATION / current status likely final outcome] - Risk of [recurrence / progression / adjacent joint issues]: [Specific risk and counseling] - Activity recommendations long-term: [Any modifications or avoidances / no restrictions] - Monitoring: [What to watch for - specific symptoms / when to seek review] - Hardware considerations: [Removal planned/not planned / surveillance needed]

Common phrases: - In summary | Overall - has achieved excellent functional outcome - following [PROCEDURE], now [TIME] post-operatively - has achieved all preoperative goals - is very satisfied with the outcome - Radiographic assessment demonstrates | confirms | shows - solid fusion | excellent healing | stable hardware | preserved joint - Functionally | From a functional standpoint - has returned to | is able to perform | has achieved - I have cleared [PATIENT] for - all activities | return to sport | full duties - no restrictions | avoid [ACTIVITY] for [DURATION] - I am discharging to GP care | discharge with open-door policy - Return if symptoms worsen | concerns arise | new problems - I will continue to follow | review in [TIMEFRAME] - Expected to continue improving | final outcome assessment - Risk of [COMPLICATION] | Monitor for | Watch for - Thank you for allowing me to participate in [PATIENT]'s care

Example:

Impression and Recommendation

In summary, [PATIENT] has achieved an excellent functional outcome following right ankle arthroscopy and lateral ligament reconstruction (Broström-Gould with suture tape augmentation), now 6 months post-operatively. The recovery trajectory has been exemplary with steady progression through rehabilitation milestones and achievement of all functional goals well within the expected timeframe.

[PATIENT] has achieved all preoperative goals: (1) restoration of ankle stability without giving-way episodes - achieved with no episodes of instability in 6 months and excellent stability on examination; (2) return to recreational basketball - achieved, now playing regularly without limitations; (3) hiking on uneven terrain without fear - achieved without issues; and (4) pain-free daily activities - achieved with essentially no pain. Compared to the preoperative status of chronic instability with 2-3 giving-way episodes per week, persistent pain, and inability to participate in any sport, the improvement has been dramatic and life-changing for the patient. [PATIENT] is very satisfied with the surgical outcome.

Radiographic assessment at 6 months demonstrates maintained anatomic alignment with stable hardware position (suture tape internal brace well-incorporated) and, most importantly, preserved tibiotalar joint space without evidence of post-traumatic arthritis. This is an excellent finding, as one of the primary goals of surgical stabilization is to restore stability to prevent ongoing cartilage damage and subsequent arthritis that can occur with recurrent instability. The bone anchor sites are fully healed. Overall radiographic appearance supports the clinical finding of successful stabilization and is very favorable for long-term outcome.

Functionally, [PATIENT] has returned to all desired activities without restriction. Range of motion is 96% of the contralateral ankle (slight restriction is common and expected after ligament reconstruction due to intentional ligamentous tightening for stability). Strength has fully recovered to 5/5 in all muscle groups including the peroneals, which had been weak preoperatively. Proprioception has fully recovered with excellent single-leg stance performance. Most importantly, stability has been completely restored with negative stress tests and subjective confidence in the ankle across all activities including high-demand sport.

I have cleared [PATIENT] for:
- All activities including recreational basketball, hiking, and any other desired sports - no restrictions on activity level
- Full return to work without modifications (already achieved)
- No restrictions on footwear, though supportive athletic shoes recommended for high-impact activities (standard recommendation, not a restriction due to surgery)
- Gradual progression over the next 2-3 months to build sport-specific endurance and confidence, but from a healing and stability standpoint, the ankle is ready for all activities

Rehabilitation and home program:
- Formal physiotherapy has been completed and [PATIENT] discharged from physical therapy
- Home exercise program can be transitioned to maintenance level: Continue balance board exercises 2-3 times per week for proprioception maintenance (especially important for cutting/pivoting sports like basketball to reduce risk of any recurrent injury). This can be integrated into warm-up routine for sports.
- No other specific exercises required; general fitness and sport-specific training sufficient at this point

Given the excellent functional outcome, achievement of all goals, and complete resolution of the preoperative instability problem, I am discharging [PATIENT] to GP care with an open-door policy. [PATIENT] should return to see me if:
- Symptoms worsen: return of instability, giving-way episodes, persistent pain
- Trauma: new significant ankle injury requiring assessment
- Concerns: any concerns about the ankle or surgical outcome
- Routine follow-up is not required unless any of the above issues develop

Long-term considerations and counseling:

Expected final outcome: [PATIENT] is essentially at the final outcome now at 6 months. May continue to see very minor improvements in ROM and any residual stiffness over the next 6 months (up to 12 months post-op for absolute final outcome), but current status is excellent and represents successful surgery.

Risk of recurrent instability: The recurrence rate after Broström-Gould with suture tape augmentation is low (approximately 5% in the literature). The excellent stability on examination, good surgical tissue quality noted intraoperatively, use of augmentation for additional security, and patient's excellent compliance with rehabilitation all suggest a low personal risk of recurrence. That said, [PATIENT] has been counseled about the signs of recurrent instability (return of giving-way, sense of looseness) and knows to return if this develops. To minimize risk: continue proprioception exercises as part of warm-up routine, wear appropriate supportive footwear for sport, and use ankle brace for very high-risk activities if desired (though not required).

Risk of post-traumatic arthritis: The surgery was performed in part to prevent development of arthritis by restoring stability (unstable ankles are at high risk of progressive cartilage damage). The 6-month X-rays show preserved joint space which is very favorable. Long-term, there remains some risk of arthritis development over years/decades (any injury to the ankle increases lifetime arthritis risk), but this surgery significantly reduces that risk by restoring normal biomechanics. No routine X-ray surveillance is needed unless symptoms develop.

Activity recommendations long-term: No specific restrictions. [PATIENT] can participate in any desired activities. Basketball and other cutting/pivoting sports are allowed. Should wear appropriate supportive athletic shoes for high-impact sports (good practice regardless). May use prophylactic ankle brace for basketball if desired for psychological comfort, though not required from a medical standpoint given the excellent stability. Should continue to maintain good overall lower extremity strength and flexibility as part of injury prevention.

Hardware considerations: The suture tape augmentation does not require removal and will remain in situ permanently. It is well-incorporated and not causing any symptoms. No planned hardware removal. If [PATIENT] were to develop pain or prominence over the hardware sites in the future (uncommon), could consider removal at that time, but currently no indication.

What to monitor for / When to return:
- Watch for return of instability symptoms (giving-way, sense of looseness) - if occurs, return for assessment promptly
- Watch for development of persistent ankle pain, swelling, or stiffness that doesn't resolve - could indicate arthritis development or other issue - return for assessment and X-rays
- If sustains significant new ankle injury (trauma), seek assessment to ensure no new damage to ligaments or other structures
- Otherwise, no routine follow-up needed - discharged with open-door policy

Thank you for allowing me to participate in [PATIENT]'s care. It has been a pleasure to achieve such an excellent outcome. Please do not hesitate to contact me if any concerns arise in the future.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. [YOUR NAME]
Orthopaedic Surgeon

Main Paragraph

[PATIENT] returns 6 months following right ankle arthroscopy and lateral ligament reconstruction.
