docs.title: Letter Structure
docs.text:
This template follows the standard outpatient letter format: Diagnosis → Plan → Main paragraph → Impression and recommendation.

For follow-up visits with test results, emphasize imaging interpretation, progress assessment, and decision-point branching.

docs.title: 1. Diagnosis
docs.text:
Format: Diagnosis + interval status (improved/unchanged/worsened) + imaging confirmation

Template: - [Primary diagnosis] ([acute/chronic], [left/right/bilateral]) - [Interval status description] - [Imaging findings if key to diagnosis]

Common descriptors: - improved | unchanged | worsened - partial response to conservative management - confirmed on [imaging modality] - grade / stage [severity]

Example:

Diagnosis
- Chronic bilateral plantar fasciitis (L>R), confirmed on MRI
- Partial response to conservative management over 3 months
- MRI demonstrates grade 2 plantar fasciosis with no complete tear

docs.title: 2. Plan
docs.text:
Format: Progress assessment → Treatment modification → Decision-point branching → Follow-up

Template:

Progress Assessment: - Overall response to conservative management: [good / partial / poor] - Symptom trajectory: [improving / stable / worsening] - Functional status: [improved from baseline / unchanged / declined]

Treatment Modification: - Continue current effective measures: [list] - Modify or intensify: [add new modality / increase frequency / adjust orthotic] - Discontinue ineffective: [treatments that haven't helped] - Trial period: [DURATION] to assess response

Decision-Point Branching:

If improved over next [DURATION]: - Continue conservative measures - Wean from support [specify how] - Gradually increase activities - Plan for discharge or PRN follow-up

If no improvement or worsening: - Consider [injection / surgical consultation / alternative diagnosis] - Additional investigations if indicated: [specify] - Reassess diagnosis and contributing factors

Follow-up: - Review in [TIMEFRAME: 3 months / 6 weeks / PRN] - Goals: [assess progress / determine if further intervention needed / decide on next steps] - Earlier review if: [symptoms worsen / new concerns / red flags]

Common phrases: - Continue | Modify | Intensify | Add - If improved → wean support, return PRN - If no improvement → consider [next step] - If deterioration → urgent review, reassess diagnosis - Review in [TIMEFRAME] to [GOAL]

Example:

Plan
- Imaging results reviewed: MRI confirms grade 2 plantar fasciosis with thickening and intermediate signal but no complete tear

- Treatment modification:
  - Continue physiotherapy with focus on eccentric loading exercises
  - Add night splints for sustained stretch
  - Consider PRP injection if no further improvement in 6 weeks
  - Continue activity modification and heel cups

- Decision points:
  - If symptoms resolve or significantly improve → wean from night splints, gradual return to full activity, discharge to GP care PRN
  - If minimal or no improvement after 6 weeks with intensified conservative management → offer PRP injection or discuss surgical options (plantar fascia release)
  - If symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop → earlier review to reassess diagnosis

- Follow-up: Review in 2 months to assess response. If planning injection, schedule at that visit.

docs.title: 3. Main Paragraph
docs.text:
Format: Opening → Interval history → Treatment adherence → Current status → Examination (comparative) → Imaging review and interpretation

Template:

Opening: [PATIENT] returns today for review, [DURATION] since last consultation.

Interval History: Since last visit, symptoms are [improved / unchanged / worsened]. [Specific symptom changes - pain level, functional capacity, frequency of episodes]. Pain is now [description with comparison to baseline]. Functional status: [specific improvements or limitations - walking distance, stairs, work capacity].

Treatment Adherence: [PATIENT] has been [compliant / partially compliant / non-compliant] with recommended treatment plan. Specifically: - Physiotherapy: [completed / ongoing sessions / poor adherence] - [response if applicable] - Orthotics: [wearing as prescribed / not tolerated / inconsistent use] - Medication: [taking as directed / side effects / stopped] - Activity modification: [following advice / difficulties with restrictions]

Current Status: Currently, [PATIENT] reports [current symptom level and functional capacity]. [Main persisting problems]. [Positive changes if any].

Examination (Comparative to Baseline): On examination, gait is [improved / unchanged / worse compared to baseline]. Swelling is [resolved / reduced / persistent / increased]. Tenderness over [LOCATION] is [markedly reduced / slightly reduced / unchanged / increased]. Range of motion: [measurements with comparison to baseline - improved / maintained / declined]. [Specific tests]: [results with comparison]. Neurovascular status remains intact.

Imaging Review and Clinical Correlation:

[X-ray / MRI / CT / Ultrasound] findings ([DATE]):

X-ray: - Findings: [detailed description] - Joint spaces: [preserved / narrowed / measurements] - Arthritis grade: [Kellgren-Lawrence if applicable] - Alignment: [measurements, comparison to previous if available] - Bone integrity: [fracture / stress reaction / normal] - Progression or new findings: [compare to prior imaging]

MRI (if obtained): - [Primary structure of interest]: [normal / partial tear (grade, %) / complete tear / degeneration (grade)] - Bone marrow edema: [absent / present at LOCATION - clinical significance] - Cartilage: [intact / Outerbridge grade / defect size in mm] - Fluid/synovitis: [absent / mild / moderate / severe] - Additional findings: [bursitis / cysts / impingement / other pathology]

Ultrasound (if obtained): - [Tendon/structure]: [thickness in mm / tear / synovial thickening] - Doppler: [normal / increased vascularity indicating active inflammation] - Dynamic assessment: [subluxation / impingement / stability]

Clinical-Radiological Correlation: Imaging findings of [KEY FINDINGS] correlate with clinical presentation of [SYMPTOMS]. This [confirms diagnosis / reveals unexpected pathology / shows progression / demonstrates improvement]. The [specific finding] explains [specific symptom]. Findings support [conservative / surgical] management approach.

Common phrases: - returns for review | [DURATION] since last visit - symptoms are improved / unchanged / worsened - pain has reduced from [baseline] to [current] - functional capacity has improved | walking distance increased - has been compliant with | adhering to | difficulty with - completed [NUMBER] sessions of physiotherapy - On examination compared to baseline - swelling has resolved / reduced / persists - range of motion has improved by [degrees] - Imaging demonstrates | shows | confirms - correlates with clinical presentation - supports the diagnosis of

Example:

Main Paragraph

[PATIENT] returns today for review, 3 months since initial consultation for bilateral heel pain.

Since last visit, symptoms have moderately improved. Pain intensity has reduced from 8/10 at worst (first steps in morning) to 5/10. Walking tolerance has increased from 500 meters to approximately 1 kilometer before onset of significant pain. Stairs remain somewhat difficult but are manageable with handrail support. Night pain has resolved. [PATIENT] reports "good days and bad days" with symptoms generally better in the afternoon after the foot "warms up."

[PATIENT] has been compliant with the treatment plan:
- Physiotherapy: Completed 8 sessions with focus on plantar fascia stretching and intrinsic foot strengthening. Continues home exercise program 5 days per week.
- Orthotics: Wearing custom heel cups daily in all footwear with good relief.
- Night splints: Using 4-5 nights per week (occasionally skips due to discomfort).
- Activity modification: Has avoided prolonged standing and reduced running frequency from 4x to 1x per week.
- Medication: Taking ibuprofen 400mg as needed, now only 2-3 times per week (previously daily).

Currently, [PATIENT] describes the heel pain as "significantly better but not resolved." Main persisting problem is first-step pain in the morning, though less severe and shorter duration (5-10 minutes vs 30-60 minutes previously). Able to work full-time in teaching role with some modifications (avoiding excessive standing, wearing supportive shoes, taking seated breaks).

On examination, gait is improved with minimal antalgic component (previously moderately antalgic). No visible swelling. Point tenderness over the plantar fascia insertion is present bilaterally but markedly reduced in intensity compared to baseline (2/10 vs 7/10 on palpation). Range of motion: Ankle dorsiflexion 10 degrees with knee extended (baseline 5 degrees), no longer reproduces severe heel pain. Windlass test remains positive but less painful. Calf flexibility has improved with gastrocnemius stretching protocol. Neurovascular examination intact.

Imaging Review:

MRI both feet (performed [DATE]):

Left foot (more symptomatic):
- Plantar fascia: Thickened to 6.5mm (normal <4mm) with intermediate T1 and increased T2 signal in the proximal plantar fascia, consistent with grade 2 plantar fasciosis. Fibers remain in continuity with no evidence of complete tear. Some peritendinous edema.
- Calcaneal marrow: Mild bone marrow edema at the plantar fascial enthesis, consistent with enthesopathy.
- Other structures: Achilles tendon normal. No stress fracture. No Baxter's nerve entrapment evident (no mass or abnormal signal along course of first branch of lateral plantar nerve). Plantar fat pad preserved.

Right foot (less symptomatic):
- Plantar fascia: Mildly thickened to 5.2mm with subtle signal change, consistent with grade 1 plantar fasciosis.
- Calcaneal marrow: Minimal bone marrow edema.
- Other structures: Unremarkable.

Clinical-Radiological Correlation:
MRI findings of grade 2 plantar fasciosis on the left (more symptomatic side) with associated enthesopathy and bone marrow edema correlate well with the clinical presentation of chronic plantar fasciitis. The degree of inflammation and thickening explains the persistent symptoms despite conservative management. The absence of complete tear is favorable and supports continued conservative approach. The lack of evidence for alternative diagnoses such as Baxter's nerve entrapment, stress fracture, or other pathology supports the primary diagnosis. The imaging findings, combined with partial clinical response to conservative measures over 3 months, suggest that more intensive conservative management (with possible PRP injection if this fails) is reasonable before considering surgical intervention.

docs.title: 4. Impression and Recommendation
docs.text:
Format: Summary of progress → Imaging interpretation recap → Treatment plan with decision branching → Follow-up goal

Template:

Summary of Progress: In summary, [PATIENT] has [DIAGNOSIS] [confirmed on imaging / with progression / stable / improving]. Over [DURATION], there has been [degree of improvement / no significant change / deterioration]. Functional status has [improved / remained limited / declined].

Imaging Interpretation: Imaging confirms [DIAGNOSIS] with [specific findings]. [Grade / severity / extent] of pathology. [Comparison to clinical presentation - correlation / unexpected findings]. [Favorable or concerning features affecting prognosis or treatment].

Treatment Recommendation with Rationale: Given [partial response / no response / progression], I recommend [continuing current management / intensifying conservative treatment / considering more invasive options]. Specifically: [detailed plan].

Rationale: [Why this approach - reasonable trial period / evidence for this treatment / staged approach / patient preference / risk-benefit consideration].

Decision Points Recap: - If improved: [Specific action - wean support, discharge, return to activities] - If unchanged or worse: [Next step - injection, surgery, further investigation]

Follow-up Goal: I will review [PATIENT] in [TIMEFRAME] to [specific goal - reassess response to intensified treatment / determine if injection or surgery needed / finalize management plan]. [Earlier review if - symptoms worsen / concerns arise].

Common phrases: - In summary | Overall - has shown [partial / good / no] response to conservative management - Imaging confirms | demonstrates | shows progression - correlates with | explains | is consistent with - Given the [findings / response / timeframe], I recommend - reasonable to continue | trial period of | staged approach - I will review to [specific goal] - earlier review if symptoms worsen

Example:

Impression and Recommendation

In summary, [PATIENT] has chronic bilateral plantar fasciitis, confirmed on MRI, with partial response to conservative management over 3 months. Functional status has improved significantly (walking tolerance increased from 500m to 1km, reduced analgesic use, able to work with modifications), though symptoms are not fully resolved. The persistent first-step morning pain and ongoing activity limitation indicate the condition has not fully resolved.

MRI confirms the diagnosis of plantar fasciosis (grade 2 on left, grade 1 on right) with associated calcaneal enthesopathy and bone marrow edema on the more symptomatic left side. The degree of inflammation and structural change correlates well with the prolonged symptom duration and partial response to treatment. Importantly, there is no complete tear, which is favorable for continued conservative management. The absence of alternative pathology (Baxter's nerve entrapment, stress fracture, other causes of heel pain) supports focusing treatment on the plantar fascia.

Given the partial but meaningful improvement over 3 months, and the relatively short timeframe since initiating intensive physiotherapy and orthotics (full benefit may take 6-12 months), I recommend continuing and intensifying the current conservative approach before considering more invasive options:

1. Continue physiotherapy with focus on eccentric loading exercises and intrinsic foot strengthening - evidence supports 6-12 month trial
2. Add night splints consistently (every night if tolerable) for sustained stretch - may improve morning symptoms
3. Continue heel cups and activity modification
4. Consider extracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT) if available - moderate evidence for chronic plantar fasciitis
5. Trial period: 6-8 weeks with above intensified regimen

Decision points:
- **If symptoms continue to improve or resolve** over the next 6-8 weeks: Gradually wean from night splints, progressive return to full activities including increased running, discharge to GP care with open-door policy for return if needed.

- **If minimal or no further improvement** after 6-8 weeks of intensified conservative management: Consider PRP (platelet-rich plasma) injection. Evidence is mixed but may provide benefit in refractory cases. Alternative: corticosteroid injection (though concerns about plantar fascia rupture limit enthusiasm for this option). Discuss risks and benefits at that time.

- **If symptoms significantly worsen** or new concerning symptoms develop (severe sudden pain suggesting rupture, progressive neurological symptoms, signs of systemic disease): Earlier review to reassess diagnosis and management.

I will review [PATIENT] in 2 months to assess response to this intensified conservative regimen and determine whether injection therapy or, as a last resort, surgical intervention (plantar fascia release) is warranted. The goal is to achieve adequate symptom control to allow return to desired activity level without need for surgery, as surgical outcomes are variable and recovery is prolonged.

Thank you for allowing me to participate in [PATIENT]'s care.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. [YOUR NAME]
Orthopaedic Surgeon

docs.title: New Referral
docs.text: First-time consultations for patients referred to the foot and ankle service. The approach differs based on whether surgical intervention is being considered.

docs.title: A. Diagnostic Testing + Non-Surgical Treatment
docs.text:
For patients requiring: - Investigation to confirm diagnosis - Conservative management trial - Baseline assessment before deciding treatment escalation

Key Goals: - Establish working diagnosis - Order appropriate investigations - Initiate conservative treatment - Plan review timeline with clear decision points

docs.title: B. Surgical Treatment
docs.text:
For patients where: - Diagnosis is established - Conservative treatment has failed or is inappropriate - Surgical intervention is being offered

Key Goals: - Confirm surgical indication - Discuss risks, benefits, and recovery - Obtain informed consent - Plan perioperative pathway

docs.title: Letter Structure
docs.text: This template follows the standard outpatient letter format: Diagnosis → Plan → Main paragraph → Impression and recommendation.

docs.title: 1. Diagnosis
docs.text:
Format: List diagnoses concisely at the top. Include working diagnosis and key differentials.

Template: - [Primary diagnosis] ([acute/chronic], [left/right/bilateral]) - [Secondary diagnosis or key differential]

Common descriptors: - chronic | acute | subacute | recurrent - refractory to conservative management - secondary to [CAUSE]

Example:

Diagnosis
- Chronic bilateral plantar fasciitis (L>R), refractory to standard conservative management
- Differential diagnosis for medial heel pain includes Baxter's nerve entrapment

docs.title: 2. Plan
docs.text:
Format: Investigations → Conservative management → Follow-up → If-Then branching

Template:

Investigations: - [X-ray / MRI / CT / Ultrasound] [LOCATION] - Purpose: to assess [bone stock / ligament integrity / tendon pathology / confirm diagnosis] - Expected timeframe for completion: [~4-6 weeks]

Conservative Management (trial for [DURATION]): - Physiotherapy: [specific focus - strengthening, stretching, proprioception] - Orthotics: [heel cups, insoles, AFO, night splints] - Medication: [NSAIDs / simple analgesia] as needed - Activity modification: [specific advice - offloading, avoid high-impact] - Immobilization: [CAM boot / splint] if indicated

Follow-up: - Review in [~3 months / ~6 weeks / after investigations complete] - Goals: reassess symptoms, review imaging, determine next steps

Decision Points: - If improved: Continue conservative measures, wean support, return PRN - If no improvement: Consider [injection / surgical consultation / further imaging] - If deterioration: Urgent review, modify treatment, reassess diagnosis

Common phrases: - to assess | to evaluate | to confirm | to rule out - for [DURATION: 3 months / 6 weeks / until next review] - If symptoms persist → consider [next step] - If improvement → continue conservative | wean from support

Example:

Plan
- Follow up in my clinic after investigations are complete (approx. 4 months).
- Advised to continue physiotherapy, shockwave therapy, heel cups, and night splints for 4 months while awaiting investigations.
- Investigations: MRI both feet (purpose: confirm plantar fascia pathology; assess for alternative causes of medial heel pain)
- If symptoms persist despite conservative measures → consider PRP injection or surgical release
- If improved → wean support and return PRN

docs.title: 3. Main Paragraph
docs.text:
Format: Opening → Chief complaint (functional) → Onset and course → Prior management → Examination → Imaging

Template:

Opening: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for assessment of [PROBLEM/REGION].

Chief Complaint (functional focus): [PATIENT] reports [FUNCTIONAL LIMITATION], which began [TIMEFRAME] ago [following INJURY / with insidious onset]. The main limitation is [SPECIFIC FUNCTIONAL IMPACT - walking distance / stairs / work activity].

Course and characteristics: Symptoms are [progressive / stable / intermittent], [aggravated by ACTIVITY] and [relieved by REST/MEDICATION]. Pain is described as [sharp / dull / aching / burning], located over the [ANATOMICAL LOCATION].

Prior Management: Prior management has included [PHYSIOTHERAPY / ORTHOTICS / NSAIDs / INJECTIONS / IMMOBILIZATION] for [DURATION], with [good / partial / minimal / no] relief.

Examination: On examination, gait is [antalgic / normal]. There is [swelling over LOCATION / no swelling]. Tenderness is present over [SPECIFIC ANATOMICAL STRUCTURES]. Range of motion is [full / limited] with pain at [end range / throughout]. [TEST NAME] is [positive / negative]. Neurovascular status is intact distally. Alignment is [neutral / varus / valgus].

Imaging: [Radiographs / MRI / CT / Ultrasound] demonstrate [KEY FINDINGS]. [Specific findings: joint space narrowing / osteophytes / tendon tear / bone marrow edema].

Common phrases: - It was a pleasure to see | Thank you for referring - reports difficulty with | is unable to | experiences pain when - walking distance limited to [DISTANCE] - began [TIMEFRAME] ago | following [INJURY] - has tried | has undergone | has completed - with good / partial / minimal / no relief - On examination | Inspection reveals | Palpation demonstrates - tenderness over | swelling is present | range of motion is limited - Radiographs demonstrate | MRI shows | CT reveals

Example:

Main Paragraph

It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for assessment of bilateral foot pain. [PATIENT] presents with a 2-3 year history of bilateral foot pain, worse on the left. The pain is most severe with the first steps in the morning and after periods of rest. Walking tolerance is limited to approximately 500 meters before symptoms worsen. Stairs are difficult due to heel pain.

Symptoms have been refractory to conservative treatments, including physiotherapy exercises for 6 months, hot and cold compresses, two steroid injections (providing only brief relief of 2-3 weeks), shockwave therapy, and night splints.

On examination, gait is antalgic with shortened stance phase on the left. There is point tenderness over the plantar fascia insertion bilaterally (left > right). Range of motion of the ankle is full, but dorsiflexion reproduces plantar heel pain. There is mild heel varus alignment bilaterally. Neurovascular examination is intact. Windlass test is positive bilaterally.

Radiographs demonstrate a small calcaneal spur at the plantar fascia insertion, more prominent on the left. Joint spaces are preserved. There is no evidence of fracture or significant arthritis.

docs.title: 4. Impression and Recommendation
docs.text:
Format: Summary diagnosis → Differential → Recommendation → Follow-up goal

Template:

Summary: In summary, [PATIENT]'s presentation is consistent with [DIAGNOSIS]. The key diagnostic features include [SUPPORTING FEATURES].

Differential: The key differential diagnoses include [DDX 1] and [DDX 2]. [Alternative diagnoses that need to be considered or ruled out].

Recommendation: I recommend [CONSERVATIVE MANAGEMENT / FURTHER INVESTIGATION / SURGICAL CONSULTATION] as outlined above. [Specific rationale for the chosen approach].

Follow-up goal: I will review [PATIENT] in [FOLLOW-UP TIMEFRAME] to [GOAL: review imaging results / reassess symptoms / finalize management plan / determine if further intervention is warranted].

Common phrases: - In summary | Overall | In conclusion - the presentation is consistent with | most likely represents - diagnostic features include - The key differential diagnoses include - Other considerations are | We need to exclude - I recommend | The plan is to | We will proceed with - to reassess | to review progress | to finalize the plan - to discuss surgical options | to ensure adequate healing

Example:

Impression and Recommendation

In summary, [PATIENT]'s presentation is consistent with chronic bilateral plantar fasciitis, more severe on the left, refractory to standard conservative management. The key diagnostic features include characteristic morning pain, plantar fascia tenderness, positive windlass test, and radiographic evidence of calcaneal spurring. The prolonged duration and failure of multiple conservative measures support the diagnosis.

The differential diagnosis for the medial heel pain includes Baxter's nerve entrapment (first branch of lateral plantar nerve), which can present with similar symptoms but may have associated numbness or dysesthesia. Other considerations include calcaneal stress fracture (ruled out on X-ray), plantar fascia rupture (no acute event, examination findings not consistent), and referred pain from lumbar radiculopathy (no back symptoms or neurological findings).

I recommend completion of the requested MRI to confirm plantar fascia pathology and assess for alternative causes of medial heel pain. In the interim, I recommend continuation of conservative measures including physiotherapy, shockwave therapy, heel cups, and night splints. If symptoms persist despite these measures and imaging confirms the diagnosis, we will consider more invasive options including PRP injection or surgical release (plantar fascia release).

I will review [PATIENT] after investigations are complete (approximately 4 months) to finalize management based on findings and clinical response. If symptoms significantly worsen before then, [PATIENT] should return for earlier review.

This is the [bone / joint / alignment]. - This bright area on the MRI shows [inflammation / fluid / tendon problem]. - The CT scan gives us a detailed view of the bone and shows [fracture / arthritis / bone quality].

docs.title: Diagnostic Explanation
docs.text:
• Based on what you've told me and what I found on examination, I believe you have [DIAGNOSIS].
  • Essentially, this means [SIMPLE EXPLANATION IN PLAIN LANGUAGE].

Example Explanations: - Plantar fasciitis: This is inflammation of the thick band of tissue on the bottom of your foot. It's a common cause of heel pain. - Achilles tendinopathy: This is a problem with the tendon at the back of your heel. It can become painful and swollen, often due to overuse. - Ankle instability: The ligaments that hold your ankle stable have been stretched or damaged, which can cause the ankle to feel unstable.

docs.text: • There are a few possibilities we need to consider. The most likely is [DIAGNOSIS], but we should also rule out [ALTERNATIVE].

docs.text: • If things get suddenly worse, or if you notice [increasing numbness, spreading redness, severe pain], please don't wait—call us right away.

docs.text:
This template follows the standard outpatient letter format: Diagnosis → Plan → Main paragraph → Impression and recommendation.

For surgical cases, the Plan section emphasizes informed consent (IC) elements: risks, benefits, natural history, and recovery timeline.

docs.title: 1. Diagnosis
docs.text:
Format: List confirmed diagnosis requiring surgical intervention. Include relevant severity/stage.

Template: - [Primary diagnosis requiring surgical intervention] - [Contributing factors or concurrent pathology]

Common descriptors: - refractory to conservative management - failed conservative management (minimum [DURATION] trial) - mechanical instability | structural deformity | end-stage arthritis - stage II / III / IV

Example:

Diagnosis
- Right ankle lateral ligament and anteromedial ligament complex laxity
- Failed 6 months conservative management with persistent mechanical instability

docs.title: 2. Plan
docs.text:
Format: Procedure → IC (benefits, risks, natural history) → Recovery → Next steps

Template:

Planned Procedure: - Plan: [SPECIFIC PROCEDURE] - Alternatives discussed: [non-operative care / alternative procedures]

Informed Consent - Benefits: - [improved stability / pain relief / functional improvement / deformity correction] - [return to activities / improved quality of life]

Informed Consent - Risks: - Infection (2-5%) - Nerve injury ([specific nerve], possible numbness or neuropraxia) - Vascular injury - Stiffness or reduced range of motion - Recurrence ([% if known]) - DVT/PE - Hardware complications (if applicable: loosening, irritation, need for removal) - Nonunion / malunion (for osteotomies/fusions) - Incomplete pain relief - Anaesthetic risks

Natural History (if not treated): - Risk of progression - Increased risk of [recurrent injury / arthritis / functional decline] - May lead to [specific long-term consequences]

Postoperative Recovery: - Weight-bearing status: [NWB / PWB / WBAT] for [DURATION: ~6 weeks] - Immobilization: [Cast / Boot / Splint] for [DURATION] - Physiotherapy: commence at [TIMEFRAME], focus on [ROM / strengthening / proprioception] - Expected recovery timeline: [3-6 months / variable] - Return to work: [DURATION - depends on occupation] - Return to sport: [TIMEFRAME]

Next Steps: - Provide consent forms - Preoperative investigations: [imaging / medical clearance / blood work] - Schedule surgery at [HOSPITAL/LOCATION] - Arrange [physiotherapy / equipment / time off work]

Patient Understanding: Patient understands diagnosis, surgical indication, alternatives, risks and benefits, and recovery expectations. [Patient willing to proceed / will consider and contact office / schedule after DATE].

Common phrases: - Benefits: improved stability, pain relief, functional improvement, deformity correction - Risks: infection, nerve injury, stiffness, recurrence, DVT/PE, anaesthetic risks - Natural history: untreated [condition] increases risk of [consequence] - Postoperative recovery: [NWB/PWB] for [~6 weeks], then commence physiotherapy - Expected recovery [~3–6 months] (variable)

Example:

Plan
- Plan: Right ankle arthroscopy and lateral and medial ligament stabilisation (Broström-Gould procedure)

- IC (Benefits):
  - Improved ankle stability and reduced giving-way episodes
  - Symptom reduction and functional improvement
  - Return to desired activity level

- IC (Risks):
  - Nerve injury (superficial peroneal nerve proximity; temporary neuropraxia possible; permanent sensory change possible)
  - Infection (2-5%)
  - Stiffness or reduced ankle range of motion
  - Recurrent instability (5-10%)
  - DVT/PE
  - Sural nerve injury causing numbness lateral foot
  - Incomplete pain relief
  - Anaesthetic risks

- Natural history:
  - Untreated instability increases risk of recurrent episodes
  - May increase risk of osteochondral damage and long-term post-traumatic arthritis
  - Progressive functional limitation

- Postoperative recovery:
  - Weight-bearing in a CAM boot for ~6 weeks, then commence physiotherapy
  - Expected recovery ~3–6 months (variable)
  - Return to sport 4-6 months
  - May need to avoid high-risk pivoting activities long-term

- Next steps:
  - Consent forms provided
  - Pre-operative X-rays reviewed, no additional imaging needed
  - Schedule surgery (patient to contact office to arrange timing)
  - Arrange physiotherapy referral for post-operative rehabilitation

docs.title: 3. Main Paragraph
docs.text:
Format: Opening → Confirm prior conservative management → Current symptoms and goals → Examination (confirm surgical indication) → Imaging review

Template:

Opening: It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for [review of persistent symptoms / surgical consultation regarding [PROBLEM]].

Prior Conservative Management: [PATIENT] has [DURATION] history of [PROBLEM]. Prior management has included [comprehensive list of conservative treatments tried with duration and response]. Overall conservative trial: [TOTAL DURATION] with [insufficient response / continued symptoms / progressive functional limitation].

Current Symptoms and Patient Goals: [PATIENT] currently reports [SYMPTOMS] causing [FUNCTIONAL LIMITATION]. [PATIENT]'s primary goals are [SPECIFIC GOALS - return to sport / pain-free walking / ability to work]. [PATIENT] [wishes to proceed with operative management / is considering surgical options after failed conservative treatment].

Examination (confirming surgical indication): On examination, gait is [antalgic / unstable / normal]. There is [KEY PHYSICAL FINDINGS that support surgical indication]. [SPECIFIC TESTS demonstrating pathology - e.g., positive anterior drawer, severe laxity, fixed deformity, restricted ROM]. Neurovascular status is intact. [Other relevant findings].

Imaging Review: Investigations reviewed include [X-ray / MRI / CT].

X-ray findings: - [Primary pathology: arthritis / deformity / fracture malunion] - Alignment: [measurements - angles, joint space] - Bone quality: [adequate / osteoporotic] - [Specific findings supporting operative intervention]

MRI findings (if applicable): - [Structure]: [complete tear / severe degeneration / grade of pathology] - Extent: [quantify - e.g., >50% tendon involvement] - Adjacent structures: [intact / involved] - Findings support diagnosis and guide procedure selection

CT findings (if applicable): - Bone detail: [3D deformity assessment / preoperative planning details]

Imaging confirms [DIAGNOSIS] with [specific findings] supporting surgical intervention.

Common phrases: - has tried | has undergone | has completed - for [DURATION] with [insufficient response / minimal relief / no sustained benefit] - Overall conservative trial: [TOTAL DURATION] - wishes to proceed with | is considering | after discussion of risks and benefits - On examination | Stress testing demonstrates | Range of motion is - severe laxity | fixed deformity | end-stage arthritis | mechanical instability - Imaging confirms | demonstrates | supports

Example:

Main Paragraph

It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for review of persistent ankle symptoms and surgical consultation. [PATIENT] reports ankle pain and instability with recurrent giving-way episodes for the past 18 months, following an inversion injury sustained while playing basketball in March 2024. The ankle "gives way" 2-3 times per week, particularly on uneven ground, causing significant functional limitation and inability to return to sport.

Prior management has included:
- Immobilization in CAM boot for 6 weeks (initial treatment)
- Physiotherapy focusing on proprioception and strengthening for 4 months with partial improvement in strength but persistent instability
- Ankle brace worn for high-risk activities with continued episodes
- Activity modification with avoidance of sport for 12 months

Overall conservative trial: 15 months with insufficient response. [PATIENT] wishes to proceed with operative management after consideration of timing and goals. Primary goal is to return to recreational basketball and hiking without fear of ankle giving way.

On examination, foot and ankle alignment is normal with full range of motion of the ankle and subtalar joint. There is severe lateral ligament laxity on stress testing. Anterior drawer test demonstrates 10mm of anterior translation compared to 3mm on the contralateral side (>7mm difference). Talar tilt test shows 15 degrees of tilt compared to 5 degrees contralaterally. There is subjective sense of anterolateral apprehension with stress. No medial tenderness or instability. Neurovascular examination is intact.

Investigations reviewed:
- Ankle MRI demonstrates a severely attenuated and lax ATFL with complete discontinuity. The CFL is also attenuated and lax. The deltoid ligament is intact but shows some laxity on the deep component. Cartilage surfaces are intact with no osteochondral defect. No significant bone marrow edema. Small amount of joint effusion consistent with chronic synovitis.
- Weight-bearing X-rays show no evidence of arthritis, normal joint space, and good alignment. No bony abnormalities or loose bodies.

Imaging confirms chronic lateral ligament insufficiency with mechanical laxity appropriate for surgical stabilization. Preserved cartilage is favorable for good outcome.

docs.title: 4. Impression and Recommendation
docs.text:
Format: Summary with surgical indication → Confirmation patient suitable → IC discussion recap → Proceed with plan

Template:

Summary: In summary, [PATIENT] has [DIAGNOSIS] with [clear surgical indication based on: failed conservative management / mechanical pathology / functional limitation / progressive disease].

Surgical Suitability: [PATIENT] is suitable for surgical intervention. [Any relevant factors: medical clearance obtained / no contraindications / appropriate expectations / motivated for rehabilitation].

IC Recap: I have discussed the procedure ([SPECIFIC PROCEDURE]) and the specific risks, including [KEY RISKS specific to procedure], as well as the expected recovery pathway and realistic functional goals.

Plan Forward: We will proceed with [PROCEDURE] as outlined. [Next specific steps: scheduling / preoperative workup / timing considerations].

Alternative if patient considering: [PATIENT] would like time to consider the surgical option. We will reassess in [TIMEFRAME] or [PATIENT] will contact the office when ready to proceed.

Common phrases: - has [failed conservative management / mechanical instability / end-stage arthritis] - is suitable for surgical intervention - appropriate candidate for | would benefit from - I have discussed the procedure and risks - including [specific risks relevant to the procedure] - expected recovery pathway | realistic functional goals - We will proceed with | plan to organize | schedule surgery - will contact the office when ready to proceed

Example:

Impression and Recommendation

In summary, [PATIENT] has chronic lateral ankle instability with mechanical laxity, documented both clinically and radiologically. [PATIENT] has failed appropriate conservative management over 15 months including prolonged physiotherapy and bracing, and continues to have recurrent giving-way episodes significantly impacting quality of life and preventing return to desired activities. This represents clear indication for surgical stabilization.

[PATIENT] is an appropriate candidate for surgical intervention: medically fit, non-smoker, motivated for rehabilitation, and has realistic expectations regarding recovery timeline and outcomes. The intact cartilage on MRI is favorable for good long-term outcome.

I believe [PATIENT] would benefit from ankle arthroscopy (to assess and treat any intra-articular pathology such as synovitis or loose bodies) and lateral ligament reconstruction (Broström-Gould procedure, with possible internal brace augmentation depending on intraoperative tissue quality). I have discussed the procedure and the specific risks, including nerve injury (particularly superficial peroneal nerve, with possible temporary neuropraxia or permanent sensory change in 5-10% of cases), recurrent instability (5-10% failure rate requiring revision), infection (2-5%), stiffness, and thromboembolic complications, as well as the expected recovery pathway (6 weeks protected weight-bearing in boot, then 3-6 months progressive rehabilitation before return to sport).

We will proceed with organizing surgery and postoperative rehabilitation as outlined. [PATIENT] will contact the office to arrange surgical scheduling to coordinate with work commitments (aiming for [TIMEFRAME/SEASON]). Preoperative clearance and consent forms will be arranged at that time.

Thank you again for this referral.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. [YOUR NAME]
Orthopaedic Surgeon

docs.title: Complete Letter Example
docs.text:
[CLINIC LETTERHEAD]
[DATE]

Dr. [REFERRING DOCTOR]
[ADDRESS]

Re: [PATIENT NAME], DOB: [DATE]

Dear Dr. [REFERRING DOCTOR],

Diagnosis
- Right ankle lateral ligament complex insufficiency (ATFL and CFL)
- Failed 15 months conservative management with persistent mechanical instability

Plan
- Plan: Right ankle arthroscopy and lateral ligament reconstruction (Broström-Gould procedure)

- IC (Benefits): improved stability, reduced giving-way episodes, functional improvement, return to sport

- IC (Risks): nerve injury (superficial peroneal nerve), infection (2-5%), stiffness, recurrent instability (5-10%), DVT/PE, incomplete pain relief, anaesthetic risks

- Natural history: untreated instability increases risk of recurrent episodes and may increase risk of cartilage damage and long-term arthritis

- Postoperative recovery: NWB in CAM boot for ~6 weeks, then commence physiotherapy; expected recovery ~3–6 months (variable)

- Next steps: [PATIENT] to contact office to arrange scheduling; consent forms and preoperative clearance to be arranged

Main Paragraph

It was a pleasure to see [PATIENT] today for surgical consultation regarding persistent ankle instability. [PATIENT] reports 18 months of ankle instability with recurrent giving-way episodes 2-3 times per week following initial inversion injury. Prior management has included 6 weeks immobilization, 4 months physiotherapy with proprioception training, and ankle bracing, with overall conservative trial of 15 months. [PATIENT] wishes to proceed with operative management to return to basketball and hiking.

On examination, there is severe lateral ligament laxity. Anterior drawer test demonstrates 10mm anterior translation (vs 3mm contralateral). Talar tilt test shows 15 degrees (vs 5 degrees contralateral). Neurovascular examination is intact.

MRI demonstrates complete ATFL and CFL insufficiency with severe attenuation. Cartilage is intact. X-rays show no arthritis.

Impression and Recommendation

In summary, [PATIENT] has chronic lateral ankle instability with mechanical laxity, failed appropriate conservative management, and clear indication for surgical stabilization. I believe [PATIENT] would benefit from ankle arthroscopy and lateral ligament reconstruction. I have discussed the procedure, risks including nerve injury and recurrent instability, and expected recovery. We will proceed with organizing surgery as outlined.

Thank you again for this referral.

Yours sincerely,

Dr. [YOUR NAME]
Orthopaedic Surgeon

docs.title: New Referral: Surgical Treatment - Patient Communication
Opening
docs.text: • Good morning/afternoon. Thank you for coming in. I understand you've been having problems with your [LOCATION].

docs.title: Confirm Prior Treatment
docs.text:
• I see you've tried [physiotherapy / orthotics / injections]. How did that go?
  • How long did you give it? Did it help at all?
  • What made you decide to seek surgical consultation?

docs.title: Current Symptoms
docs.text:
• How are things now? What's your biggest limitation?
  • What would you most like to be able to do that you can't do now?

docs.title: Patient Goals & Expectations
docs.text:
• What's most important to you right now? Work, sports, daily activities?
  • What are your goals for treatment?
  • Have you had surgery before? How do you feel about the possibility of surgery?

docs.title: Preparation
docs.text: • Let me examine your [LOCATION] to confirm the findings and make sure surgery is the right option for you.

docs.title: Focused Assessment
docs.text:
• (Perform systematic examination)
  • I can confirm [KEY FINDINGS that support surgical indication].

docs.title: Imaging Review
docs.text:
• Let me show you the imaging studies.
  • X-ray: Here you can see [arthritis / deformity / fracture / bone spur / alignment issue].
  • This joint space narrowing indicates wear and tear of the cartilage.
  • The bone spur here is causing impingement and pain.

  • The alignment is off by [DEGREE], which is causing abnormal stress.

  • MRI (if available): This shows us the soft tissue detail.

  • This dark area indicates [tendon tear / ligament injury / cartilage damage].
  • The bright signal here shows inflammation or fluid accumulation.

  • We can see that [structure] is completely torn/severely damaged.

  • CT scan (if available): This gives us 3D bone detail.

  • The fracture pattern is [configuration].
  • The bone quality is [adequate / osteoporotic].
  • This helps us plan the surgical approach and fixation.

Key Finding: - The imaging clearly shows [PRIMARY PATHOLOGY], which is why surgery would be beneficial.

docs.title: Diagnosis Confirmation
docs.text:
• Based on your history, examination, and imaging, you have [DIAGNOSIS].
  • This is causing [FUNCTIONAL IMPACT].

docs.title: Why Surgery
docs.text:
• Given that conservative treatment hasn't provided enough relief, I believe surgery would be the best option for you.
  • Surgery can help by [SPECIFIC BENEFIT: stabilizing, correcting deformity, removing damaged tissue].

docs.title: Surgical Plan
docs.text:
• I recommend [SPECIFIC PROCEDURE].
  • This involves [SIMPLE DESCRIPTION OF WHAT WILL BE DONE].

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• The main benefits are: [improved stability / pain relief / functional improvement / deformity correction].
  • This should allow you to [RETURN TO ACTIVITIES / REDUCE PAIN / IMPROVE QUALITY OF LIFE].

docs.title: Risks
docs.text:
• As with any surgery, there are risks. The main ones include:
  • Infection (though this is uncommon)
  • Nerve injury, which could cause numbness or tingling
  • Stiffness or reduced range of motion
  • Blood clots (DVT/PE)
  • The problem could come back (recurrence)
  • Anaesthetic risks

docs.title: Recovery Timeline
docs.text:
• After surgery, you'll need to [NON-WEIGHT-BEARING / WEIGHT-BEARING IN BOOT] for about [DURATION].
  • You'll be in a [CAST / BOOT / SPLINT] for [DURATION].
  • Physiotherapy will start at [TIMEFRAME] and focus on [GOALS].
  • Full recovery typically takes [TIMEFRAME], though this varies from person to person.
  • You'll need to take [DURATION] off work, depending on your job.

docs.title: What if I Don't Have Surgery?
docs.text: • If we don't treat this, [PROBLEM] may get worse over time, potentially leading to [LONG-TERM CONSEQUENCES].

docs.title: Decision Making
docs.text:
• I'd like you to take some time to think about this. There's no rush—we can discuss it again at your next visit.
  • Do you have any questions? Please feel free to ask about anything.
  • If you decide to proceed, we can schedule the surgery. Just let us know when you're ready.

docs.title: Closing
docs.text:
• Take the time you need to consider this. We can arrange a follow-up discussion at your convenience.
  • Thank you for coming in today.

docs.title: New Referral: Surgical Treatment - Short Presentation
a. History Taking
docs.text:
Format: "[AGE] [SEX] with [DURATION] history of [PROBLEM], failed [CONSERVATIVE TREATMENTS], now considering surgery."

Example: "35F with 18-month history of chronic right ankle instability with recurrent giving way, failed 6 months physiotherapy and bracing, now considering lateral ligament reconstruction."

Key Elements: - Age, sex - Duration and problem - Conservative treatments attempted (with duration) - Indication for surgery

docs.title: b. Examination
docs.text:
Format: "Examination confirms [KEY FINDINGS supporting surgical indication]. Imaging shows [RELEVANT PATHOLOGY]."

Example: "Examination confirms severe laxity on anterior drawer and talar tilt testing. MRI demonstrates complete ATFL and CFL tears with no evidence of osteochondral injury."

Key Elements: - Physical findings supporting surgery - Imaging confirmation - Relevant negative findings (exclude contraindications)

Imaging Summary Format: "[X-ray/MRI/CT] shows [primary pathology supporting surgery], [relevant measurements/grades]."

Imaging Examples: - "X-ray: severe ankle arthritis, joint space obliterated, large osteophytes." - "MRI: complete ATFL and CFL tears, no osteochondral lesion." - "CT: Lisfranc diastasis 5mm, displaced 2nd MT base fracture."

docs.title: c. Impression
docs.text:
Format: "[DIAGNOSIS] with [failed conservative management / surgical indication]."

Example: "Chronic lateral ankle instability with mechanical laxity, failed conservative management, suitable for surgical stabilization."

Key Elements: - Diagnosis - Why surgery is indicated - Confirmation suitable for operative intervention

docs.title: d. Recommendation
docs.text:
Format: "Plan: [PROCEDURE]. Discussed risks ([KEY RISKS]), benefits ([KEY BENEFITS]), recovery ([TIMELINE]). Patient to consider and confirm decision."

Example: "Plan: Right ankle arthroscopy and lateral ligament reconstruction. Discussed risks (infection, nerve injury, recurrence, DVT), benefits (improved stability, reduced giving-way episodes), recovery (6 weeks NWB in boot, 3-6 months full recovery). Patient to consider and confirm decision for surgical scheduling."

Key Elements: - Specific procedure - Key risks discussed - Key benefits - Recovery timeline - Patient decision-making status

docs.title: Complete Presentation Template
docs.text:
"[AGE] [SEX] with [DURATION] [PROBLEM], failed [CONSERVATIVE], now considering [PROCEDURE]. Examination: [KEY FINDINGS]. Imaging: [PATHOLOGY]. Impression: [DIAGNOSIS], surgical indication confirmed. Plan: [PROCEDURE], discussed IC (risks: [KEY RISKS]; benefits: [KEY BENEFITS]; recovery: [TIMELINE]). Patient considering, will confirm for scheduling."

Example:

"48M with 2-year history of progressive hallux valgus with bunion pain, failed wide shoes and orthotics for 12 months, now considering surgical correction. Examination: severe HV deformity, HA angle ~35°, IM angle ~15°, 2nd MTP joint crossover. X-ray: confirms moderate-severe HV with subluxation. Impression: Symptomatic hallux valgus with 2nd MTP instability, suitable for operative correction. Plan: Scarf osteotomy + 2nd MTP stabilization. Discussed IC (risks: infection, recurrence, stiffness; benefits: pain relief, improved shoe fit; recovery: 6 weeks protected weight-bearing, 3 months full recovery). Patient considering, will confirm for scheduling."

docs.title: PATHOLOGY
docs.text: 本セクションでは、足部・足関節の主要な病態について、解剖学的部位別（後足部、中足部、前足部)に整理しています。各病態は頻度順に配列されており、非手術的治療と手術的治療の両方について記載しています。

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This section provides comprehensive information on common foot and ankle pathologies, organized by anatomical region:

  • Hindfoot: Conditions affecting the ankle and heel
  • Midfoot: Conditions affecting the arch and midfoot joints
  • Forefoot: Conditions affecting the toes and metatarsals

For each pathology, both non-surgical and surgical management approaches are covered.

docs.title: Organization
docs.text:
Each pathology is organized by frequency within its anatomical region and includes:

  • Clinical presentation and diagnosis
  • Non-surgical treatment options
  • Surgical indications and techniques
  • Evidence-based management strategies

docs.title: Clinical Application
docs.text:
This resource is designed for:

  • Quick reference during clinical encounters
  • Treatment planning and decision-making
  • Patient education and counseling
  • Preparing for case presentations

docs.title: Forefoot Pathology
docs.text: 前足部の主要な病態について、頻度順に整理しています。

docs.title: Common Conditions (by Frequency)
docs.text:
1. Hallux Valgus - Most common forefoot deformity
  2. Hallux Rigidus - Common degenerative condition
  3. Morton's Neuroma - Frequent cause of forefoot pain
  4. Metatarsalgia - General forefoot pain syndrome

docs.title: Anatomical Considerations
docs.text: The forefoot includes: - First metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint - Lesser MTP joints - Intermetatarsal spaces - Toes

docs.title: Clinical Approach
docs.text: Each pathology in this section covers: - Diagnostic workup - Non-surgical management - Surgical indications and techniques

docs.title: Clinical Presentation
docs.text:
• Pain at 1st MTP joint, especially with dorsiflexion
  • Stiffness and limited range of motion
  • Dorsal prominence ("dorsal bunion")
  • Pain with push-off during gait
  • Difficulty with inclines, stairs
  • Worse with high heels or flexible shoes

docs.title: Grade 0: Dorsiflexion 40-60°, Normal X-ray
docs.text:
• Early symptoms
  • No radiographic changes

docs.title: Grade 1: Dorsiflexion 30-40°
docs.text:
• Mild osteophytes
  • Minimal joint space narrowing
  • Subchondral sclerosis

docs.title: Grade 2: Dorsiflexion 10-30°
docs.text:
• Moderate osteophytes
  • Flattening of metatarsal head

  • 25% joint space narrowing

  • Sesamoid hypertrophy

docs.title: Grade 3: Dorsiflexion <10°
docs.text:
• Severe osteophytes
  • Marked joint space narrowing or loss
  • Cysts, loose bodies
  • May have plantar/lateral cartilage preserved

docs.title: Grade 4: Symptoms as Grade 3 + Pain at Midrange
docs.text:
• Pan-articular arthritis
  • Loss of all cartilage surfaces

docs.title: Etiology
docs.text:
• Idiopathic (most common): Primary osteoarthritis
  • Trauma: Fracture, chronic turf toe injuries
  • Inflammatory arthritis: Gout, RA, seronegative arthropathies
  • Biomechanical: Long 1st metatarsal, pes planus
  • Osteochondral defect
  • Iatrogenic: Post-surgical (overcorrection in bunion surgery)

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
• Range of Motion:
  • Dorsiflexion (normal 60-80°)
  • Plantarflexion (normal 20-30°)

  • Pain at end-range dorsiflexion

  • Dorsal Osteophytes: Palpable prominence

  • Grind Test: Axial compression with rotation → pain
  • Pain Pattern:
  • End-range dorsiflexion pain (Grades 1-3)

  • Midrange pain (Grade 4)

  • Gait: Antalgic, decreased push-off

  • Shoe Wear: Look for wear pattern (lateral shift)

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• Weight-bearing AP and Lateral Foot X-rays
  • Lateral View (most important):
  • Dorsal osteophytes
  • Joint space narrowing
  • Metatarsal head flattening

  • Subchondral cysts

  • Oblique View: Assess medial/lateral joint surfaces

  • Sesamoid View: Hypertrophy, arthritis

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Grades 0-2 (primary treatment)
  • Grade 3 (may provide relief, but surgery often needed)
  • Grade 4 (limited benefit)
  • Low-demand patients
  • Medical comorbidities precluding surgery

docs.title: Treatment Goals
docs.text:
• Reduce pain
  • Maintain or improve function
  • Slow progression (uncertain)

docs.title: 1. Footwear Modification (Most Effective)
docs.text:
• Stiff-soled shoes: Limit MTP dorsiflexion
  • Athletic shoes with firm sole
  • Hiking boots

  • Stiff dress shoes

  • Rocker-bottom sole: Facilitates roll-through without MTP motion

  • Can be added to existing shoes

  • Carbon fiber inserts: Rigidify shoe sole

  • Low heel height: Reduce dorsiflexion demand

  • Wide toe box: Accommodate dorsal prominence

Avoid: - Flexible sneakers - High heels - Thin-soled shoes

docs.title: 2. Orthotic Management
docs.text:
• Morton's extension: Rigid plate under 1st ray
  • Dancer's pad: Offload 1st MTP joint
  • Custom orthotics: May help if biomechanical factors
  • Accommodative padding: Over dorsal prominence

docs.title: 3. Activity Modification
docs.text:
• Avoid activities requiring extreme dorsiflexion
  • Modify sports participation (running → cycling/swimming)
  • Use appropriate footwear for activities

docs.title: 4. Pharmacological Management
docs.text:
• NSAIDs: Oral or topical
  • Acetaminophen
  • Topical analgesics

docs.title: 5. Injection Therapy
docs.text:
• Corticosteroid Injection:
  • Temporary relief (3-6 months)
  • Can repeat 2-3 times

  • Risk: Accelerate cartilage degeneration

  • Hyaluronic Acid (Visco-supplementation):

  • Mixed evidence

  • May provide relief in early stages

  • Technique: Inject dorsally or medially, avoid plantar (sesamoids)

docs.title: 6. Physical Therapy
docs.text:
• Range of Motion: Maintain mobility
  • Strengthening: Intrinsics, extrinsics
  • Modalities: Ice, ultrasound
  • Gait training: Optimize mechanics

docs.title: What DOESN'T Work
docs.text:
• Chiropractic manipulation: No evidence
  • Toe spacers: Irrelevant for this condition
  • Supplements (glucosamine, chondroitin): No proven benefit

docs.title: Success Rates
docs.text:
• Grade 1-2: 70-80% improve with footwear modification
  • Grade 3: 30-50% adequate relief
  • Grade 4: <20% benefit
  • Injections: Temporary relief, may delay surgery

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Progressive condition: May worsen over time
  • Non-operative treatment: Manages symptoms, doesn't reverse arthritis
  • Footwear critical: Stiff, rocker-bottom shoes most effective
  • Surgery: Consider if conservative treatment fails
  • Timing: No urgency for surgery unless significant disability
  • Natural history: Variable progression, some remain mild for years

docs.title: When to Consider Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (minimum 3-6 months)
  • Significant pain limiting activities
  • Difficulty with work or daily activities
  • Progression despite treatment
  • Grade 3-4 disease

docs.title: Follow-up
docs.text:
• Reassess at 3-6 months
  • Serial X-rays if symptomatic progression
  • Ensure proper footwear and orthotic use
  • Discuss surgery if symptoms persist or worsen

docs.title: Gout
docs.text:
• May present acutely as gout attack at 1st MTP
  • Treat underlying hyperuricemia
  • Higher risk of rapid progression

docs.title: Athletes
docs.text:
• May significantly limit performance
  • Consider cheilectomy (surgical) earlier to preserve motion

docs.title: Inflammatory Arthritis
docs.text:
• More aggressive arthritis
  • Address underlying disease
  • Often need surgery earlier

docs.title: Bilateral Disease
docs.text:
• Common (up to 80%)
  • Stage surgery if both need intervention

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
1. Footwear modification is the most effective non-surgical treatment
  2. Stiff-soled, rocker-bottom shoes are the gold standard
  3. Injections provide temporary relief, may delay surgery
  4. Grade 1-2 often respond well to conservative treatment
  5. Grade 3-4 usually eventually require surgery
  6. Non-operative treatment doesn't reverse arthritis
  7. Surgery should be considered if quality of life significantly affected

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (minimum 3-6 months)
  • Significant pain limiting activities of daily living
  • Progressive deformity and stiffness
  • Inability to maintain adequate footwear
  • Grade 2-4 disease (especially Grade 3-4)

docs.title: Patient Factors
docs.text:
• Age and activity level
  • Functional demands
  • Shoe wear requirements
  • Occupation (effects of fusion vs. arthroplasty)
  • Expectations: Motion preservation vs. pain relief

docs.title: Radiographic Assessment
docs.text:
• Grade (0-4): Guides procedure selection
  • Dorsal osteophytes: Size and location
  • Joint space: Amount of remaining cartilage
  • Cartilage distribution: Dorsal vs. plantar/central
  • Sesamoid arthritis
  • Metatarsal length: Relative to 2nd MT

docs.title: 1. Cheilectomy (Dorsal Osteophyte Excision)
docs.text:
Indications: - Grade 1-2 disease - Dorsal impingement pain - Preserved joint space (>50%) - Dorsal/dorsolateral cartilage loss only

Technique: - Dorsal incision - Excise dorsal 20-30% of metatarsal head - Remove dorsal osteophytes - Dorsal capsulectomy - Decompress joint

Outcomes: - Success: 70-90% good to excellent results - Pain relief: 80-90% - Increased dorsiflexion: 20-30° - Durability: 5-10 years average - Revision rate: 20-30% within 10 years

Advantages: - Preserves motion - Low morbidity - Quick recovery (6-8 weeks) - Can convert to arthrodesis later

Disadvantages: - Does not address advanced arthritis - Temporary solution for many - May not relieve midrange pain (Grade 4)

docs.title: 2. Cheilectomy + Moberg Osteotomy
docs.text:
Indications: - Grade 2 disease - Need greater dorsiflexion - Plantar cartilage preserved

Technique: - Cheilectomy as above - Dorsal closing wedge osteotomy of proximal phalanx - Extends hallux (increases functional dorsiflexion)

Outcomes: - Similar to cheilectomy, may provide additional dorsiflexion - 75-85% good results

docs.title: Grade 2-3: Consider Cheilectomy or Arthrodesis
docs.text: Decision depends on: - Amount of remaining cartilage - Patient age and activity - Presence of midrange pain

docs.title: 1. MTP Arthrodesis (Gold Standard for Advanced Disease)
docs.text:
Indications: - Grade 3-4 disease - Young, active patients - Manual laborers - Revision after failed cheilectomy or arthroplasty

Technique: - Medial or dorsal incision - Prepare joint surfaces (remove cartilage) - Position: 10-15° dorsiflexion, 10-15° valgus, neutral rotation - Fixation: Plate, screws, or combination

Positioning Critical: - Dorsiflexion: 10-15° relative to floor when standing - Too much: Difficulty walking downhill, IPJ stress - Too little: Difficulty with toe-off, shoe wear - Valgus: 10-15° (match contralateral if normal) - Rotation: Neutral (nail points upward)

Outcomes: - Fusion rate: 90-95% - Pain relief: 90-95% excellent - Satisfaction: 85-95% - Return to activity: 4-6 months - Durability: Lifelong - Complications: Nonunion (5-10%), malposition, IPJ arthritis

Advantages: - Excellent, predictable pain relief - Durable solution - Allows return to high-impact activities - No implant issues

Disadvantages: - Loss of MTP motion - Difficulty with certain shoe wear (high heels) - Stress transfer to IPJ (may develop arthritis) - Permanent solution (not reversible)

docs.title: 2. Hemi-Arthroplasty (Interposition or Implant)
docs.text:
Indications: - Grade 3-4 disease - Older, lower-demand patients - Desire to preserve motion - Not suitable for high-impact activities

Types: - Metatarsal head resurfacing (HemiCAP) - Silicone implant (Historical, high failure rate) - Cartiva (SCI) - Synthetic cartilage implant

Outcomes: - Variable results: 60-80% good to excellent - Preserves some motion - Less predictable than arthrodesis - Revision rate higher than arthrodesis

Advantages: - Preserves motion - Reversible (can convert to arthrodesis)

Disadvantages: - Less predictable outcomes - Implant-related complications - Not for high-demand patients - May require revision

docs.title: 3. Total Joint Replacement (Rare)
docs.text:
Indications: - Very limited - Older, low-demand patients - Rheumatoid arthritis - Desire motion preservation

Outcomes: - High failure rate (30-50% within 10 years) - Loosening, subsidence common - Generally NOT recommended

docs.title: 4. Keller Resection Arthroplasty (Salvage Only)
docs.text:
Technique: - Resect proximal phalanx base (30-50%) - Create fibrous pseudoarthrosis

Indications: - Salvage procedure only - Elderly, low-demand patients - Contraindication to arthrodesis

Outcomes: - Poor push-off strength - Cock-up deformity - Transfer metatarsalgia - Generally avoided in modern practice

docs.title: Decision Algorithm
docs.text:
Grade 1-2 + Preserved cartilage:
└─ Cheilectomy (± Moberg)

Grade 2-3 + Moderate cartilage loss:
├─ Young, active → Cheilectomy
└─ Older, low-demand or midrange pain → Consider arthrodesis

Grade 3-4:
├─ Young, active, high-demand
│  └─ MTP Arthrodesis (Gold Standard)
│
├─ Older, low-demand, want motion
│  └─ Hemi-arthroplasty or Arthrodesis
│
└─ Rheumatoid, very low-demand
   └─ Consider implant arthroplasty

Failed Cheilectomy:
└─ MTP Arthrodesis

docs.title: Cheilectomy
docs.text:
Weeks 0-2: - Surgical shoe - Weight-bearing as tolerated - Elevation

Weeks 2-6: - Progress to regular shoe (stiff-soled) - ROM exercises immediately

Weeks 6-8: - Return to activities

Months 3-6: - Full activities

docs.title: MTP Arthrodesis
docs.text:
Weeks 0-6: - Short leg cast or CAM boot - Non-weight bearing (some protocols allow heel weight-bearing) - Elevation

Weeks 6-8: - CAM boot, protected weight-bearing - Check X-rays for fusion progress

Weeks 8-12: - Full weight-bearing in boot - Progressive activity

Months 3-6: - Transition to regular shoe (stiff-soled) - Return to activities at 4-6 months - Full recovery 6-12 months

docs.title: Arthroplasty
docs.text:
Weeks 0-2: - Surgical shoe - Protected weight-bearing

Weeks 2-6: - Weight-bearing as tolerated - ROM exercises

Weeks 6-12: - Progress activity - Return to normal shoe

docs.title: Cheilectomy
docs.text:
• Recurrence (20-30% within 10 years)
  • Persistent pain (10-20%)
  • Stiffness
  • Neurovascular injury
  • Progression to arthrodesis needed

docs.title: MTP Arthrodesis
docs.text:
• Nonunion (5-10%): Most common complication
  • Malposition (5%): Too much/little dorsiflexion or valgus
  • IPJ arthritis (10-20% long-term): Stress transfer
  • Hardware irritation (5-10%)
  • Infection (2-5%)
  • Persistent pain despite fusion (rare)

docs.title: Arthroplasty
docs.text:
• Implant loosening/subsidence (10-30%)
  • Osteolysis (silicone synovitis if silicone)
  • Infection (2-5%)
  • Stiffness or persistent pain
  • Revision surgery needed (15-30%)

docs.title: Outcomes by Procedure
docs.text: Procedure Success Rate Motion Durability Patient Satisfaction Return to Activity Cheilectomy (Grade 1-2) 70-90% Improved 5-10 years 80-85% 6-8 weeks MTP Arthrodesis 90-95% Lost Lifelong 85-95% 4-6 months Hemi-arthroplasty 60-80% Partial Variable 70-80% 3-4 months

docs.title: Key Surgical Principles
docs.text:
1. Grade determines procedure: Don't do cheilectomy for Grade 4
  2. MTP arthrodesis is gold standard for advanced disease (Grade 3-4)
  3. Positioning in arthrodesis is critical: 10-15° dorsiflexion, 10-15° valgus
  4. Cheilectomy for early disease (Grade 1-2), allows conversion to arthrodesis later
  5. Arthroplasty has higher revision rate, less predictable than arthrodesis
  6. Total joint replacement generally not recommended
  7. Patient selection: Match procedure to patient demand and expectations

docs.title: Failed Cheilectomy
docs.text:
• Convert to arthrodesis (most common)
  • Outcomes of arthrodesis after cheilectomy are good

docs.title: Nonunion after Arthrodesis
docs.text:
• Revision arthrodesis with bone graft
  • Ensure proper positioning
  • Consider biologic augmentation (BMP)

docs.title: Failed Arthroplasty
docs.text:
• Convert to arthrodesis
  • More technically demanding
  • May need bone graft
  • Outcomes less predictable than primary arthrodesis

docs.title: Athletes
docs.text:
• Cheilectomy preferred if early disease (preserve motion)
  • Arthrodesis allows return to high-impact sports
  • Some elite athletes successfully compete with arthrodesis

docs.title: High Heels
docs.text:
• Difficult with arthrodesis (fixed position)
  • Counsel patients preoperatively
  • Consider arthroplasty if high heel wear essential (though less reliable)

docs.title: Bilateral Disease
docs.text:
• Common (up to 80%)
  • Stage surgeries 3-6 months apart
  • Consider doing less affected side first

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
1. Cheilectomy for early disease (Grade 1-2) with preserved joint space
  2. MTP arthrodesis is gold standard for advanced disease (Grade 3-4)
  3. Arthrodesis provides excellent pain relief (90-95%) with predictable outcomes
  4. Arthroplasty less reliable, higher revision rate
  5. Positioning in arthrodesis is critical for good outcome
  6. Motion vs. Pain relief: Arthrodesis sacrifices motion but gives best pain relief
  7. Failed cheilectomy converts well to arthrodesis

docs.title: Clinical Presentation
docs.text:
• Medial prominence at 1st MTP joint ("bunion")
  • Lateral deviation of great toe
  • Pain over medial eminence from shoe irritation
  • Difficulty with shoe wear
  • Transfer metatarsalgia (lesser toes)
  • Cosmetic concerns

docs.title: By Deformity Severity (Radiographic)
docs.text:
• Mild: HVA 15-20°, IMA 9-11°
  • Moderate: HVA 20-40°, IMA 11-16°
  • Severe: HVA >40°, IMA >16°

Angles: - HVA (Hallux Valgus Angle): Between 1st metatarsal and proximal phalanx (Normal <15°) - IMA (Intermetatarsal Angle): Between 1st and 2nd metatarsals (Normal <9°)

docs.title: Associated Deformities
docs.text:
• Pronation of great toe
  • Bunionette (5th toe)
  • Crossover 2nd toe deformity
  • Pes planus (flatfoot)

docs.title: Etiology and Risk Factors
docs.text:
• Footwear: Narrow toe box, high heels (exacerbating factor)
  • Genetics: Strong familial predisposition
  • Ligamentous laxity
  • Inflammatory arthritis (RA)
  • Neuromuscular conditions
  • First ray hypermobility

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
• Alignment: Measure HVA clinically
  • Medial Eminence: Bursitis, tenderness
  • Range of Motion: First MTP joint (assess for rigidus)
  • Pronation: Great toe pronates with deformity
  • Transfer Metatarsalgia: Calluses under lesser metatarsals
  • Crossover Deformity: 2nd toe overlaps great toe
  • First Ray Mobility: Assess hypermobility
  • Foot Type: Pes planus often associated

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• Weight-bearing AP and Lateral Foot X-rays (Essential)
  • Measure:
  • HVA (hallux valgus angle)
  • IMA (intermetatarsal angle)
  • DMAA (distal metatarsal articular angle): assess articular surface
  • Sesamoid position
  • Assess for:
  • Arthritis at 1st MTP joint
  • First TMT joint instability
  • Pes planus deformity

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Mild symptoms
  • Minimal pain
  • Primarily cosmetic concerns
  • Low-demand patients
  • Patients unwilling to undergo surgery

docs.title: Treatment Goals
docs.text:
• Pain relief (not deformity correction)
  • Accommodate deformity
  • Prevent progression (uncertain)

docs.title: 1. Footwear Modification (Most Important)
docs.text:
• Wide toe box: Accommodate deformity
  • Soft uppers: Reduce pressure on bunion
  • Rocker sole: Decrease 1st MTP motion
  • Low heel height: <2 inches
  • Avoid narrow, pointy shoes

docs.title: 2. Padding and Orthotics
docs.text:
• Bunion pads: Gel or felt over medial eminence
  • Toe spacers: Between 1st and 2nd toes (limited efficacy)
  • Custom orthotics: Arch support for flatfoot
  • Bunion splint/night splint: May provide temporary relief, does NOT correct deformity

docs.title: 3. Pharmacological Management
docs.text:
• NSAIDs: For bursitis, inflammation
  • Ice: After prolonged standing/walking
  • Topical analgesics

docs.title: 4. Injection Therapy (Limited Role)
docs.text:
• Corticosteroid: For acute bursitis over medial eminence
  • Temporary relief only
  • Do NOT inject into joint (risk of cartilage damage)

docs.title: What DOESN'T Work
docs.text:
• Toe spacers/splints: Do NOT correct deformity permanently
  • "Bunion correctors": Marketing gimmick, no evidence
  • Exercises: Cannot reverse bony deformity

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Non-operative treatment does NOT correct deformity
  • Goal: Symptom management, not deformity correction
  • Progression: May progress over time despite treatment
  • Footwear: Most important factor for symptom control
  • Surgery: Only definitive treatment for deformity correction
  • Cosmetic surgery: Not recommended if asymptomatic
  • Realistic expectations: Can't "cure" bunion without surgery

docs.title: When to Consider Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (3-6 months)
  • Significant pain limiting activities
  • Difficulty with shoe wear
  • Progressive deformity
  • Transfer metatarsalgia
  • Crossover toe deformity

docs.title: Success Rates
docs.text:
• Footwear modification: 70-80% have adequate symptom relief
  • Does NOT prevent progression of deformity
  • Temporary relief with padding, NSAIDs

docs.title: Follow-up
docs.text:
• Reassess at 3-6 months
  • Monitor for progression (serial X-rays if symptomatic progression)
  • Discuss surgery if symptoms persist or worsen

docs.title: Adolescent Hallux Valgus
docs.text:
• Often familial, bilateral
  • Conservative treatment preferred until skeletal maturity
  • High recurrence rate even with surgery

docs.title: Inflammatory Arthritis (RA)
docs.text:
• Aggressive deformity
  • Address underlying disease
  • Higher surgical complication rate

docs.title: Hypermobility/Flatfoot
docs.text:
• Address with arch support
  • May need more extensive surgery if operative

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
1. Non-operative treatment provides symptom relief, NOT deformity correction
  2. Wide shoes are the most effective non-surgical intervention
  3. "Bunion correctors" and toe spacers do NOT work
  4. Surgery is the only way to correct deformity
  5. Asymptomatic bunions do NOT need treatment
  6. Progression is variable and unpredictable

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (minimum 3-6 months)
  • Significant pain limiting activities of daily living
  • Difficulty with shoe wear
  • Progressive deformity
  • Transfer metatarsalgia
  • Associated deformities (crossover 2nd toe)

NOT indicated for: - Cosmetic reasons alone - Asymptomatic bunions - Unrealistic patient expectations

docs.title: Patient Factors
docs.text:
• Age: Consider skeletal maturity in adolescents
  • Activity level and goals
  • Medical comorbidities: Diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, smoking
  • Realistic expectations
  • Shoe wear goals

docs.title: Deformity Assessment
docs.text:
• Severity: Mild, moderate, severe (HVA, IMA)
  • DMAA (distal metatarsal articular angle): >10° = abnormal, may need distal osteotomy or double osteotomy
  • First ray hypermobility: May need TMT fusion (Lapidus)
  • Sesamoid subluxation: Assess degree
  • Arthritis: MTP arthrodesis if severe
  • Associated flatfoot: Address if significant
  • Lesser toe deformities: Often need correction

docs.title: Mild Deformity (HVA 15-20°, IMA 9-11°)
docs.text:
Distal Soft Tissue Procedure + Distal Metatarsal Osteotomy

1. Chevron Osteotomy - V-shaped osteotomy through distal MT head - Lateral displacement of capital fragment - Fix with screw - Corrects up to 15° HVA, 5° IMA - Advantages: Stable, predictable - Disadvantages: Limited correction

2. Scarf Osteotomy - Z-shaped osteotomy through MT shaft - Allows translation and rotation - More versatile than Chevron - Advantages: Greater correction potential - Disadvantages: Technically demanding

docs.title: Moderate Deformity (HVA 20-40°, IMA 11-16°)
docs.text:
Proximal or Diaphyseal Osteotomy + Soft Tissue Procedure

1. Proximal Crescentic Osteotomy - Curved osteotomy at MT base - Rotate to correct deformity - Less stable, needs protection

2. Proximal Chevron - Similar to distal Chevron but at MT base - Greater correction than distal

3. Scarf Osteotomy - Can also be used for moderate deformities - Popular in Europe

4. Lapidus Procedure (TMT Arthrodesis) - Fuse 1st TMT joint - Correct IMA at base - Indications: - First ray hypermobility - TMT arthritis - Severe deformity with flexibility at TMT - Advantages: Addresses hypermobility, durable correction - Disadvantages: Fusion (loss of motion), longer recovery

docs.title: Severe Deformity (HVA >40°, IMA >16°)
docs.text:
Double Osteotomy or Lapidus Procedure

1. Lapidus Procedure (Preferred by many) - TMT arthrodesis - Most powerful correction - Addresses instability

2. Proximal + Distal Osteotomy - Correct at two levels - Technically challenging - Risk of AVN (metatarsal head)

docs.title: Arthritis at MTP Joint
docs.text: MTP Arthrodesis - Fuse 1st MTP joint in functional position - 10-15° dorsiflexion, 10-15° valgus - Eliminates bunion and arthritis pain - Loss of MTP motion (affects shoe wear, gait) - Outcomes: Excellent pain relief, high satisfaction

docs.title: Medial Capsular Plication
docs.text:
• Tighten medial capsule
  • Excise medial eminence

docs.title: Lateral Release
docs.text:
• Release adductor hallucis
  • Release lateral capsule
  • Free lateral sesamoid if needed

docs.title: Akin Osteotomy (Proximal Phalanx)
docs.text:
• Closing wedge osteotomy of proximal phalanx
  • Corrects interphalangeal deviation
  • Often added to metatarsal osteotomy

docs.title: Decision Algorithm
docs.text:
Severity:
├─ Mild (HVA 15-20°, IMA <11°)
│  └─ Distal osteotomy (Chevron or Scarf)
│
├─ Moderate (HVA 20-40°, IMA 11-16°)
│  ├─ No hypermobility → Proximal osteotomy or Scarf
│  └─ Hypermobility → Lapidus
│
└─ Severe (HVA >40°, IMA >16°)
   └─ Lapidus (preferred) or Double osteotomy

Arthritis at MTP:
└─ MTP Arthrodesis

High DMAA (>10°):
└─ Consider distal soft tissue realignment or double osteotomy

docs.title: Distal Soft Tissue Procedure (McBride)
docs.text:
• Medial incision
  • Excise medial eminence (don't over-resect)
  • Lateral release (through separate incision or same)
  • Release adductor, lateral capsule
  • Tighten medial capsule

docs.title: Chevron Osteotomy
docs.text:
• 60° V-shaped cut through distal MT
  • Translate lateral 3-5 mm
  • Fix with screw
  • Stable construct

docs.title: Lapidus Procedure
docs.text:
• Dorsomedial incision over 1st TMT joint
  • Remove cartilage at TMT joint
  • Reduce IMA
  • Fix with plate or screws
  • Rigid fixation for fusion

docs.title: Distal Osteotomies (Chevron)
docs.text:
Weeks 0-2: - Surgical shoe with stiff sole - Weight-bearing on heel only - Elevation

Weeks 2-6: - Protected weight-bearing in surgical shoe - May progress to full weight-bearing in shoe - ROM exercises (gentle)

Weeks 6-8: - Transition to wide, supportive shoe - Progressive activity

Months 3-6: - Return to normal shoes (wide toe box) - Return to activities

docs.title: Proximal Osteotomies / Lapidus
docs.text:
Weeks 0-6: - Short leg cast or CAM boot - Non-weight bearing - Elevation

Weeks 6-8: - CAM boot, protected weight-bearing - Check X-rays for healing/fusion

Weeks 8-12: - Progressive weight-bearing - Transition to shoe

Months 3-6: - Return to regular shoes - Full activity at 4-6 months

docs.title: MTP Arthrodesis
docs.text:
Weeks 0-6: - Short leg cast or CAM boot - Non-weight bearing

Weeks 6-8: - Protected weight-bearing once fusion evident

Weeks 8-12: - Full weight-bearing - Transition to shoe

Months 3-6: - Full activity - Avoid high heels (difficulty with MTP fusion)

docs.title: Intraoperative
docs.text:
• Neurovascular injury (medial dorsal cutaneous nerve)
  • Fracture propagation
  • Over/under-correction

docs.title: Early Postoperative
docs.text:
• Wound healing problems (5-10%)
  • Infection (2-5%)
  • Swelling (universal, can last months)
  • Stiffness

docs.title: Late Postoperative
docs.text:
• Recurrence (5-15%)
  • Hallux varus (overcorrection, 2-5%)
  • Transfer metatarsalgia (5-10%)
  • Nonunion (Lapidus: 5%, arthrodesis: 5-10%)
  • Malunion (poor position)
  • AVN of metatarsal head (rare, <1%)
  • Persistent pain or stiffness
  • Numbness (medial dorsal cutaneous nerve)

docs.title: Outcomes by Procedure
docs.text: Procedure Success Rate Recurrence Return to Activity Satisfaction Chevron 85-90% 5-10% 3 months 85-90% Scarf 85-95% 5-10% 3-4 months 85-90% Proximal osteotomy 80-90% 10-15% 4-6 months 80-85% Lapidus 90-95% <5% 4-6 months 90% MTP arthrodesis 90-95% N/A 4-6 months 85-90%

docs.title: Key Surgical Principles
docs.text:
1. Correct all components: Bony deformity + soft tissue imbalance
  2. Don't over-resect medial eminence (risk of hallux varus)
  3. Lateral release essential for moderate-severe deformities
  4. Lapidus for hypermobility: Don't miss instability
  5. DMAA >10°: Consider distal realignment or double osteotomy
  6. Arthrodesis for arthritis: Don't do osteotomy if arthritis present
  7. Address lesser toe deformities: Often need simultaneous correction
  8. Patient selection: Realistic expectations, appropriate footwear goals

docs.title: Adolescent Hallux Valgus
docs.text:
• High recurrence rate (20-30%)
  • Defer surgery until skeletal maturity if possible
  • Address flatfoot if present

docs.title: Rheumatoid Arthritis
docs.text:
• Aggressive deformity, multiple toe involvement
  • Often need MTP arthrodesis or resection arthroplasty
  • Address lesser toes simultaneously

docs.title: Diabetes / Peripheral Vascular Disease
docs.text:
• Higher complication rate
  • Assess vascular status preoperatively
  • May need non-operative management

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Recurrence
  • Hallux varus
  • Persistent pain
  • Malunion/nonunion

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• Revision osteotomy (if young, minimal surgery previously)
  • Lapidus if previous distal procedure
  • MTP arthrodesis (salvage)

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
1. Surgery corrects deformity, non-operative does not
  2. Match procedure to deformity severity and patient factors
  3. Lapidus procedure excellent for moderate-severe deformity and hypermobility
  4. MTP arthrodesis for arthritis
