  5. Realistic expectations: Swelling lasts months, shoe wear limitations
  6. High patient satisfaction overall (85-90%)
  7. Not cosmetic surgery: Done for pain and function

docs.title: Clinical Presentation
docs.text:
• Plantar forefoot pain under metatarsal heads
  • Burning, aching, or sharp pain
  • Worse with: Weight-bearing, walking barefoot, thin-soled shoes
  • Better with: Rest, shoe removal, massage
  • Calluses under metatarsal heads
  • Typically affects 2nd and 3rd metatarsals most commonly

docs.title: Definition and Etiology
docs.text: Metatarsalgia = Non-specific term for pain under metatarsal heads

docs.title: 1. Mechanical Overload
docs.text:
• Altered weight distribution: Excessive pressure on metatarsal heads
  • Biomechanical factors:
  • Pes cavus (high arch) - increased forefoot loading
  • Short 1st metatarsal - transfers load to 2nd MT
  • Long lesser metatarsals
  • Hallux valgus - loss of 1st ray weight-bearing
  • Hallux rigidus - loss of 1st MTP push-off
  • Tight gastrocnemius - increases forefoot pressure

docs.title: 2. Anatomic Factors
docs.text:
• Fat pad atrophy (aging, steroid injections)
  • Prominent metatarsal heads
  • Metatarsal declination angle

docs.title: 3. Pathologic Conditions
docs.text:
• Freiberg's disease (2nd MT head osteonecrosis)
  • MTP synovitis/capsulitis
  • Plantar plate tear
  • Stress fracture
  • Sesamoiditis (1st MT)
  • Morton's neuroma (interspace, not MT head)

docs.title: 4. Footwear
docs.text:
• High heels - shift weight forward
  • Thin soles - inadequate cushioning
  • Narrow toe box - compresses forefoot

docs.title: 5. Sports/Activities
docs.text:
• High-impact activities: Running, jumping
  • Sports with forefoot loading: Ballet, basketball, tennis

docs.title: Clinical History
docs.text:
• Pain location (which metatarsal heads)
  • Footwear habits
  • Activity level
  • Associated deformities (bunion, hammer toes)
  • Previous treatments

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
• Calluses: Indicate pressure points
  • Point tenderness: Directly over MT heads (plantar)
  • Metatarsal squeeze test: Compressing MT heads together → pain
  • Gastrocnemius tightness: Silfverskiöld test (<10° dorsiflexion with knee extended)
  • Assess for:
  • Hallux valgus
  • Hammer/claw toes
  • Pes cavus
  • Fat pad atrophy
  • MTP stability: Drawer test for plantar plate integrity
  • Differentiate from Morton's neuroma: Interspace tenderness (neuroma) vs. MT head tenderness (metatarsalgia)

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• Weight-bearing AP and Lateral X-rays:
  • Assess metatarsal length
  • Look for stress fracture
  • Freiberg's disease (flattening, sclerosis of MT head)
  • MTP arthritis

  • Assess alignment (pes cavus, hallux valgus)

  • MRI: If diagnosis uncertain

  • Stress fracture
  • Osteonecrosis
  • Plantar plate tear
  • Soft tissue pathology

docs.title: Classification by Etiology
docs.text:
• Primary metatarsalgia: Mechanical overload without specific pathology
  • Secondary metatarsalgia: Due to specific condition (Freiberg's, plantar plate tear, etc.)

docs.title: Success Rate
docs.text:
• 70-90% improve with conservative treatment
  • Best results with mechanical causes

docs.title: 1. Footwear Modification (Most Important)
docs.text:
• Cushioned, thick soles: Shock absorption
  • Rocker-bottom sole: Reduces forefoot pressure
  • Wide toe box: Reduce compression
  • Low heel height: <2 inches
  • Stiff sole: Limit MTP motion (if associated hammer toes)
  • Avoid: High heels, thin-soled shoes, narrow toe box

docs.title: 2. Orthotic Management
docs.text:
• Metatarsal pad: Place proximal to painful MT heads
  • Offloads pressure from MT heads

  • Critical: Positioning must be proximal to MT heads, not under them

  • Cushioned insoles: Shock absorption

  • Arch support: If pes cavus or flatfoot
  • Dancer's pad: Cutout under painful MT heads with pad proximal
  • Custom orthotics: Address biomechanical factors

docs.title: 3. Activity Modification
docs.text:
• Reduce high-impact activities
  • Cross-training: Swimming, cycling (low forefoot impact)
  • Avoid barefoot walking
  • Gradual return to activity

docs.title: 4. Stretching
docs.text:
• Gastrocnemius-soleus stretching: Critical if tight
  • Decrease forefoot pressure

  • 3 sets of 30 seconds, 2-3x daily

  • Plantar fascia stretching

docs.title: 5. Strengthening
docs.text:
• Intrinsic foot muscle strengthening
  • Toe curls, marble pickup
  • Improve shock absorption

docs.title: 6. Pharmacological Management
docs.text:
• NSAIDs: Oral or topical
  • Ice: After activity

docs.title: 7. Physical Therapy
docs.text:
• Stretching program
  • Strengthening
  • Gait training
  • Modalities (ultrasound, iontophoresis)

docs.title: 8. Injection Therapy (Use Cautiously)
docs.text:
• Corticosteroid: May provide temporary relief
  • Risk: Fat pad atrophy (worsens condition long-term)
  • Generally avoided unless severe acute inflammation

docs.title: Weight Loss
docs.text:
• Reduces forefoot pressure
  • Important if BMI elevated

docs.title: Treatment Protocol
docs.text:
Phase 1 (0-6 weeks): - Footwear modification - Metatarsal pad - Gastrocnemius stretching - Activity modification - NSAIDs

Phase 2 (6-12 weeks): - Continue above - Add physical therapy if not improving - Custom orthotics if biomechanical factors

Phase 3 (3-6 months): - If no improvement: Re-evaluate for specific pathology - Consider MRI - Surgical consultation if refractory

docs.title: Associated Conditions to Treat
docs.text:
• Hallux valgus: Consider bunion surgery
  • Hallux rigidus: Treat with cheilectomy or arthrodesis
  • Hammer toes: Flexible: strapping; Rigid: surgery
  • Gastrocnemius contracture: Stretching, consider recession if severe
  • Pes cavus: Orthotics, consider osteotomy if severe

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Most cases improve with footwear and orthotics
  • Metatarsal pad positioning is critical (proximal to MT heads)
  • Avoid corticosteroid injections (risk of fat pad atrophy)
  • Gastrocnemius stretching very important
  • Lifelong footwear modifications may be needed
  • Address associated deformities (bunion, hammer toes)

docs.title: When to Consider Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (minimum 3-6 months)
  • Identifiable pathology (plantar plate tear, Freiberg's, severe hammer toes)
  • Significant functional limitation
  • Unable to modify footwear adequately

docs.title: Follow-up
docs.text:
• Reassess at 6 weeks
  • Ensure proper orthotic positioning
  • If no improvement at 3 months, consider MRI
  • Surgical consultation if refractory at 6 months

docs.title: Differential Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Morton's neuroma: Interspace pain, not MT head
  • Stress fracture: Point tenderness over MT shaft
  • Freiberg's disease: 2nd MT head osteonecrosis (X-ray)
  • Plantar plate tear: MTP instability, positive drawer test
  • Sesamoiditis: Under 1st MT, not lesser MTs
  • MTP synovitis: Joint effusion, pain with MTP motion
  • Tarsal tunnel syndrome: Medial ankle, burning, Tinel's sign

docs.title: Athletes
docs.text:
• High-impact sports exacerbate
  • May need activity modification
  • Custom sport-specific orthotics
  • Consider taping for competitions

docs.title: Ballet Dancers
docs.text:
• Extreme forefoot loading
  • Often need specialized orthotics or padding
  • May need to modify technique

docs.title: Fat Pad Atrophy
docs.text:
• More common in elderly
  • Prior corticosteroid injections
  • Very difficult to treat
  • Cushioned shoes and padding critical
  • Consider injectable filler (off-label, limited evidence)

docs.title: Diabetes/Neuropathy
docs.text:
• May not feel pain until severe
  • High risk of ulceration
  • Aggressive padding and footwear modification
  • Avoid injections

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
1. Metatarsalgia is a symptom, not a diagnosis - find the cause
  2. Footwear modification is the most effective treatment
  3. Metatarsal pad must be positioned proximal to MT heads
  4. Gastrocnemius stretching reduces forefoot pressure
  5. Avoid steroid injections (risk of fat pad atrophy)
  6. 70-90% improve with conservative treatment
  7. Address associated deformities (bunion, hammer toes, pes cavus)
  8. Consider MRI if not improving to rule out specific pathology

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
Surgery is RARELY first-line for primary metatarsalgia

Indications: - Failed conservative treatment (minimum 6-12 months) - Identifiable structural pathology: - Hallux valgus causing transfer metatarsalgia - Hallux rigidus limiting 1st ray function - Rigid hammer/claw toes - Plantar plate tear - Freiberg's disease - Significant metatarsal length discrepancy - Pes cavus with excessive forefoot loading - Significant functional limitation - Unable to tolerate conservative management

Important: Surgery addresses the underlying cause, not just the symptom of forefoot pain.

docs.title: Identify the Cause
docs.text:
• Primary vs. secondary metatarsalgia
  • Associated deformities: Hallux valgus, hammer toes, cavus foot
  • Specific pathology: Plantar plate tear, Freiberg's disease
  • Biomechanical factors: Gastrocnemius contracture, metatarsal length

docs.title: Radiographic Assessment
docs.text:
• Weight-bearing X-rays
  • Metatarsal parabola: Normal cascade of decreasing length from 1-5
  • Relative metatarsal lengths
  • Associated deformities (bunion, pes cavus)
  • Freiberg's disease (flattening, sclerosis of MT head)

docs.title: Advanced Imaging
docs.text:
• MRI: Plantar plate tear, stress fracture, soft tissue pathology
  • CT: Bone detail if needed

docs.title: Patient Selection
docs.text:
• Realistic expectations
  • Understanding that pain may not completely resolve
  • Willing to continue orthotic use postoperatively

docs.title: Hallux Valgus Correction
docs.text:
• If bunion present: Correcting bunion often relieves transfer metatarsalgia
  • Restore 1st ray weight-bearing
  • Procedure depends on bunion severity (see Hallux Valgus section)

docs.title: Hallux Rigidus Treatment
docs.text:
• If 1st MTP arthritis: Cheilectomy or arthrodesis
  • Restore 1st ray push-off
  • Reduces load on lesser metatarsals

docs.title: Hammer/Claw Toe Correction
docs.text:
• Flexible: PIPJ arthroplasty, flexor-to-extensor transfer
  • Rigid: PIPJ arthrodesis
  • Reduces pressure under MT heads

docs.title: Gastrocnemius Recession
docs.text:
• If gastrocnemius contracture (>10° equinus)
  • Decreases forefoot pressure
  • Can be combined with other procedures

docs.title: 2. Metatarsal Osteotomies (For Primary Metatarsalgia)
docs.text: Indications: - Metatarsal length discrepancy - Prominent MT head - Failed conservative treatment without other deformity

docs.title: Weil Osteotomy (Most Common)
docs.text:
Technique: - Dorsal longitudinal incision - Oblique osteotomy parallel to weightbearing surface - Slide MT head proximally (shortens MT) - Fix with screw

Outcomes: - Success: 70-85% - Complications: Stiffness (20-40%), floating toe, recurrence

Advantages: - Reliable shortening - Stable fixation

Disadvantages: - High stiffness rate - Transfer metatarsalgia to adjacent MT (if too much shortening) - Floating toe deformity

docs.title: Distal MT Osteotomy (Dorsiflexion)
docs.text:
• Elevate MT head (plantarflex distal fragment)
  • Offloads pressure
  • Less commonly done than Weil

docs.title: BRT (Bösch) Osteotomy
docs.text:
• Distal oblique osteotomy
  • Shortens and elevates MT head
  • Alternative to Weil

docs.title: 3. Plantar Plate Repair
docs.text:
Indications: - MTP instability - Positive drawer test - MRI confirmation of tear

Technique: - Dorsal or plantar approach - Reattach plantar plate to base of proximal phalanx - Often combined with Weil osteotomy - May need K-wire temporary fixation

Outcomes: - 70-85% good to excellent results - Improved stability

docs.title: 4. Freiberg's Disease Treatment
docs.text:
Options: - Early (Stage I-II): Debridement, drilling, Weil osteotomy - Advanced (Stage III-IV): Osteochondral grafting, MT head resection, interpositional arthroplasty

Technique depends on stage (see specific Freiberg's protocols)

docs.title: 5. Partial MT Head Resection (Rarely Done)
docs.text:
Technique: - Resect plantar condyles of MT head

Disadvantages: - Destabilizes joint - High complication rate - Generally avoided

docs.title: 6. Pes Cavus Correction
docs.text: If severe pes cavus with excessive forefoot loading: - Calcaneal osteotomy: Dorsiflexion/lateralizing - 1st MT dorsiflexion osteotomy - Plantar fascia release - Complex reconstruction (see Pes Cavus section)

docs.title: Decision Algorithm
docs.text:
Cause of Metatarsalgia:

├─ Hallux Valgus (Transfer Metatarsalgia)
│  └─ Bunion correction (Lapidus, osteotomy)
│
├─ Hallux Rigidus
│  └─ Cheilectomy or MTP arthrodesis
│
├─ Hammer/Claw Toes
│  └─ PIPJ arthroplasty or arthrodesis
│
├─ Plantar Plate Tear
│  └─ Plantar plate repair ± Weil osteotomy
│
├─ Freiberg's Disease
│  └─ Debridement ± Weil osteotomy or grafting
│
├─ Metatarsal Length Discrepancy
│  └─ Weil osteotomy (shorten long MT)
│
├─ Gastrocnemius Contracture
│  └─ Gastrocnemius recession
│
└─ Pes Cavus
   └─ Calcaneal/metatarsal osteotomies

docs.title: Which Metatarsals to Operate On
docs.text:
• Typically 2nd and/or 3rd MT most symptomatic
  • Restore metatarsal parabola (cascade)
  • Avoid creating transfer metatarsalgia

docs.title: Amount of Shortening (Weil Osteotomy)
docs.text:
• Usually 3-5mm
  • Too much → transfer metatarsalgia, floating toe
  • Too little → persistent pain
  • Consider 1-2mm less shortening than preoperatively planned

docs.title: Avoid Over-Treatment
docs.text:
• Don't shorten multiple metatarsals excessively
  • Risk of transfer lesion or generalized forefoot pain

docs.title: Isolated Weil Osteotomy
docs.text:
Weeks 0-2: - Surgical shoe with stiff sole - Heel or midfoot weight-bearing - Avoid direct forefoot pressure - Elevation, ice

Weeks 2-6: - Continue surgical shoe - Progressive weight-bearing - Toe ROM exercises (combat stiffness)

Weeks 6-8: - Transition to wide, stiff-soled shoe - Full weight-bearing

Months 3-6: - Return to normal activities - Continue orthotic use

docs.title: With Bunion/Hammer Toe Correction
docs.text:
• Follow protocol for primary procedure
  • Usually more restrictive initially

docs.title: With Plantar Plate Repair
docs.text:
Weeks 0-6: - Surgical shoe or CAM boot - Non- or protected weight-bearing - K-wire if placed (remove at 4-6 weeks)

Weeks 6-12: - Progressive weight-bearing - ROM exercises

docs.title: Weil Osteotomy Specific
docs.text:
• Stiffness (20-40%): Most common complication
  • Early ROM exercises critical

  • May be permanent

  • Floating toe (5-15%): Toe doesn't contact ground

  • Due to over-shortening or extensor tightness

  • Functional but cosmetic issue

  • Transfer metatarsalgia (5-10%): Pain shifts to adjacent MT

  • Due to over-shortening

  • Recurrence (10-15%)

  • Nonunion (rare, <5%)
  • Malunion

docs.title: General Complications
docs.text:
• Infection (2-5%)
  • Wound healing problems
  • Nerve injury (numbness)
  • Persistent pain despite surgery (10-20%)
  • Scar tissue
  • Complex regional pain syndrome (rare)

docs.title: By Procedure
docs.text: Procedure Success Rate Satisfaction Complications Bunion correction (for transfer metatarsalgia) 80-90% 85% Specific to bunion surgery Weil osteotomy 70-85% 70-80% Stiffness 20-40%, floating toe 5-15% Hammer toe correction 75-90% 80% Specific to procedure Plantar plate repair 70-85% 75% Stiffness, recurrence Gastrocnemius recession 70-80% 75% Sural nerve injury, weakness

docs.title: General Outcomes
docs.text:
• Patient satisfaction: 70-85%
  • Pain improvement: Most improve, but complete resolution uncommon
  • Orthotic use: Often still needed postoperatively
  • Return to activity: 3-6 months

docs.title: Key Surgical Principles
docs.text:
1. Surgery addresses the cause, not just the symptom
  2. Most commonly: Correct associated deformities (bunion, hammer toes)
  3. Isolated metatarsal osteotomy: Reserved for structural abnormality
  4. Weil osteotomy: Reliable but high stiffness rate
  5. Don't over-shorten: Risk of transfer metatarsalgia, floating toe
  6. Early ROM exercises: Critical to prevent stiffness
  7. Set realistic expectations: May not completely resolve pain
  8. Orthotics often still needed postoperatively

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Recurrence
  • Transfer metatarsalgia
  • Floating toe (if symptomatic)
  • Malunion/nonunion
  • Persistent pain

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• Revision osteotomy
  • Correct adjacent metatarsals
  • Address missed pathology
  • Arthrodesis (salvage)

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text:
• Less predictable than primary surgery
  • 50-70% success rate

docs.title: Multiple MT Involvement
docs.text:
• May need to address multiple metatarsals
  • Higher risk of complications
  • More prolonged recovery

docs.title: Older Patients
docs.text:
• Consider less aggressive surgery
  • Continue orthotic management
  • Surgery if severe disability only

docs.title: Athletes
docs.text:
• May need surgery earlier if competitive
  • Return to sports 4-6 months
  • May not return to pre-injury level

docs.title: Rheumatoid Arthritis
docs.text:
• Pan-MT head involvement common
  • May need more extensive surgery
  • Resection arthroplasty or arthrodesis
  • Address 1st ray (bunion, hallux rigidus) simultaneously

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
1. Surgery for metatarsalgia primarily addresses underlying cause, not isolated forefoot pain
  2. Most common surgeries: Bunion correction, hammer toe correction (for secondary metatarsalgia)
  3. Weil osteotomy for primary metatarsalgia or metatarsal length discrepancy
  4. High stiffness rate with Weil (20-40%) - early ROM critical
  5. Set realistic expectations: Complete pain resolution uncommon
  6. Orthotics often needed even after surgery
  7. Success rate: 70-85% overall, depends on cause
  8. Consider surgery only after 6-12 months failed conservative treatment

docs.title: Clinical Presentation
docs.text:
• Sharp, burning pain in forefoot, typically 3rd-4th interspace
  • Radiates to toes (typically 3rd and 4th toes)
  • Numbness/tingling in adjacent toes
  • Worse with: Tight shoes, high heels, prolonged standing
  • Better with: Shoe removal, foot massage
  • "Walking on a pebble" sensation
  • Intermittent symptoms initially, may become constant

docs.title: Anatomy and Pathophysiology
docs.text:
• Intermetatarsal (Morton's) Neuroma: Not a true neuroma, but perineural fibrosis
  • Location: Most common in 3rd interspace (3rd-4th web space), also 2nd interspace
  • Etiology: Repetitive compression of digital nerve under transverse metatarsal ligament
  • Risk Factors:
  • Tight, narrow shoes
  • High heels (>2 inches)
  • Repetitive forefoot loading
  • Foot deformities (bunion, hammer toes, flatfoot)
  • Hypermobility of metatarsals

docs.title: Clinical History
docs.text:
• Pain location: Between metatarsals, radiating to toes
  • Shoe type: Worse in tight or high-heeled shoes
  • Activity: Worse with walking, standing
  • Relief: Removing shoes, massage

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
• Mulder's Click:
  • Squeeze metatarsals together with one hand
  • Compress interspace with other hand

  • Palpable "click" with pain reproduction = positive

  • Tenderness: Plantar interspace (not metatarsal head)

  • Numbness: Adjacent sides of affected toes
  • Metatarsal squeeze test: Pain with medial-lateral compression
  • Toe spread test: Unable to abduct affected toes apart
  • Assess for:
  • Bunion, hammer toes (contribute to narrow toe box)
  • Flatfoot deformity
  • Calluses (metatarsalgia)

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• X-ray (Weight-bearing AP and lateral):
  • Rule out fracture, arthritis, Freiberg's disease

  • Usually normal in Morton's neuroma

  • Ultrasound:

  • Can visualize neuroma (>5mm suggestive)
  • Operator-dependent

  • Good sensitivity/specificity

  • MRI:

  • High sensitivity for neuroma
  • Useful if diagnosis uncertain
  • Expense usually not warranted

docs.title: Differential Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Metatarsalgia: Pain at metatarsal heads, not interspace
  • Stress fracture: Point tenderness over MT shaft
  • Freiberg's disease: 2nd MT head osteonecrosis (visible on X-ray)
  • MTP synovitis or capsulitis
  • Intermetatarsal bursitis
  • Tarsal tunnel syndrome: Medial ankle symptoms, Tinel's sign
  • Plantar plate tear: Instability, drawer test positive

docs.title: Success Rate
docs.text:
• 50-80% improve with conservative treatment
  • Better results if symptoms <6 months

docs.title: 1. Footwear Modification (Most Important)
docs.text:
• Wide toe box: Reduce compression
  • Low heel height: <2 inches, reduces forefoot pressure
  • Soft, cushioned sole: Shock absorption
  • Lace-up shoes: Better adjustability
  • Avoid: Narrow, pointed toe shoes; high heels

docs.title: 2. Orthotic Management
docs.text:
• Metatarsal pad: Place proximal to metatarsal heads
  • Spreads metatarsals apart
  • Reduces compression on nerve

  • Critical: Must be positioned correctly (proximal to MT heads)

  • Cushioned insoles: Shock absorption

  • Custom orthotics: If biomechanical abnormalities (flatfoot)

docs.title: 3. Activity Modification
docs.text:
• Reduce high-impact activities
  • Avoid prolonged standing
  • Cross-training (swimming, cycling)

docs.title: 4. Pharmacological Management
docs.text:
• NSAIDs: Oral or topical
  • Neuropathic pain medications (if refractory):
  • Gabapentin
  • Pregabalin
  • Limited evidence

docs.title: 5. Injection Therapy
docs.text:
Corticosteroid Injection: - Inject into interspace (plantar or dorsal approach) - Success: 30-50% long-term relief - Can repeat up to 2-3 times - Risks: Fat pad atrophy (plantar approach), skin depigmentation

Alcohol Sclerosing Injections: - Series of 4-7 injections (4% alcohol) - Ablates nerve - Success: 60-90% in some studies - Less invasive than surgery - Not widely available

Technique: - Dorsal approach preferred (avoid fat pad) - 23-25 gauge needle - 1-2 mL mixture (steroid + lidocaine)

docs.title: Treatment Protocol
docs.text:
Phase 1 (0-6 weeks): - Footwear modification - Metatarsal pad - NSAIDs

Phase 2 (6-12 weeks): - If no improvement: Corticosteroid injection - Continue footwear/orthotic modifications

Phase 3 (3-6 months): - If no improvement: Consider alcohol injections (if available) - Or proceed to surgery

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Footwear is critical: Avoid narrow, high-heeled shoes lifelong
  • Metatarsal pad positioning: Must be proximal to metatarsal heads
  • Injections: Temporary relief, not curative
  • Surgery: Consider if no improvement after 3-6 months
  • Recurrence: Can occur even after treatment
  • Natural history: May worsen without treatment

docs.title: What to Avoid
docs.text:
• High heels >2 inches
  • Tight, narrow toe box shoes
  • Prolonged barefoot walking (lack of cushioning)
  • High-impact activities without proper footwear

docs.title: When to Consider Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (minimum 3-6 months)
  • Significant pain limiting activities
  • Progressive symptoms
  • Inability to modify footwear adequately (occupation)
  • Multiple failed injections

docs.title: Follow-up
docs.text:
• Reassess at 6 weeks after starting treatment
  • If no improvement, consider injection
  • Reassess 3-6 months after injection
  • Discuss surgery if conservative treatment fails

docs.title: Multiple Neuromas
docs.text:
• May have neuromas in multiple interspaces
  • Less responsive to conservative treatment
  • Higher failure rate with surgery

docs.title: Occupation-Related
docs.text:
• Jobs requiring narrow dress shoes (flight attendants, servers)
  • May need earlier surgical intervention

docs.title: Athletes
docs.text:
• High-impact sports may exacerbate
  • Adequate footwear critical
  • May need activity modification

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
1. Footwear modification is the most important non-surgical treatment
  2. Wide toe box, low heels are essential
  3. Metatarsal pad must be positioned correctly (proximal to MT heads)
  4. Injections provide relief in 30-50%, but often temporary
  5. 50-80% improve with conservative treatment
  6. Better results if symptoms <6 months
  7. Surgery if failed conservative treatment for 3-6 months

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (minimum 3-6 months)
  • Significant pain limiting activities of daily living
  • Failed corticosteroid injections (at least 1-2 attempts)
  • Progressive symptoms
  • Unable to modify footwear adequately
  • Diagnostic nerve block provides relief (confirms diagnosis)

docs.title: Confirm Diagnosis
docs.text:
• Diagnostic nerve block: Should provide significant relief
  • If no relief → reconsider diagnosis
  • Rule out alternative diagnoses (metatarsalgia, Freiberg's, MTP synovitis)

docs.title: Patient Selection
docs.text:
• Realistic expectations
  • Willing to comply with postoperative restrictions
  • Appropriate footwear expectations

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• Weight-bearing X-rays to rule out other pathology
  • MRI or ultrasound may help confirm neuroma and size

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Standard treatment for refractory Morton's neuroma
  • Most predictable results

docs.title: Approach Options
docs.text:
A. Dorsal Approach (Most Common) - Advantages: - Better visualization - Can excise nerve more proximally - Avoids plantar scar (no weight-bearing pain from scar) - Less risk of plantar fat pad injury

  • Disadvantages:
  • Must release deep transverse metatarsal ligament
  • Slightly longer dissection

Technique: - Longitudinal incision between metatarsals (dorsal) - Retract extensor tendons - Divide deep transverse metatarsal ligament - Identify and trace nerve proximally - Excise neuroma with 1-2 cm of normal nerve proximally - Leave nerve end in intermetatarsal space (not subcutaneous)

B. Plantar Approach - Advantages: - Direct access to neuroma - Don't need to release ligament

  • Disadvantages:
  • Plantar scar: Risk of painful scar with weight-bearing
  • Less popular for this reason

Technique: - Transverse or longitudinal incision between MT heads (plantar) - Identify and excise neuroma - Ensure adequate proximal excision

Preferred: Most surgeons favor dorsal approach due to avoiding plantar scar.

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text:
• Success (good to excellent): 75-90%
  • Symptom relief: 80-85%
  • Recurrence/persistent pain: 10-25%
  • Permanent numbness: 100% (expected, usually not bothersome)
  • Painful stump neuroma: 5-10%
  • Return to activity: 6-12 weeks

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Desire to preserve sensation
  • Patient preference to avoid numbness
  • Early/mild neuromas

docs.title: Technique
docs.text:
• Release deep transverse metatarsal ligament only
  • Decompress nerve without excising
  • May combine with metatarsal osteotomy if excessive weight-bearing

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text:
• Less predictable than neurectomy
  • Success: 50-70%
  • Preserves sensation (advantage)
  • Higher recurrence rate than excision

docs.title: Disadvantages
docs.text:
• Less reliable pain relief
  • May need later neurectomy

Generally less favored than neurectomy due to lower success rate.

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Alternative to neurectomy
  • Minimally invasive option

docs.title: Technique
docs.text:
• Percutaneous or open approach
  • Freeze nerve with cryoprobe (-50 to -70°C)
  • Causes Wallerian degeneration

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text:
• Success: 60-80% (variable in literature)
  • Less invasive
  • May require repeat treatment
  • Limited long-term data

docs.title: Technique
docs.text:
• Heat ablation of nerve
  • Can be done percutaneously

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text:
• Limited evidence
  • Not widely used

docs.title: Decision Making: Neurectomy vs. Decompression
docs.text:
Factor Neurectomy Decompression Success rate 75-90% 50-70% Predictability High Lower Sensation Permanent numbness Preserved Recurrence Lower Higher Revision if fails Difficult Convert to neurectomy Recommendation Gold standard Alternative option

Most surgeons favor neurectomy due to higher success rate and predictability.

docs.title: Neurectomy (Dorsal Approach)
docs.text:
Weeks 0-2: - Surgical shoe or CAM boot - Weight-bearing as tolerated - Elevation, ice - Dressing changes

Weeks 2-4: - Progress to stiff-soled shoe - Increase activity - Sutures removed at 2 weeks

Weeks 4-6: - Transition to regular shoe (wide toe box) - Avoid narrow shoes, high heels

Weeks 6-12: - Gradual return to activities - Full return to activity 8-12 weeks

docs.title: Plantar Approach
docs.text:
• Similar protocol
  • May limit weight-bearing more initially (protect incision)
  • Scar massage after healing

docs.title: Intraoperative
docs.text:
• Injury to adjacent structures (digital arteries, nerves)
  • Incomplete excision

docs.title: Early Postoperative
docs.text:
• Wound healing problems (3-5%)
  • Infection (1-2%)
  • Hematoma

docs.title: Late Postoperative
docs.text:
• Persistent pain (10-20%):
  • Incorrect diagnosis
  • Incomplete excision
  • Adjacent neuroma (different interspace)

  • Stump neuroma

  • Permanent numbness (100%, expected):

  • Adjacent toes (e.g., 3rd and 4th toes for 3rd interspace)
  • Usually not bothersome

  • Counsel preoperatively

  • Stump neuroma (5-10%):

  • Painful neuroma at proximal cut end

  • May require revision surgery

  • Plantar scar pain (10-20% if plantar approach):

  • Painful with weight-bearing

  • Reason to favor dorsal approach

  • Transfer metatarsalgia (5%):

  • If ligament released, metatarsals may splay

  • Recurrence (5-15%)

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Persistent or recurrent pain after neurectomy
  • Stump neuroma
  • Missed additional neuroma

docs.title: Workup
docs.text:
• Confirm diagnosis with nerve block
  • MRI or ultrasound to identify stump neuroma
  • Rule out other causes (stress fracture, metatarsalgia)

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• Re-excision with proximal dissection:
  • Trace nerve more proximally
  • Excise farther proximal to get beyond scar tissue

  • Bury nerve stump in muscle (interosseous)

  • Neuromas buried in bone: Limited evidence

  • Targeted muscle reinnervation: Emerging technique
  • Nerve capping devices: Limited evidence

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text:
• Less predictable than primary surgery
  • 50-70% success rate

docs.title: Outcomes by Approach
docs.text: Approach Success Rate Numbness Plantar Scar Recurrence Dorsal neurectomy 75-90% Yes (expected) No 10-15% Plantar neurectomy 70-85% Yes (expected) Yes (risk) 10-15% Decompression 50-70% No No 20-30% Cryoablation 60-80% Variable No Variable

docs.title: Key Surgical Principles
docs.text:
1. Dorsal approach preferred: Avoids plantar scar
  2. Adequate proximal excision: Get 1-2 cm of normal nerve
  3. Confirm diagnosis preoperatively: Nerve block should provide relief
  4. Neurectomy > Decompression: Higher success rate
  5. Counsel about numbness: Permanent, usually not bothersome
  6. Leave nerve stump deep: Not subcutaneous (avoid painful stump)
  7. Multiple neuromas: Address all symptomatic interspaces

docs.title: Multiple Neuromas
docs.text:
• Can address multiple interspaces simultaneously
  • Higher recurrence rate
  • More extensive numbness
  • Counsel patients appropriately

docs.title: Failed Prior Surgery
docs.text:
• Stump neuroma vs. incorrect diagnosis
  • Diagnostic nerve block critical
  • Revision surgery less predictable

docs.title: Athletes
docs.text:
• Return to sports 8-12 weeks
  • Numbness usually not functionally significant
  • High success rate with surgery

docs.title: Expectations
docs.text:
• Pain relief: 80-85% good to excellent
  • Numbness: Permanent, expected (between affected toes)
  • Return to activity: 8-12 weeks
  • Footwear: Still need to avoid very narrow shoes, high heels
  • Recurrence: 10-15% may have persistent symptoms

docs.title: Decision Making
docs.text:
• Surgery if failed 3-6 months conservative treatment
  • High success rate (75-90%)
  • Numbness is trade-off for pain relief
  • Most patients satisfied despite numbness

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
1. Neurectomy (dorsal approach) is gold standard
  2. 75-90% success rate with neurectomy
  3. Permanent numbness is expected and usually acceptable
  4. Dorsal approach preferred over plantar (avoids weight-bearing scar)
  5. Adequate proximal excision reduces stump neuroma risk
  6. Decompression has lower success rate, less predictable
  7. Confirm diagnosis with nerve block before surgery
  8. Most patients satisfied despite permanent numbness

docs.title: Hindfoot Pathology
docs.text: 後足部の主要な病態について、頻度順に整理しています。

docs.title: Common Conditions (by Frequency)
docs.text:
1. Ankle Osteoarthritis - Most common degenerative condition
  2. Osteochondral Defect (OCD) - Common in young athletes
  3. Achilles Tendinopathy - Frequent overuse injury
  4. Ankle Instability - Common after ankle sprains

docs.title: Anatomical Considerations
docs.text: The hindfoot includes: - Ankle joint (tibiotalar joint) - Subtalar joint - Achilles tendon complex

docs.title: Clinical Approach
docs.text: Each pathology in this section covers: - Diagnostic workup - Non-surgical management - Surgical indications and techniques

docs.title: Clinical Presentation
docs.text:
• Posterior heel pain, 2-6 cm proximal to insertion
  • Morning stiffness
  • Pain with activity that may improve with warm-up
  • Pain after activity
  • Thickened, tender tendon

docs.title: Insertional Tendinopathy
docs.text:
• Pain at calcaneal insertion
  • Associated with Haglund's deformity
  • Calcification within tendon

docs.title: Non-insertional (Midsubstance) Tendinopathy
docs.text:
• Pain 2-6 cm proximal to insertion
  • Nodular thickening
  • More common

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
• Palpable nodule or thickening
  • Tenderness to palpation
  • Pain with resisted plantarflexion
  • Decreased strength
  • Assess for gastroc tightness (>10° dorsiflexion deficit)

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• X-ray: Calcaneal spurring (insertional), calcification
  • Ultrasound: Thickening, hypoechoic areas, neovascularization
  • MRI: Reserved for surgical planning or differential diagnosis

docs.title: Phase 1: Acute Management (0-2 weeks)
docs.text:
• Relative rest (avoid aggravating activities)
  • Ice 15-20 minutes, 3-4x daily
  • NSAIDs (controversial - may impair healing)
  • Heel lift (temporarily reduce strain)

docs.title: Phase 2: Progressive Loading (2-12 weeks)
docs.text: Eccentric Exercise Protocol (Alfredson Protocol) - 3 sets of 15 reps, twice daily - Straight knee (gastrocnemius) - Bent knee (soleus) - Gradual increase in load

docs.title: Phase 3: Return to Activity (3-6 months)
docs.text:
• Sport-specific training
  • Progressive running program
  • Maintain strengthening

docs.title: Additional Modalities
docs.text:
• Physical Therapy
  • Eccentric strengthening
  • Gastrocnemius stretching
  • Deep tissue massage

  • Gait analysis and correction

  • Extracorporeal Shockwave Therapy (ESWT)

  • Moderate evidence for chronic cases

  • 3-5 sessions over weeks

  • Injection Therapy (controversial)

  • PRP (platelet-rich plasma): mixed evidence
  • Avoid corticosteroids (risk of rupture)

docs.title: Orthotic Management
docs.text:
• Heel lift to reduce strain
  • Proper footwear with cushioned heel
  • Avoid flat shoes

docs.title: Success Rates
docs.text:
• 70-80% improve with eccentric exercises
  • May take 3-6 months to see results
  • Chronic cases (>6 months) more resistant

docs.title: Patient Education
docs.text:
• Avoid "pushing through pain"
  • Compliance with exercises critical
  • Long recovery timeframe
  • Avoid steroid injections
  • Risk of progression to rupture if untreated

docs.title: Follow-up
docs.text:
• Reassess at 6-12 weeks
  • If no improvement after 3-6 months conservative treatment, consider surgery

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (minimum 6 months)
  • Significant functional limitation
  • Chronic, recalcitrant pain
  • Large tendon tear (>50%)

docs.title: 1. Open Debridement with/without FHL Transfer
docs.text:
For Non-Insertional Tendinopathy:

Technique: - Posteromedial longitudinal incision - Identify and debride diseased tissue - If >50% tendon debrided: FHL transfer for reinforcement - Repair remaining healthy tendon

FHL Transfer Technique: - Harvest FHL through same incision - Create tunnel in calcaneus - Transfer and secure with interference screw or suture anchor

Outcomes: - 80-90% good to excellent results - Return to activity 4-6 months - FHL transfer when needed: 85-95% success

docs.title: 2. Insertional Tendinopathy Repair
docs.text:
Technique: - Midline or medial longitudinal incision - Detach Achilles insertion - Resect calcaneal prominence (Haglund's) - Excise calcification and diseased tissue - Create bone trough in calcaneus - Reattach tendon with suture anchors

Outcomes: - 75-90% satisfaction - Higher complication rate than midsubstance - Wound healing issues more common

docs.title: 3. Minimally Invasive Options
docs.text:
Gastrocnemius Recession: - For isolated gastrocnemius contracture - Strayer (intramuscular) or Baumann (aponeurotic) recession - Can be combined with debridement

Percutaneous Longitudinal Tenotomies: - Multiple longitudinal incisions in tendon - Stimulates healing response - Limited evidence

Outcomes: - Less invasive - Faster recovery - May be inadequate for severe cases

docs.title: Decision Making
docs.text:
Tendinopathy Type:
├─ Non-insertional + <50% involvement
│  └─ Open debridement
├─ Non-insertional + >50% involvement
│  └─ Open debridement + FHL transfer
├─ Insertional + bone spur
│  └─ Detachment, spur resection, repair
└─ With gastrocnemius contracture
   └─ Add gastrocnemius recession

docs.title: FHL Transfer
docs.text:
Indications: - >50% tendon excision - Chronic rupture repair - Revision surgery

Advantages: - Strong transfer (toe flexor) - In-phase with Achilles - Minimal donor morbidity

Disadvantages: - Loss of great toe push-off strength (usually minimal) - Technically demanding

docs.title: Haglund's Deformity
docs.text:
• Resect adequate bone without destabilizing insertion
  • Smooth bone edges
  • May need calcaneal osteotomy if severe

docs.title: Weeks 0-2
docs.text:
• Posterior splint in equinus
  • Non-weight bearing
  • Wound care

docs.title: Weeks 2-6
docs.text:
• CAM boot in equinus (20-30° plantarflexion)
  • Non-weight bearing
  • Begin gentle ankle pumps

docs.title: Weeks 6-8
docs.text:
• Progress boot to neutral
  • Begin protected weight-bearing
  • ROM exercises

docs.title: Weeks 8-12
docs.text:
• Full weight-bearing in boot
  • Progressive strengthening
  • Wean from boot

docs.title: Months 3-6
docs.text:
• Running program begins at 4 months
  • Sports at 6 months
  • Full return to activity 6-12 months

If FHL Transfer: - More conservative progression - Non-weight bearing 4 weeks - Full activity 9-12 months

docs.title: Complications
docs.text:
• Wound healing problems (10-15% insertional)
  • Sural nerve injury
  • Re-rupture (rare with proper rehab)
  • Persistent pain or stiffness
  • Weakness
  • Deep venous thrombosis

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text: Procedure Success Rate Return to Sport Satisfaction Midsubstance debridement 80-90% 4-6 months 85-90% + FHL transfer 85-95% 6-9 months 90% Insertional repair 75-90% 6-9 months 75-85% Gastrocnemius recession 70-80% 3-4 months 80%

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Surgery reserved for chronic cases failing 6+ months conservative treatment
  • FHL transfer for large defects improves outcomes
  • Insertional repair has higher complication rate
  • Patient selection and realistic expectations crucial
  • Prolonged rehabilitation required

docs.title: Clinical Presentation
docs.text:
• Recurrent ankle "giving way"
  • Feeling of instability, especially on uneven ground
  • Recurrent swelling after minor injury
  • Chronic pain or achiness
  • History of significant ankle sprain

docs.title: Mechanical Instability
docs.text:
• Objective ligamentous laxity
  • Positive stress tests
  • Documented on imaging

docs.title: Functional Instability
docs.text:
• Subjective instability
  • Normal stress tests
  • Proprioceptive deficit

docs.title: Ligaments Involved
docs.text:
• ATFL (anterior talofibular) - most common, injured first
  • CFL (calcaneofibular) - injured with more severe sprains
  • PTFL (posterior talofibular) - rarely injured in isolation

docs.title: History
docs.text:
• Mechanism of initial injury
  • Frequency of giving way episodes
  • Activities that provoke instability
  • Previous treatment and response

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
• Anterior Drawer Test
  • ATFL integrity

  • 5mm anterior translation = positive

  • Side-to-side comparison

  • Talar Tilt Test

  • CFL integrity

  • 10° difference compared to contralateral = positive

  • Subtalar Instability

  • Medial-lateral drawer

  • Peroneal Strength

  • Often weak on affected side

  • Single Leg Stance

  • Assessment of proprioception

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• X-ray: Weight-bearing AP, lateral, mortise
  • Rule out bony injury, arthritis, osteochondral lesion

  • May show talar tilt or OCD

  • Stress X-rays (rarely done now)

  • Anterior drawer or talar tilt under stress

  • MRI

  • Evaluate ligaments, osteochondral lesions
  • High-grade tears, bone edema
  • Not always necessary for clinical diagnosis

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• First-time instability
  • Functional instability without mechanical laxity
  • Low-demand patients
  • Willing to modify activities

docs.title: Phase 1: Acute Management (if recent sprain)
docs.text:
• RICE protocol (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation)
  • Protected weight-bearing with brace
  • NSAIDs for pain/swelling

docs.title: Phase 2: Rehabilitation (Primary Treatment)
docs.text:
1. Proprioception Training (Most Important) - Single leg stance - Balance board exercises - Progression to unstable surfaces - Eyes closed progression

2. Peroneal Strengthening - Resistance band eversion exercises - Multi-directional strengthening - Eccentric exercises - Progress to functional movements

3. Range of Motion - Ankle pumps, circles - Gastrocnemius/soleus stretching - Joint mobilization

4. Functional Training - Sport-specific drills - Agility exercises - Plyometrics - Return to sport progression

docs.title: Phase 3: Maintenance
docs.text:
• Continue proprioception exercises
  • Maintain peroneal strength
  • Bracing for high-risk activities

docs.title: Bracing Options
docs.text:
• Lace-up ankle brace: Good support, adjustable
  • Semi-rigid brace: Maximum support
  • Taping: Temporary support for sports
  • Prophylactic bracing for high-risk sports

docs.title: Success Rates
docs.text:
• 50-80% of patients improve with structured rehabilitation
  • Better results in functional vs. mechanical instability
  • Compliance with exercises critical
  • May take 3-6 months for full benefit

docs.title: Patient Education
docs.text:
• Natural history: Risk of recurrent sprains without treatment
  • Importance of proprioceptive training
  • Bracing may be needed long-term for sports
  • Risk of developing arthritis with repeated sprains
  • Surgery option if conservative treatment fails

docs.title: When to Consider Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed rehabilitation (minimum 3-6 months)
  • Mechanical instability with continued episodes
  • High-demand athlete
  • Associated pathology (OCD, arthritis)

docs.title: Follow-up
docs.text:
• Reassess at 6-12 weeks
  • Ensure compliance with exercises
  • Adjust program based on progress
  • Discuss surgical options if no improvement at 3-6 months

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (minimum 3-6 months structured rehab)
  • Recurrent instability affecting quality of life
  • Mechanical instability with objective laxity
  • High-demand athletes
  • Associated pathology requiring surgery (OCD, arthritis)

docs.title: Patient Selection
docs.text:
• Realistic expectations
  • Willing to complete rehabilitation
  • Appropriate activity level
  • No significant arthritis

docs.title: Associated Pathology (Common)
docs.text:
• Osteochondral defects (25%)
  • Peroneal tendon pathology
  • Bone impingement
  • Must address these at time of surgery

docs.title: Broström Procedure (Gold Standard)
docs.text:
Technique: - Direct repair of ATFL and CFL - Advance and imbricate torn ligaments - Anchor to fibula

Gould Modification: - Add inferior extensor retinaculum reinforcement - Improved strength

Indications: - Primary reconstruction - Good tissue quality - Normal BMI - Normal alignment

Outcomes: - 85-95% good to excellent results - Return to sport 3-6 months - Low recurrence rate (5-10%) - Preserves normal ankle kinematics

docs.title: Broström-Gould with Suture Tape Augmentation
docs.text:
Technique: - Standard Broström repair - Add internal brace (suture tape) for reinforcement - Allows earlier mobilization

Advantages: - Potentially faster recovery - Additional security - May allow earlier weight-bearing

Outcomes: - Similar to standard Broström (limited long-term data) - May reduce re-rupture risk

docs.title: Chrisman-Snook Procedure
docs.text:
Technique: - Split peroneus brevis tendon - Route through fibula and calcaneus - Recreate ATFL and CFL

Indications: - Revision surgery - Poor tissue quality - Failed Broström - Cavovarus foot

Disadvantages: - Altered ankle kinematics - Potential stiffness - Peroneal weakness

Outcomes: - 70-85% good results - Higher stiffness rate - Reserved for salvage

docs.title: 3. Arthroscopic-Assisted Repair
docs.text:
Technique: - Arthroscopy first: evaluate and treat intra-articular pathology - Then perform open or percutaneous Broström

Advantages: - Address OCD, loose bodies, synovitis - Comprehensive treatment

Outcomes: - Comparable to open Broström - Advantage of addressing intra-articular pathology

docs.title: Decision Algorithm
docs.text:
First-time Surgery + Good Tissue:
└─ Broström-Gould (± suture tape augmentation)

Revision Surgery or Poor Tissue:
└─ Non-anatomic reconstruction (Chrisman-Snook)

Associated OCD/Intra-articular Pathology:
└─ Arthroscopic-assisted Broström

Cavovarus Deformity:
└─ Correct deformity first, then Broström or tendon transfer

docs.title: Address Underlying Deformity
docs.text:
• Cavovarus foot: Calcaneal osteotomy, plantar fascia release
  • Valgus hindfoot: Correct with osteotomy
  • Gastrocnemius contracture: Recession

docs.title: Treat Associated Pathology
docs.text:
• OCD: Microfracture, OAT
  • Synovitis: Synovectomy
  • Bone impingement: Remove anterolateral osteophytes
  • Peroneal pathology: Debride, repair if needed

docs.title: Standard Broström-Gould
docs.text:
Weeks 0-2: - Posterior splint - Non-weight bearing - Elevation, ice

Weeks 2-6: - CAM boot - Non-weight bearing weeks 2-4 - Protected weight-bearing weeks 4-6 - Begin gentle ankle ROM

Weeks 6-8: - Wean from boot - Progressive weight-bearing - Increase ROM exercises

Weeks 8-12: - Strengthening program - Proprioception training - Pool exercises, bike

Months 3-6: - Running progression at 3-4 months - Sport-specific training - Return to sports at 4-6 months

docs.title: With Suture Tape Augmentation
docs.text:
• May allow earlier weight-bearing (week 2-4)
  • Otherwise similar protocol

docs.title: Tendon Transfer (Chrisman-Snook)
docs.text:
• More conservative protocol
  • Non-weight bearing 4-6 weeks
  • Slower return to activities (6-9 months)

docs.title: Complications
docs.text:
• Recurrent instability (5-10% Broström, higher with tenodesis)
  • Stiffness (more common with tenodesis)
  • Peroneal weakness
  • Sural nerve injury (numbness lateral foot)
  • Wound healing problems
  • Complex regional pain syndrome (rare)
  • Over-tightening causing pain

docs.title: Outcomes by Procedure
docs.text: Procedure Success Rate Recurrence Return to Sport Patient Satisfaction Broström 85-95% 5-10% 4-6 months 90-95% Broström + Augmentation 90-95% 5% 3-5 months 90-95% Chrisman-Snook 70-85% 10-15% 6-9 months 75-85%

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• Broström-Gould is gold standard for primary reconstruction
  • Arthroscopy helps identify and treat associated pathology (25% have OCD)
  • Must address underlying deformity (cavovarus)
  • Rehabilitation compliance critical for success
  • Suture tape augmentation may allow faster recovery
  • Tendon transfers reserved for revision or poor tissue

docs.title: Clinical Presentation
docs.text:
• Pain with weight-bearing and activity
  • Stiffness, especially in the morning
  • Decreased range of motion
  • History of previous trauma (80% of cases)

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
• Decreased dorsiflexion/plantarflexion
  • Pain at end range of motion
  • Joint line tenderness
  • Palpable osteophytes

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• Weight-bearing AP, lateral, mortise views
  • Look for joint space narrowing, osteophytes, subchondral cysts
  • CT for preoperative planning
  • MRI if osteochondral lesion suspected

docs.title: 1. Activity Modification
docs.text:
• Avoid high-impact activities
  • Low-impact exercise (swimming, cycling)
  • Weight loss if indicated

docs.title: 2. Pharmacological Management
docs.text:
• NSAIDs (oral or topical)
  • Acetaminophen
  • Intra-articular corticosteroid injection (temporary relief)

docs.title: 3. Orthotic Management
docs.text:
• Rocker-bottom shoe modifications
  • Ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) for severe cases
  • Custom insoles with cushioning

docs.title: 4. Physical Therapy
docs.text:
• Range of motion exercises
  • Strengthening of surrounding muscles
  • Gait training
  • Modalities (ice, ultrasound)

docs.title: Patient Education
docs.text:
• Natural history: Progressive condition
  • Treatment goals: Pain relief, maintain function
  • Realistic expectations about activity level
  • When to consider surgical options

docs.title: Follow-up
docs.text:
• Reassess at 3-6 months
  • Monitor symptom progression
  • Adjust treatment as needed
  • Discuss surgical options if conservative management fails

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative management (minimum 3-6 months)
  • Significant pain limiting activities of daily living
  • Progressive deformity
  • Radiographic evidence of advanced arthritis

docs.title: 1. Ankle Arthroscopy with Debridement
docs.text:
Indications: - Early to moderate arthritis - Mechanical symptoms (loose bodies, osteophytes) - Preserved joint space

Technique: - Remove loose bodies and osteophytes - Synovectomy - Microfracture for small cartilage defects

Outcomes: - Good short-term pain relief (1-2 years) - Best for younger, active patients - May delay need for arthrodesis

docs.title: 2. Ankle Arthrodesis (Gold Standard)
docs.text:
Indications: - End-stage ankle arthritis - Failed previous surgery - Reliable option for manual laborers

Technique: - Open, arthroscopic, or arthroscopic-assisted - Remove cartilage, position in neutral/slight valgus - Fixation: screws, plate, or intramedullary nail

Positioning: - Neutral dorsiflexion - 5° valgus - Slight external rotation

Outcomes: - 90-95% fusion rate - Excellent pain relief - May develop adjacent joint arthritis over time

docs.title: 3. Total Ankle Replacement (TAR)
docs.text:
Indications: - End-stage arthritis - Adequate bone stock - No significant deformity - Patient desires preserved motion

Contraindications: - Active infection - Avascular necrosis of talus - Neuropathy - Severe deformity (>15-20°)

Technique: - Anterior approach - Bone cuts with alignment guides - Insert prosthetic components

Outcomes: - Preserves ankle motion - Good pain relief - 10-year survival: 70-80% - Higher revision rate than arthrodesis

docs.title: Decision Making
docs.text: Factor Arthrodesis TAR Age Any age <75 years preferred Activity Manual labor, high-impact Low-impact activities Adjacent joints Arthritic Normal Bone quality Any Good Deformity Any Minimal (<15°)

docs.title: Arthrodesis
docs.text:
• Non-weight bearing 6-8 weeks
  • Gradual weight-bearing with boot
  • Full weight-bearing at 12 weeks
  • Return to full activity 6 months

docs.title: TAR
docs.text:
• Non-weight bearing 2 weeks
  • Protected weight-bearing 4-6 weeks
  • Gradual return to activity
  • Avoid high-impact activities lifelong

docs.title: Arthrodesis
docs.text:
• Nonunion (5-10%)
  • Malunion
  • Adjacent joint arthritis
  • Hardware irritation

docs.title: TAR
docs.text:
• Aseptic loosening
  • Subsidence
  • Infection
  • Wound healing problems
  • Instability
  • Component migration

docs.title: Clinical Presentation
docs.text:
• Persistent ankle pain after sprain
  • Deep, aching pain in the ankle
  • Catching or locking sensation
  • Swelling
  • Instability

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
• Point tenderness over talus
  • Pain with dorsiflexion (anterior lesions)
  • Pain with plantarflexion (posterior lesions)
  • Assess for ankle instability

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• X-ray: May show lesion (AP, lateral, mortise)
  • MRI: Gold standard for diagnosis
  • Assess lesion size, location, stability
  • Bone edema pattern
  • CT: Better for bone detail

docs.title: Classification
docs.text:
• Location: Medial vs. lateral talar dome
  • Size: <15mm (small), 15-20mm (medium), >20mm (large)
  • Stability: Stable vs. unstable (on MRI)

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Stable lesions
  • Asymptomatic lesions
  • Small lesions (<15mm)
  • Acute lesions with minimal displacement

docs.title: Phase 1: Rest and Protection (0-6 weeks)
docs.text:
• Non-weight bearing or protected weight-bearing
  • CAM boot or cast
  • Cryotherapy
  • NSAIDs for pain control

docs.title: Phase 2: Progressive Loading (6-12 weeks)
docs.text:
• Gradual return to weight-bearing
  • Range of motion exercises
  • Proprioception training
  • Ankle strengthening

docs.title: Phase 3: Return to Activity (3-6 months)
docs.text:
• Sport-specific training
  • Continue strengthening
  • Gradual return to impact activities

docs.title: Success Rates
docs.text:
• Small, stable lesions: 45-50% healing with non-operative treatment
  • Larger or unstable lesions: Lower success rate

docs.title: Patient Education
docs.text:
• Natural history varies
  • May take 3-6 months to assess healing
  • Some lesions may not heal and require surgery
  • Continued symptoms after 3-6 months indicate surgery may be needed

docs.title: Follow-up
docs.text:
• Repeat MRI at 3-6 months to assess healing
  • If symptoms persist or worsen, consider surgery
  • Monitor for development of arthritis

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (3-6 months)
  • Unstable lesion on MRI
  • Large lesion (>15mm)
  • Symptomatic cyst formation
  • Persistent pain and dysfunction

docs.title: 1. Bone Marrow Stimulation (Microfracture)
docs.text:
Indications: - Lesions <15mm - First-line surgical treatment - Good subchondral bone

Technique: - Arthroscopic approach - Debride unstable cartilage to stable rim - Create multiple perforations in subchondral bone - Induces fibrocartilage formation

Outcomes: - 70-85% good results for lesions <15mm - Results decline with larger lesions - Fibrocartilage (not hyaline cartilage)

docs.title: 2. Osteochondral Autograft Transfer (OAT/OATS)
docs.text:
Indications: - Lesions 10-20mm - Failed microfracture - Requires hyaline cartilage restoration

Technique: - Harvest plugs from ipsilateral knee - Usually need medial malleolar osteotomy for medial lesions - Press-fit plugs into prepared defect

Outcomes: - 85-90% good results - Provides hyaline cartilage - Donor site morbidity (knee pain 5-10%)

docs.title: 3. Osteochondral Allograft
docs.text:
Indications: - Large lesions (>20mm) - Significant bone loss - Salvage procedure

Technique: - Fresh or preserved allograft - Malleolar osteotomy often needed - Secure with screws

Outcomes: - Variable results - Best for large defects - Risk of disease transmission (minimal)

docs.title: 4. Autologous Chondrocyte Implantation (ACI/MACI)
docs.text:
Indications: - Large lesions (>20mm) - Failed previous surgery - Minimal bone loss

Technique: - Two-stage procedure - Stage 1: Harvest chondrocytes arthroscopically - Stage 2 (6-8 weeks later): Implant cultured cells

Outcomes: - 75-85% good results - Expensive - Two surgeries required - Good for large, isolated defects

docs.title: Arthroscopic
docs.text:
• Small to medium anterior/central lesions
  • Minimal morbidity
  • Limited access to posterior lesions

docs.title: Medial Malleolar Osteotomy
docs.text:
• Medial talar dome lesions
  • Excellent exposure
  • 5% nonunion risk

docs.title: Lateral Approach
docs.text:
• Lateral talar dome lesions
  • Through fibula or anterior to fibula

docs.title: Decision Algorithm
docs.text:
Lesion Size:
├─ <15mm → Microfracture
├─ 15-20mm → OAT or Microfracture
└─ >20mm → Allograft or ACI/MACI

Bone Loss:
├─ Minimal → Microfracture, OAT, or ACI
└─ Significant → Allograft

Previous Surgery:
└─ Failed Microfracture → OAT, Allograft, or ACI

docs.title: General Protocol
docs.text:
• Non-weight bearing 6-8 weeks
  • CPM (continuous passive motion) if available
  • Progressive weight-bearing weeks 8-12
  • Return to sports 6-12 months

docs.title: Activity Restrictions
docs.text:
• Avoid high-impact activities initially
  • Gradual return to sport-specific training
  • Full return when strength and ROM restored

docs.title: Outcomes by Procedure
docs.text: Procedure Success Rate Return to Sport Longevity Microfracture 70-85% 6-9 months 5-10 years OAT 85-90% 9-12 months 10+ years Allograft 70-80% 12+ months Variable ACI/MACI 75-85% 12+ months 10+ years

docs.title: Complications
docs.text:
• Persistent pain
  • Ankle stiffness
  • Graft failure or non-incorporation
  • Donor site morbidity (OAT)
  • Osteotomy nonunion
  • Progression to ankle arthritis

docs.title: Midfoot Pathology
docs.text: 中足部の主要な病態について、頻度順に整理しています。

docs.title: Common Conditions (by Frequency)
docs.text:
1. Flatfoot (PTTD) - Most common acquired flatfoot deformity
  2. Lisfranc Injury - Important traumatic condition

docs.title: Anatomical Considerations
docs.text: The midfoot includes: - Tarsometatarsal (Lisfranc) joints - Naviculocuneiform joints - Posterior tibial tendon

docs.title: Clinical Approach
docs.text: Each pathology in this section covers: - Diagnostic workup - Non-surgical management - Surgical indications and techniques

docs.title: Clinical Presentation
docs.text:
• Medial ankle/midfoot pain and swelling
  • Progressive flattening of arch
  • Difficulty with single-limb heel rise
  • Abduction of forefoot ("too many toes" sign)
  • Difficulty walking on uneven terrain

docs.title: Classification: Johnson and Strom (Modified by Myerson)
Stage I
docs.text:
• Tenosynovitis without deformity
  • Pain and swelling along PTT
  • Normal arch height
  • Single heel rise possible (with pain)

docs.title: Stage II
docs.text:
• PTT dysfunction with flexible deformity
  • Loss of arch, hindfoot valgus
  • Forefoot abduction
  • Unable to perform single heel rise
  • IIA: <30% talonavicular uncovering
  • IIB: >40% talonavicular uncovering

docs.title: Stage III
docs.text:
• Fixed (rigid) deformity
  • Cannot correct manually
  • Subtalar arthritis may be present

docs.title: Stage IV
docs.text:
• Valgus ankle arthritis
  • Deltoid insufficiency

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
• Too Many Toes Sign: Forefoot abduction
  • Single Heel Rise Test: Unable or painful
  • Hindfoot Alignment: Valgus
  • Arch Height: Collapsed
  • Flexibility: Assess with Jack test, hindfoot inversion
  • PTT Palpation: Swelling, tenderness along course
  • Strength Testing: Resisted inversion weakness

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• Weight-bearing X-rays (essential)
  • AP, lateral, hindfoot alignment view
  • Lateral: Decreased calcaneal pitch, increased talo-1st MT angle
  • AP: Talonavicular uncovering, increased talus-1st MT angle
  • MRI: Evaluate PTT (hypertrophy, tear, degeneration)

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Stage I disease
  • Stage II with minimal deformity
  • Low-demand patients
  • Medical comorbidities precluding surgery
  • Patient preference

docs.title: 1. Immobilization (Acute Phase)
docs.text:
• CAM boot or short leg cast
  • 4-6 weeks
  • Allow inflammation to settle
  • Non-weight bearing if severe

docs.title: 2. Orthotic Management (Mainstay)
docs.text:
• UCBL (University of California Biomechanics Lab): Rigid, controls hindfoot
  • AFO (Ankle-Foot Orthosis): For Stage III or severe Stage II
  • Custom arch support: Less aggressive, better tolerated
  • Medial heel wedge: Decreases valgus stress

Fitting: - Must be custom-molded - Firm posting at hindfoot - Arch support - Deep heel cup

docs.title: 3. Physical Therapy
docs.text:
• Stretching: Gastrocnemius-soleus complex
  • Strengthening: PTT, intrinsics, invertors
  • Proprioception training
  • Gait training

docs.title: 4. Pharmacological
docs.text:
• NSAIDs for inflammation
  • Activity modification
  • Weight loss if appropriate

docs.title: 5. Injection (Controversial)
docs.text:
• Corticosteroid around (not into) tendon
  • Risk of tendon rupture
  • Generally avoided

docs.title: Brace Options by Stage
docs.text: Stage Orthotic Comments Stage I Medial arch support Off-the-shelf possible Stage IIA UCBL or custom AFO Custom-molded Stage IIB-III Rigid AFO (Arizona, Richie) Controls hindfoot and ankle Stage IV Rigid AFO or KAFO May need knee control

docs.title: Success Rates
docs.text:
• Stage I: 50-90% improve with immobilization and orthotics
  • Stage II: 30-50% adequate symptom relief
  • Stage III-IV: Bracing for symptom control, not corrective

docs.title: Patient Education
docs.text:
• Progressive condition without surgery
  • Orthotic compliance critical
  • May need lifelong bracing
  • Surgery often eventually needed for Stage II-III
  • Risk factors: Obesity, hypertension, diabetes, age, female

docs.title: When to Consider Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (3-6 months minimum)
  • Progressive deformity
  • Inability to brace adequately
  • Young, active patient
  • Stage IIB or greater

docs.title: Follow-up
docs.text:
• Reassess at 6-12 weeks
  • Ensure proper orthotic fit
  • Monitor for progression
  • Serial X-rays if worsening symptoms
  • Discuss surgery if no improvement

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
• Failed conservative treatment (minimum 3-6 months)
  • Progressive deformity
  • Stage II or greater disease
  • Young, active patients
  • Inability to tolerate bracing
  • Significant functional limitation

docs.title: Stage I: Tenosynovitis Only
docs.text:
Procedures: - PTT debridement and synovectomy - FDL tendon transfer (if >50% PTT damage) - Gastrocnemius recession (if contracture present)

Outcomes: - 80-90% good results - Rare to require this (usually treated non-operatively)

docs.title: Stage IIA: Flexible Deformity, Minimal Uncovering
docs.text:
Procedures (à la carte approach): 1. Medial displacement calcaneal osteotomy (MDCO) - Cornerstone 2. FDL tendon transfer - Replace dysfunctional PTT 3. Gastrocnemius recession - If contracture (>10° equinus) 4. ± Lateral column lengthening (if severe abduction)

Rationale: - MDCO: Shifts ground reaction force medially, decreases PTT demand - FDL transfer: Restores inversion strength - Gastrocnemius recession: Decreases valgus moment

Outcomes: - 80-90% good to excellent results - Patient satisfaction high - Preserves motion

docs.title: Stage IIB: Flexible Deformity, Significant Uncovering (>40%)
docs.text:
Procedures: 1. Medial displacement calcaneal osteotomy (MDCO) 2. FDL tendon transfer 3. Lateral column lengthening (Evans or Cotton osteotomy) - Evans: Calcaneal osteotomy, opens lateral column - Cotton: Medial cuneiform opening wedge 4. Gastrocnemius recession (if contracture)

Evans vs. Cotton: - Evans: More powerful correction, addresses forefoot abduction - Cotton: Plantarflexes forefoot, addresses dorsiflexion of 1st ray

Outcomes: - 75-85% good results - More extensive surgery = longer recovery - Risk of lateral overload pain

docs.title: Stage III: Fixed (Rigid) Deformity
docs.text:
Procedures: 1. Double or triple arthrodesis - Double: Talonavicular + subtalar fusion - Triple: Add calcaneocuboid fusion 2. ± Gastrocnemius recession

Rationale: - Cannot correct with osteotomies alone - Arthritis often present - Sacrifices motion but relieves pain

Outcomes: - 70-85% pain relief - Loss of hindfoot motion - Gait alterations - Risk of adjacent joint arthritis

docs.title: Stage IV: Valgus Ankle Arthritis
docs.text:
Procedures: 1. Deltoid ligament reconstruction (if ankle stable) 2. Ankle arthrodesis or total ankle replacement 3. Tibia-talus-calcaneus fusion (pantalar fusion)

Outcomes: - Salvage procedures - Variable outcomes - Significant functional limitation

docs.title: Medial Displacement Calcaneal Osteotomy (MDCO)
docs.text:
• Lateral incision
  • Oblique osteotomy 1-1.5 cm posterior to posterior facet
  • Shift posterior fragment medially 8-10 mm
  • Fix with 1-2 screws

docs.title: FDL Tendon Transfer
docs.text:
• Medial incision
  • Harvest FDL through separate plantar incision
  • Transfer to navicular
  • Secure with interference screw or suture anchor
  • Provides dynamic inversion support

docs.title: Lateral Column Lengthening (Evans)
docs.text:
• Lateral incision
  • Osteotomy through anterior calcaneus
  • Insert structural graft (10-12 mm)
  • Fix with plate or staples
  • Corrects forefoot abduction

docs.title: Gastrocnemius Recession
docs.text:
• Posteromedial incision
  • Release gastrocnemius aponeurosis (Strayer)
  • Or intramuscular recession (Baumann)
  • Check for neutral dorsiflexion

docs.title: Combination Surgery Algorithm
docs.text:
Stage IIA (Mild):
└─ MDCO + FDL transfer + Gastrocnemius recession

Stage IIB (Severe):
└─ MDCO + FDL transfer + Evans + Gastrocnemius recession

Stage III (Rigid):
└─ Double or Triple arthrodesis ± Gastrocnemius recession

Stage IV (Ankle involved):
└─ Pantalar fusion or Ankle fusion + hindfoot fusion

docs.title: Joint-Sparing Procedures (Stage I-II)
docs.text:
Weeks 0-6: - Short leg cast or splint - Non-weight bearing - Elevation

Weeks 6-8: - CAM boot - Begin protected weight-bearing

Weeks 8-12: - Progressive weight-bearing - Physical therapy - ROM exercises

Months 3-6: - Return to regular shoes with orthotic - Continue strengthening - Return to activities at 4-6 months

docs.title: Arthrodesis Procedures (Stage III-IV)
docs.text:
Weeks 0-6: - Short leg cast - Non-weight bearing - May need longer (up to 8-10 weeks)

Weeks 6-12: - CAM boot - Progressive weight-bearing once fusion evident

Months 3-12: - Return to activities at 6 months - Full recovery 12 months

docs.title: General
docs.text:
• Wound healing problems
  • Infection
  • DVT
  • Sural nerve injury (lateral procedures)
  • Tibial nerve injury (medial procedures)

docs.title: Specific to Procedures
docs.text:
MDCO: - Nonunion (rare) - Under/overcorrection

Evans: - Lateral column overload (5-10%) - Calcaneocuboid arthritis - Graft resorption

FDL Transfer: - Loss of great toe flexion strength (usually minimal) - Transfer failure

Arthrodesis: - Nonunion (5-15% triple arthrodesis) - Malunion - Adjacent joint arthritis - Hardware irritation

docs.title: Outcomes by Procedure
docs.text: Procedure Success Rate Return to Activity Patient Satisfaction MDCO + FDL (IIA) 80-90% 4-6 months 85-90% MDCO + FDL + Evans (IIB) 75-85% 6-9 months 75-85% Double/Triple arthrodesis (III) 70-85% 9-12 months 70-80%

docs.title: Key Surgical Principles
docs.text:
1. Address all components: Tendon, bony alignment, contracture
  2. Stage-appropriate surgery: Don't overtreat or undertreat
  3. Gastrocnemius contracture: Common and must be addressed
  4. Lateral column lengthening: Reserve for significant forefoot abduction
  5. Preserve motion when possible (joint-sparing procedures)
  6. Arthrodesis: For rigid deformity and arthritis only

docs.title: Revision Surgery
docs.text:
• Often needed if:
  • Inadequate initial correction
  • Progression of deformity
  • Persistent symptoms
  • May require conversion to arthrodesis

docs.title: Clinical Presentation
docs.text:
• Midfoot pain and swelling
  • Difficulty weight-bearing
  • Plantar ecchymosis (high suspicion for Lisfranc injury)
  • Often from low-energy mechanism (twist, fall)
  • High-energy trauma in MVA, crush injuries

docs.title: Anatomy
docs.text:
• Lisfranc Joint Complex: Tarsometatarsal (TMT) joints
  • Lisfranc Ligament: Strongest, connects medial cuneiform to 2nd metatarsal base
  • Keystone: 2nd metatarsal base recessed, provides stability
  • Ligament Injury: Leads to instability and deformity

docs.title: Mechanism
docs.text:
• Low-energy: Twist injury, fall (indirect)
  • High-energy: MVA, crush (direct)

docs.title: Myerson Classification
docs.text:
• Type A: Total incongruity (all TMT joints)
  • Type B: Partial incongruity
  • B1: Medial (1st TMT)
  • B2: Lateral (2nd-5th TMT)
  • Type C: Divergent (medial and lateral separation)

docs.title: Stability
docs.text:
• Stable: <2mm displacement, no diastasis
  • Unstable: >2mm displacement, any diastasis

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
• Plantar Ecchymosis: Pathognomonic sign
  • Midfoot Swelling: Diffuse
  • Tenderness: Over TMT joints
  • Piano Key Test: Dorsoplantar stress causes pain, instability
  • Abduction Stress: Reproduces pain
  • Passive Forefoot Pronation/Supination: Pain with stress

docs.title: Imaging
docs.text:
• Weight-bearing X-rays (Essential if possible)
  • AP, lateral, oblique foot
  • Non-weight-bearing X-rays: May miss subtle instability
  • Key Findings:
  • Diastasis between 1st and 2nd metatarsal (>2mm)
  • Loss of alignment at TMT joints

  • Fractures of metatarsal bases or cuneiforms

  • CT Scan: Better visualization of fractures, joint subluxation

  • MRI: Assess Lisfranc ligament integrity, occult fractures
  • Weight-bearing CT: Gold standard for subtle instability

docs.title: Suspicious Findings Requiring Further Workup
docs.text:
• Fleck sign (avulsion fracture)
  • Any diastasis between 1st and 2nd metatarsal
  • Loss of alignment at TMT joints
  • Plantar ecchymosis

docs.title: Indications (RARE - Most require surgery)
docs.text:
• No diastasis (<2mm)
  • Anatomic alignment on weight-bearing X-rays
  • No fracture displacement
  • Stable injury pattern
  • Low-demand patient

docs.title: Phase 1: Acute Immobilization (0-6 weeks)
docs.text:
• Short leg cast
  • Non-weight bearing
  • Strict compliance required
  • Ice, elevation

docs.title: Phase 2: Progressive Loading (6-12 weeks)
docs.text:
• Repeat X-rays at 6 weeks
  • If stable: CAM boot, protected weight-bearing
  • Continue non-weight bearing if any displacement

docs.title: Phase 3: Return to Activity (3-6 months)
docs.text:
• Gradual weight-bearing
  • Custom orthotic with arch support
  • Strengthening program
  • Carbon fiber insert or rigid sole shoe

docs.title: Critical Monitoring
docs.text:
• Serial X-rays: Weekly for first 3 weeks, then at 6 weeks
  • Weight-bearing X-rays at 6 weeks: Essential to confirm stability
  • Any displacement: Convert to surgery immediately

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
• High risk of displacement: Even "stable" injuries may displace
  • Importance of compliance: No weight-bearing, frequent X-rays
  • Threshold for surgery: Any displacement >2mm requires surgery
  • Long-term implications: Risk of post-traumatic arthritis
  • Arch support: Lifelong need for arch support/orthotics
  • Return to sports: May take 6-12 months

docs.title: Warning Signs
docs.text:
• Increased pain
  • Feeling of instability
  • Unable to maintain non-weight bearing
  • → Immediate X-ray needed

docs.title: Outcomes of Non-Surgical Treatment
docs.text:
• Success Rate: Variable, many studies show high failure rate
  • Risk of Displacement: 15-30% may displace even with casting
  • Post-traumatic Arthritis: Can occur even with anatomic reduction
  • Functional Outcomes: Generally worse than surgical treatment for unstable injuries

docs.title: Absolute Indications
docs.text:
• Any displacement >2mm on follow-up X-rays
  • Persistent pain despite immobilization
  • Patient non-compliance with non-weight bearing
  • Athlete or high-demand patient

docs.title: Relative Indications
docs.text:
• Even "stable" injuries may benefit from surgery
  • Low threshold for surgical fixation

docs.title: Follow-up Protocol
docs.text:
• Week 1-2: X-rays, assess for displacement
  • Week 3: X-rays
  • Week 6: Weight-bearing X-rays (critical)
  • Week 12: X-rays, assess healing
  • Thereafter: Monitor for arthritis development

docs.title: Low Threshold for Surgery
docs.text:
• Many experts recommend surgery for ALL Lisfranc ligament injuries
  • Non-operative treatment only for:
  • Isolated cuneonavicular injuries
  • Pure midfoot sprains without ligamentous disruption
  • Truly stable injuries confirmed on weight-bearing X-rays

docs.title: Subtle Instability
docs.text:
• Standard X-rays may miss instability
  • Weight-bearing imaging essential
  • CT or MRI if clinical suspicion high

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
1. Lisfranc injuries are often UNSTABLE → Most require surgery
  2. Non-operative treatment reserved for truly stable injuries only
  3. Serial X-rays mandatory to detect displacement
  4. Weight-bearing X-rays at 6 weeks are critical
  5. Low threshold for converting to surgical treatment
  6. Plantar ecchymosis = high suspicion for Lisfranc injury
  7. Long-term arch support needed regardless of treatment

docs.title: Indications for Surgery
docs.text:
• Diastasis >2mm between 1st and 2nd metatarsal
  • Any displacement at TMT joints
  • Unstable injury on weight-bearing X-rays
  • Fracture displacement
  • High-demand athlete
  • Most Lisfranc ligament injuries (low threshold for surgery)

docs.title: Timing of Surgery
docs.text:
• Acute (<3 weeks): ORIF if soft tissue permits
  • Delayed (if severe swelling): Wait for "wrinkle sign" (7-14 days)
  • Subacute (3-6 weeks): ORIF still possible
  • Chronic (>6 weeks): May need arthrodesis

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Acute injuries (<6 weeks)
  • Minimal arthritis
  • Young, active patients
  • Reducible displacement

docs.title: Technique
docs.text:
• Incisions: Typically 2 dorsal incisions (medial and lateral)
  • Reduction: Anatomic reduction essential (<2mm displacement)
  • Fixation Options:

A. Screw Fixation (Traditional) - Solid screws 1st-2nd TMT (across Lisfranc ligament) - Screws for other TMT joints as needed - Biomechanically strongest - Disadvantage: Requires hardware removal (6-12 months)

B. K-wire Fixation - Temporary fixation - Less stiff than screws - Risk of wire breakage, migration

C. Suture-Button (TightRope) - Flexible fixation across 1st-2nd TMT - Allows micro-motion - No hardware removal needed - Emerging technique, mixed early results

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text:
• Good to excellent: 50-70% (lower than expected)
  • Return to sports: 6-12 months
  • Hardware removal: Required at 3-6 months for screws
  • Post-traumatic arthritis: 25-50% develop regardless

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Severe comminution
  • Chronic injury (>6-12 weeks)
  • Pre-existing arthritis
  • Revision surgery
  • Older, lower-demand patients

docs.title: Technique
docs.text:
• Remove cartilage from affected TMT joints
  • Reduce anatomically
  • Fixation with screws or plates
  • May fuse 1st-3rd TMT joints (most mobile)
  • Consider preserving 4th-5th TMT (more mobile laterally)

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text:
• Good to excellent: 60-80%
  • Return to activity: 6-12 months
  • Advantages: Single surgery, no hardware removal, durable
  • Disadvantages: Loss of midfoot motion (usually minimal impact)

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Isolated Lisfranc ligament rupture
  • No fracture displacement
  • Chronic instability

docs.title: Technique
docs.text:
• Reconstruct Lisfranc ligament with tendon graft or suture tape
  • Anatomic drill tunnels
  • Secure with interference screws

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text:
• Limited long-term data
  • May preserve motion better than arthrodesis

docs.title: Decision Making: ORIF vs. Primary Arthrodesis
docs.text: Factor ORIF Primary Arthrodesis Injury timing Acute (<6 weeks) Chronic (>6-12 weeks) Age Younger Older Activity level High (athlete) Low to moderate Fracture pattern Minimal comminution Severe comminution Joint surface Intact Damaged Surgeon preference Varies Varies

docs.title: Controversy
docs.text:
• Some surgeons advocate primary arthrodesis for ALL Lisfranc injuries
  • Rationale: High rate of post-traumatic arthritis after ORIF, often requiring later fusion
  • Others prefer ORIF to preserve motion

docs.title: Which Joints to Fix/Fuse?
docs.text:
Medial Column (1st-3rd TMT): - Must be rigidly stable - Fix/fuse all displaced joints

Lateral Column (4th-5th TMT): - More mobile naturally - May use flexible fixation or no fixation if stable

docs.title: Reduction Techniques
docs.text:
• Use pointed reduction forceps
  • Temporary K-wire fixation
  • Confirm with fluoroscopy (AP, lateral, oblique)
  • Anatomic alignment critical (<2mm)

docs.title: Fixation Constructs
docs.text:
• 1st TMT: Plate or screw (medial to lateral)
  • 2nd TMT: Screw from medial cuneiform into 2nd MT base
  • 3rd TMT: Screw as needed
  • 4th-5th TMT: K-wires or screws if unstable

docs.title: ORIF
docs.text:
Weeks 0-6: - Short leg cast or splint - Non-weight bearing - Elevation

Weeks 6-8: - Weight-bearing X-rays to confirm stability - If stable: CAM boot, progressive weight-bearing

Weeks 8-12: - Progressive weight-bearing - Physical therapy - ROM exercises

Months 3-6: - Hardware removal at 3-6 months (if screws across 1st-2nd TMT) - Return to activity after hardware removal

Months 6-12: - Return to sports - May need arch support long-term

docs.title: Primary Arthrodesis
docs.text:
Weeks 0-8: - Short leg cast - Non-weight bearing

Weeks 8-12: - CAM boot, progressive weight-bearing - Once fusion evident on X-ray

Months 3-6: - Return to regular shoes with orthotic - Continue strengthening

Months 6-12: - Return to sports - Full recovery 12 months

docs.title: Intraoperative
docs.text:
• Difficulty achieving reduction
  • Neurovascular injury
  • Fracture during fixation

docs.title: Postoperative
docs.text:
• Loss of reduction (10-15%)
  • Hardware failure (K-wire breakage, screw loosening)
  • Infection (3-5%)
  • Wound healing problems
  • Post-traumatic arthritis (25-50%)
  • Chronic pain (common)
  • Nonunion (5-10% for arthrodesis)
  • Malunion
  • Complex regional pain syndrome (5%)

docs.title: Long-term
docs.text:
• Arthritis at TMT joints (very common)
  • Midfoot stiffness
  • Chronic pain
  • Altered gait
  • May require later arthrodesis

docs.title: ORIF
docs.text:
• Good to excellent results: 50-70%
  • Return to pre-injury level: 50-60%
  • Post-traumatic arthritis: 25-50%
  • Require later arthrodesis: 10-25%

docs.title: Primary Arthrodesis
docs.text:
• Good to excellent results: 60-80%
  • Return to activity: 70-80%
  • Single surgery: Advantage
  • Patient satisfaction: Often higher than ORIF

docs.title: Indications
docs.text:
• Loss of reduction after ORIF
  • Persistent pain and instability
  • Progressive arthritis

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
• Revision ORIF (if early)
  • Conversion to arthrodesis (most common)
  • Salvage arthrodesis

docs.title: Key Surgical Principles
docs.text:
1. Anatomic reduction mandatory: <2mm displacement
  2. Stabilize medial column rigidly: 1st-3rd TMT
  3. Consider primary arthrodesis for severe injuries, older patients
  4. Hardware removal required for screws across 1st-2nd TMT (ORIF)
  5. Long-term arch support often needed
  6. Counsel about arthritis risk: Common despite good surgery
  7. Low threshold for surgery: Better outcomes than non-operative treatment

docs.title: Athletes
docs.text:
• ORIF preferred to preserve motion
  • Realistic expectations about return to pre-injury level
  • May need 9-12 months

docs.title: Polytrauma
docs.text:
• May be missed in setting of multiple injuries
  • High index of suspicion needed

docs.title: Compartment Syndrome
docs.text:
• Can occur with high-energy Lisfranc injuries
  • Monitor closely, consider prophylactic fasciotomies

docs.title: Future Directions
docs.text:
• Suture-button fixation (emerging)
  • Biologic augmentation
  • Better prediction of who will develop arthritis

docs.title: 研究
docs.text: このページ群では、研究活動を「既発表（公開）」と「執筆中（非公開）」に厳密に分離して管理します。GitHub Pagesに掲載されるのは既発表の業績（公開可能な情報）のみであり、執筆中の原稿は公開リポジトリの追跡対象外として運用します。

docs.title: 非公開（執筆中）の取り扱い
docs.text:
執筆中の原稿、メモ、解析途中の結果は、リポジトリ直下のprivate/フォルダに配置することを推奨します。private/は.gitignoreにより追跡されず、GitHub Pagesにも含まれません。

ただし、機密性の高いデータ（症例情報、未匿名化データなど）は、この仕組みの範囲外として、所属施設の規程と情報セキュリティ方針に従って管理する必要があります。
